Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I move: That the amendments be agreed to. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill fulfils the promises made by the coalition in its election policy statement, Better Pay for Better Work. Before the 1993 election, the Australian Labor Party disguised its policy intentions and, after the election, betrayed the confidences of the Australian people. They legislated the most pro-union laws ever introduced into Australia. They did so at the insistence of the ACTU. The contrast with the coalition's legislation could not be more stark. The pre-election guarantee we gave workers was that we would keep awards and the Industrial Relations Commission and if you entered an agreement you would not be worse off than under the award. Today we make our guarantee the law and present a balanced system not dictated by some special interest group but a system fair for both employers and employees. Our new act is built on: commitments to a more direct relationship between employers and employees with a much reduced role for third party intervention; a fair go for all so that the system is appropriately balanced and delivers benefits for both employees and employers; genuine freedom of association and greater choice of union representation; a more accessible system; and a stronger sense of the rights and responsibilities of parties in the industrial relations system. The government remains committed to these principles. The bill, as amended, implements them. The task is now for employees and employers to use the opportunities the bill offers them. Under the legislation we have delivered what we said we would deliver. We have delivered an award system which will provide a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions with benefits beyond it generally being a matter for agreement at the enterprise or workplace level. We have delivered a system in which there will be more effective flexibility for parties in reaching agreements, a genuine choice of agreements, formal and informal, union and non-union, individual and collective. That is, we have put in place enabling legislation-legislation which is designed purposefully to avoid prescription and to enable employers and employees to find a home in the system which suits their particular needs. We do not favour one agreement stream over another. We do not want to corral employers and employees into one end of the system and boast that as a government we have achieved some remarkable success. We simply want to give them the general flexibility of the jurisdiction established by the legislation so that they can get what they want from the system. We have also formally introduced into the federal industrial relations system an individual agreement stream. This is a long overdue but profoundly significant change in emphasis in the jurisdiction. Not so long ago this would have seemed an inconceivable proposition at the Commonwealth level. It is an initiative that, for political reasons only, has been resisted by those on the other side of the House and by the trade union movement, but the needs of the modem workplace for simplicity, flexibility and closer direct relations between workers and their employers have won out. It is a new agreement stream which minimises third party intervention. It is designed, subject to a safety net, to get workers into jobs without delay, without conflict between award parties and without costly litigation. For many employers and employees Australian workplace agreements will symbolise that it is now safe to come back into the industrial relations system again. As a new option, Australian workplace agreements will change the character of the federal system. The system is no longer exclusively about registered organisations and collective bargaining; it is now about workers and employers and their particular and local needs. The bill's objects reinforce this, along with other amendments to the certified agreement and award streams which seek to emphasise the views of employers and their employees rather than those of tribunals and third parties. We have also delivered genuine freedom of association founded on effective protection against coercion or discrimination based on an individual's membership or non-membership of a union. Mr Speaker, I am delighted to say that today we abolished compulsory unionism. We have also delivered changes which will increase choice and accountability in relation to registered organisations. In making these changes, we invited regist-red organisations into the world of competihon and improved service delivery for their - embers. Legislated privilege and monopoly nghts have a dwindling relevance to modernity. Employers and employees will always have representational needs, and the bill embraces this concept firmly. But, equally, employers and employees deserve a quality return on the financial and personal trust that they place in organisations. For all their declining membership base, the government has given unions their last best chance to square themselves with workers. The bill is not anti-union, despite what some union leaders say. The bill provides unions with a shot at building their status as responsible organisations which provide a professional service geared to the contemporary workplace and the contemporary work force. We have delivered legislation which will ensure that appropriate standards of industrial conduct are observed. There will be a more effective regime to ensure that agreements are honoured. The commission's powers to curtail unlawful industrial action have been strengthened and secondary boycott provisions have been restored. (Extension of time granted) We have recognised the right to take industrial action. We have also ensured that both parties in the industrial system have proper regard for their responsibilities to one another and the wider community. We have delivered a workable system for dealing with unfair dismissal on the basis of a fair go all round and, in doing so, we have expressed an overwhelming community consensus that the previous Brereton system did nothing more than stifle employment growth and create division in the workplace. This was Labor's legacy, and the government has buried it. Under this government, harmonisation of federal and state systems of industrial relations is being pursued through complementary legislation and through a cooperative approach to administrative arrangements and service delivery. Again, the government is conscious of the need to gear industrial relations systems at all levels to the needs of the users. Industrial relations systems should not be characterised by institutionalisation of bureaucracy and undue process. Consistent with the forces affecting all areas of government at all levels, the system as a whole should be about delivering services to its users, ensuring their ease of access and providing quick and effective responses. This approach has affected many aspects of the bill, and it is an important force for future change. But it has had a more recent impact as well. This week the Victorian government moved legislatively to refer its powers over industrial relations to the Commonwealth. This sends a powerful message about the leadership of the Victorian government. It does, too, provide a vote of confidence in this government's vision of the workplace as embedded in this legislation. It is also an eminently practical decision which will ensure that businesses in Victoria will be able to consolidate their industrial relations strategies under the federal system and boost their efficiency as a result. Small and medium-sized businesses will be able to use federal arrangements for Australian workplace agreements or for collective agreements without the need for an award if that is their wish, and without the need to become embroiled in the jurisdictional and constitutional complexities which have dogged their quest for flexibility and productivity. This symbolises the capacity of governments to make real and substantial improvements in the way in which users interface with the industrial relations system. Similarly, the bill provides that employees and employers should have the right to choose whether they wish to be covered by an award or agreement in the state or the federal jurisdiction. The amendments to the provisions dealing with federal-state coverage maintain this principle. They continue to allow choice between federal awards and state employment agreements provided that the relevant state legislation contains certain protections for employees. In opening new options in the agreement stream in the changes to the role of organisations under the bill, in the harmonisation initiatives being undertaken by the government, in wearing down the borders between state and Commonwealth industrial relations jurisdictions, the government is demonstrating that the wider system can genuinely work for the benefit of its users-that is, that this industrial relations system can and should work in the context of modem standards of service delivery and best practice. The government also believes that the workplace relations system which its legislation establishes is appropriately balanced and delivers benefits for both employers and employees. We have had lengthy discussions with the Australian Democrats about the concerns they had in relation to some of the arrangements proposed by the government in its original bill. In these discussions there was a common respect for principle and a common commitment to making the legislation work for all Australians. I congratulate the Democrats on the cooperative and positive approach that they brought to this task, and thank them for the manner in which our discussions and negotiations were conducted. It is important to rebut the misrepresentation that the government's industrial relations policy is a low wage policy. The aim of the reforms is not to cut wages and conditions, but to promote higher productivity and a more flexible labour market and so provide the opportunity for higher wages and better conditions for workers. This, after all, was where the government staked its ground in its election policy statement, Better Pay for Better Work, which was so resoundingly affirmed by the Australian people on 2 March. The pressing need for genuine labour market reform to which this bill gives strong support is highlighted by Australia's dismal productivity performance over the last decade and a half. According to the OECD, between 1979 and 1995 Australia's annual rate of growth in labour productivity averaged a meagre 1.4 per cent. This was below the OECD average and far behind rates of productivity growth recorded in some of the dynamic economies to our north. These years of dismal productivity growth largely coincided with the era of centralised wage fixation. The pick-up in our productivity performance to the extent that we have had it in recent years with the introduction of enterprise bargaining, even on Labor's flawed model, goes to show the enormous potential gains which will flow from a genuine program of labour market reform such as ours. Only through genuine reform can we secure the productivity improvement that is necessary to underpin continued employment growth and a sustainable rise in living standards for all Australians. (E'Kfcnsion of time granted) In view of this, the award system will operate as a safety net of minimum wages and conditions. The detailed mechanism for its adjustment is being left within the jurisdiction of the commission. There arc a number of factors which the commissinn will he required to have regard to when it is adjusting the s;lfety net. These include a range ot economic considerations: productivity, inflation and unemployment. It will have to consider the needs of the low paid, equal pay and the need to prevent discriminatillO. The commission will also need to ensure that anv alteratiuns to v.:af!e relativities tween ;wards arc hascd llIl - kill, responsibility and the conditions under which work is performed. This requirement recognises the importance of rclati vi tics between awards for the viability or the award wage system in ensuring its capacity hoth to maintain the stability and equity of the system and to provide ongoing net protection. The government's kgislatilln does not extend, however, to internal relativities within awards. Indeed, the emphasis which we are proposing, and in particular the focus on the low paid and minimum safety net, may involve some compression of internal relativities. Such compression has occurred in the past when the commission has awarded flat dollar increases in award rates. In addition, while stahle relativities between awards arc important for the workability of the system and for their safety net role, the government anticipates that, over time, there will he increasing diversity in actual pay relationships as a result of the emphasis of the system on agreement making. Wages and conditions need to increasingly reflect local needs and circumstances. Similarly, in future, When maintaining the safety net, regard must be had hy the commission when altering wage relativities between awards to the skill, responsihility and the conditions under which work is perrormed. That is, the bill consigns to the deeper past still the notions of automatIC wage f1ow"oI1 between awards and comparative wage justice. The focusing of the award system on the provision of minimum terms and conditions of employment will apply to all awards, regardless of their customary status as either minimum rates or paid rates. All awards will be simplified. The same allowable matters and the same process and timing will apply. There will not be new paid rates awards. Over time, and following consultation between the parties, it is expected that existing paid rates structures will be phased out and translated into minimum rates arrangements under the supervision of the commission. Transitional provisions in the bill work to ensure that overall pay entitlements are not reduced as part of such conversion process. be- Wages and conditions beyond the minimum safety net will be a matter for the parties themselves to settle through enterprise and workplace agreements. In exceptional circumstances, there is provision for special case arbitration in certain critical dispute situations and in situations where paid rates awards have customarily applied. However, this is only where all efforts to reach an agreement have been exhausted and the exceptional nature of any fixed term arbitration undertaken in these circumstances is reflected in the conditions that apply, including consideration by a full bench of the public interest, how productivity might be improved and the conduct of the negotiating parties. In addition, any resultant award will not generally be able to be varied or to form part of the benchmark for the no disadvantage test for any subsequent bargaining. Strong incentives are maintained in the workplace relations framework generally to focus the system on agreement making rather than recourse to the commission. Even then, conciliation must be exhausted so that any arbitration other than general adjustments to the safety net will be a last resort confined to special and isolated cases. The expectation is that most parties who have been on paid rates awards will be covered by agreements. This is not new, as employees covered by paid rates awards have generally made the transition to enterprise bargaining so that their actual terms and conditions are now determined by agreements, rather than awards. Amendments to the bill also provide that award minima will act as the benchmark for the tests which are to apply to formalised agreements. In order to be formalised, all agreements will now be required to satisfy a modified version of the existing no disadvantage test. In the light of the move to the vetting of AW As provided for in the amendments agreed with the Democrats and against the background of the award simplification process, the government believes that the new no disadvantage test provides a practical way of delivering the government's commitments while affording considerable t1exibility to the parties. In this context, the legislation makes it clear that the no disadvantage test is a global one. That is, the test is whether an agreement would result in a reduction in the overall terms and conditions of employees to be covered. The government's intention is that, apart from this overall assessment, t1exibility not be constrained. Subject only to the global test, employers and employees are now at liberty to strike genuinely innovative agreements without any contrivances or artificial restrictions. It would be up to the Employment Advocate or the commission to weigh up the respective elements of the different components of a proposed agreement in deciding whether there was any disadvantage to employees in their overall terms and conditions of employment. Different sorts of considerations might be relevant in different contexts. As such, any term or condition of employment may be negotiated and dealt with by agreement, provided it is consistent with the act. The government's approach to the reform of workplace relations in Australia retains an important role for the commission, whose status and involvement will continue to be integral to the effective working of our system of workplace relations. (Extension of time granted) The commission's role will be different in a number of important respects under the new legislation as employers and employees increasingly take responsibility for their own industrial relations and agreement making and awards become a safety net of minimum wages and conditions. The commission will have a particular role in ensuring the establishment and maintenance of the award safety net, encouraging the making of certified agreements, overseeing the conduct of workplace bargaining for certified agreements and ensuring that the parties to such agreements and awards comply with their industrial responsibilities and obligations. It will have responsibility for managing the simplification for the award safety net and for encouraging the spread of and improved access to part-time work with pro rata conditions and reasonable predictability of working hours. The amendments to the bill do broaden the commission's role in several respects, but we have focused the commission's role, particularly and importantly for the benefit of the low paid. The government's submission to the commission, foreshadowed last weekend by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), is yet again evidence of our concern for the low paid, both in respect of the wages which they receive and their prospects of both retaining the jobs they have and for the unemployed securing a job in the future. Where the commission has a role in intervening beyond the minimum safety net of allowable award matters, the legislation ensures that this is appropriately circumscribed so that the focus of the system on agreement making at the enterprise and workplace levels is maintained. There are a number of criteria that will have to be met before the commission can make such orders. These are intended to ensure that the jurisdiction is confined to exceptional matters and that there is no reasonable prospect of their being settled by agreement. The exceptional matters orders include a requirement that they relate to a single matter and apply to only a single business unless the commission is satisfied that an application is appropriate. Such acceptable matters provisions cannot undermine the award simplification process, or the strong emphasis of the legislation on the role of awards as setting minimum wages and conditions overall, while actual wage determination is principally managed through formal or informal agreements made at the workplace level. I have often referred to the consultative process which began before the election last March and has led to the legislation which will be concluded today. It was a process which included employers, employer organisations, unions, the ACTU, governments-state and territory-women' s organisations and churches, and ethnic community and welfare groups. We have henefited considerably from their comments and suggestions-we have taken many on board-and the government is grateful for their effort and involvement. At the same time, some individual organisations and pcople who took part in that process do stand out in terms of the depth, consistency and strength of their ongoing contribution to the development of the hill. It is appropriate today that their names go on the record. In particular, I wish to acknowledge the contributions of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Bryan Noakes and Reg Hamilton provided very constructive and important support throughout the process. The ACTU were very involved through the committee on industrial legislation. I particularly acknowledge the work done by Tim Pallas and John Cairns in that respect. Our thanks go to the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Retailers Association, the National Farmers Federation and the Labour Council of New South Wales, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Western Australian Chamher of Commerce and Industry, Mr Brendan Macarthy, the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Michael Angwin, Professor Charles Mulvey, Paul Houlihan and Dr Chris Jessup QC. I am also grateful to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel for continuing to provide us with consistently high quality legislative drafting against very short deadlines. I also thank the Department of Industrial Relations, which has throughout the process demonstrated its professionalism, capacity for auth?ritative technical advice and openness to l-novative approaches to policy and institutIonal reforms and for, ahove all, its singular ability to provide a quality service to the government of the day. I also particularly want to acknowledge the work done by my ministerial staff in the process prior to the election and throughout a very long eight months. To Peter Richards, my chief of staff; to Jonathan Hamberger, who worked for me once before as an adviser on industrial relations and who is a specialist par excellence in this field, and to Nick Hordern, who worked with me both as a policy adviser and as a media adviser all through the process-my special and grateful thanks. Thanks also go to my other ministerial staff who provided great support and worked many hours to see the successful conclusion of this bill. The task for the reformist is not over. The policy debate must go on. For business and for employers and employees the pressing task is to take advantage of the opportunities provided by the new laws. The government, in its role as an employer, needs to address its own human resources strategy. We also need to encourage better practices in key industries like the waterfront, construction and meat processing industries and other industries. I place on record my thanks to the Prime Minister and to my colleagues for the support that they have given me in this process. Lastly, I thank the Australian people for the confidence with which they trusted us to present this bill and to see its successful carriage today.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I would like to commence in the tone that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) concluded-it might be the only thing about which we agree-and to thank some people for their contribution to the debate which led to us dealing with these amendments today. I particularly thank Senator Sherry and the Labor senators for their excellent and diligent work throughout a very complex process of dealing with these and many other amendments which were not successful in the Senate. I thank the clerks in the House and the Senate for their great assistance to the opposition in a very complex task of drafting, which they did very effectively and conscientiously. On behalf of all my Labor colleagues here and in the Senate, I thank David Fredericks for the work he did in assisting us in the drafting of these amendments and in the processing and management of them. The opposition recognises what is, for it, unpleasant political reality that these amenddisputes. ments mean that this flawed and unfair bill has been passed by the Senate with many of its worse features intact and its original critieven cisms still valid. Our original very lengthy. I made a half-hour speech, we moved 300 amendments and many of our ised colleagues spoke, so I will not repeat all that. But our concerns came down to three core principles. Our concerns were that this bill undermined the Industrial Relations CommisIndustrial sion, it undermined the award system and it undermined the rights of workers to organise. All these three concerns continue, slightly modified in some instances. But, even after these amendments, those concerns are still conditions. valid. The Industrial Relations Commission, example, has lost its general jurisdiction arbitrate to settle industrial disputes. The significance of that change to industrial relations in Australia and many aspects of economy and society in future is a remarkable thing which I think most Australians are not aware of. That has gone, despite the assurance of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the Industrial Relations Commission would keep its powers. For every worker working in Australia now, the award system, which has underpinned and been the vehicle for advancement of workers' wages and conditions for generations, has played some, if not the total, role in determinunder ing wages and working conditions. They are now stripped back as a result of these amendminister ments to 20 allowable matters rather than merely 18-but the balance still disappears 18 months. The clock has started ticking so many fundamental award conditions for Australian workers, despite the Minister's guarantee that no worker would lose their award conditions. The right to organise is still at risk, most particularly due to, simply summarised, the massive increases in penalties and punishwith ments and the easier access to these sanctions rather than the use of the conciliation and arbitration process to which Australians have become accustomed and which has been part of the cooperative process leading to, in an recent years, a record low level of industrial This is, unfortunately, already showing signs of increasing under the industrial relations management of this government, before we run into the problems that this criticisms were bill might generate. Of course, the strongest and the best organworkers will win their lost conditions back. Some already have a guarantee to that effect. But for others-those who need the award protections most, those who need the Relations Commission most, those who need the support of the collective organisations that represent them most-these provisions will be gone forever. Many workers, many workplaces, will be back to 20 basic Think of the circumstances in which the for workers find themselves when trying to to negotiate to win these conditions back. The person with whom they are negotiating knows that if no agreement is reached the conditions our disappear. There is no imperative on the employer to agree at all. Many reasonable employers will. But the point of it is that the fundamental protections that these awards provide are against the activities of unreasonable employers, and they are the ones who are empowered by this bill. So much for the rock solid guarantee that no worker would be worse off. Not that that should be a surprise, of course, because we have already established quite clearly that the government's submission to the Industrial Relations Commission, to which the referred in his speech, low paid workers will be $1,000 a year worse off than in they would have been under the proposals of for the previous Labor government. So much for the fact that no worker would be worse off. Prime (Extension of time granted) Where does that leave us after the passage of the workplace relations bill? It still leaves us with a fundamentally flawed bill. It still leaves us with an unfair bill. It still leaves us a bill that undermines the three pillars of Australian industrial relations which have protected Australian workers. It leaves us with the Prime Minister's promises to workers during the election campaign lying in a crumpled heap, just next to those from the budget and the other broken promises. Looking forward, where do we go to from here? Strenuous as our opposition to this bill continues to be, it will become the law quite soon. Despite our continuing opposition, that will occur. How are we to look forward to measure the success or failure of this bill? We have found people running away very hard from the idea of what criteria should be set to measure the success of this bill. We have had a few comments about what should not be used. Let me make some suggestions of criteria, apart from the Prime Minister's two promises that no worker would be worse off and no worker would lose their award conditions. What are other broader social and economic criteria? Will there be fewer industrial disputes over this three-year term under this regime than there were in the last three years under the old regime? Each time. I raise this, the media likes to interpret it as some sort of forecast industrial war. I am not predicting industrial Armageddon. The signs at the moment are not encouraging about what is going to happen in terms of the number of industrial disputes in Australia, but there is still time--even under this bill-for the government to adopt a cooperative approach that would not lead to a major increase in industrial disputes. The signs are not very optimistic, either about the current trends or about this bill, but let us wait and see and measure this bill against that criterion first. Perhaps more importantly, will there be more jobs created in this parliamentary term under this regime than there were in the last term of the parliament? Particularly, will there be more jobs created in small business? On the social criterion of fairness, will the distribution of wage outcomes and benefits be fairer after this bill than it was before it? Will the gap between high and low incomes narrow or widen? Will the gap between male and female incomes narrow or widen? The sign are not good, but let us see. We have had great emphasis on how this will boost productivity. Will labour productivity increase faster after this bill than the current trend rate of 1.75 per cent per annum? I think that is unlikely, but let us see. As to the broader economic objectives with regard to continuing growth, will the overall wage outcomes be more consistent with the low inflation, low interest rate environment than the outcomes under the present system? It may be that over time other criteria will be set. But it seems to me that is not a bad starting point against which to measure the success of this proposed new industrial relations regime. At least these criteria of success look for positive outcomes. I note that the minister has recently raised some criteria that are essentially negative-criteria that he will not use. For example, he said he would not be measuring the success of the legislation by simply counting the number of employees covered by AWAs. That is a bit of an irony, because we remember the same person constantly saying that enterprise flexibility agreements were clearly a failure because they had not been used in any significant numbers. It of is interesting to ask why the minister is retreating from applying the same standard to his new Australian workplace agreement stream, and we will look to see how many people take up these proposals. I also asked the minister previously in the parliament to give us an assurance, because of the great job benefits he sees in this bill, that the government will create more than 500,000 jobs in small business in this term. He has not yet given that assurance. We continue to seek it. We will monitor with interest the outcomes in that regard. I think it is highly unlikely that it is a goal that can be achieved; nevertheless, it is a very significant criterion for every Australian family, for every Australian unemployed worker, for all those in employment who are concerned about their employment security. (Extension of time granted) The principle concern is, at its core, even after these inadequate, unsatisfactory amendments, this is a bill which fundamentally misunderstands the nature of the labour market. It continues to be predicated on the assumption of equality of bargaining power in the workplace between employers and employees. That assumption is so fundamentally flawed-so obviously flawed to anyone who has been on a workplace floor for more than five minutes, or spoken to workers rather than spoken at them, who has listened to workers-that it is hard to believe that you could build an edifice on such a flawed structure. It is the fundamental flaws of that structure that permeate every element of this bill. It is what inevitably means, however one measures the intentions of those who initiated the bill or those who negotiated the amendments, that the outcome of this process must be fundamentally flawed and can be only an unfair outcome because of the absolute failure to recognise that aspect of the labour market and the need for elements of this legislation to cope with the consequences of that fundamental difference in bargaining power in the workplace. It is those problems and that circumstance that pervades this bill and means that it has the regressive social consequences about which we are so apprehensive without having the capacity to deliver the economic benefits which the government seeks. Secondly, looking prospectively, going beyond the immediate concerns, this bill absolutely fails to address, and by its inactivithe ty will exacerbate, the biggest issue in workplaces today. It is none of the things the minister has spoken about. When you go into workplaces and talk to workers, when you look at the surveys that the Department of Industrial Relations itself does-and I suspect when you look at the market research the Liberal Party does-the biggest issue for Australian workers today is the increased stress and insecurity in their workplaces. Workers say they are having to work harder, having to work longer and are feeling less secure because circumstances continue to change under their feet every day. They find themselves negotiating away conditions that they value to preserve living standards that they need. They feel that they cannot see in the future the security to which they have aspired. There is a significant emergence of bargaining fatigue. Even those who have done very well under enterprise bargaining-and that is not all-are flagging under the pressure of being called upon to do it again and again. Under this bill, they are called upon to enter into an extra round of enterprise bargaining merely to win back conditions that are currently guaranteed to them under their award. I can assure the House-particularly the government members-that I have not found a worker who is looking forward to a round of enterprise bargaining to win back their award conditions that the government has arbitrarily taken away from them by this legislation. The Democrats have conspired in having taken those away from them, with only the most meagre-but welcome-modifications. This bill fails to address the most profound issue affecting workers in their workplaces today-the issue of stress and insecurity. By its inadvertence and by its increased emphasis on the nature of the negotiations at the workplace, the increased need for enterprise bargaining and workplace bargaining, that insecurity and that stress will be increased. All the evidence from Victoria and Western Australia, where there has been increased emphasis in this way on individual contracts and on the nature of bargaining fundamentally underpinning Australian workplace agreements, has been that the stress, the insecurity, pressure and the working hours for workers under those agreements have gone up. That leads me to the third point about the future. This bill fundamentally ignores the emerging issue of working hours and the fair distribution of work in our society. With the changes being made, we are finding that working hours for those in work are going up while more and more Australians are either seeking work or seeking increased hours of work. (Extension of time granted) As with the minister, I will make sure this is my last extension. I thank the House for its agreement. As we are debating the amendments that the government has moved and the bill as a consequence, I might continue to talk about that. It might cause you concern but I might do so. There is a very serious issue emerging which all governments should be addressing and which people with social concern need to give consideration to and which the Labor Party in opposition will be developing policies about as a response and to put to the people. It i:; this issue of the fair distribution of work. the fact that those in work are working [(Inger hours while more and more Australian, arc either sccking work or seeking more homs or work. You would huve to say there is one achievement out of these amendments. Clearly, you can see the advantage to Mr Reith within the Liberal Party. It might have been smart politics but it is very bad industrial relations. That, I remind the minister, is actually his joh. This bill was talked out on the second reading in the House when we had 15 hours and 52 minutes. Dr Lawrence interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: The member interjects 'no committee stage debate'. In fact, we had two hours and 32 minutes, including 17 speakers, which did not exclude the minister. In the Senate, the opposition parties ran a filibuster to gi ve us the second longest debate in the Senate in the history of parliamentary debate in the Senate. Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I do keep saying to the opposition that we were never as feral as this when we were in opposition to which they say, 'No, nothing's changed. We're just as bad an opposition as you were.' In paragraph 4, it says: The number of divisions has also increased from an average of 2 per sitting over the period to 3.7 per sitting in 1996. So there is the evidence proof positive that they have virtually doubled the number of divisions this year. Going back to the figures which are inclusive to 1987, the opposition parties are now the all-time record holders. They are the all-time callers of divisions. They hold the all-time record. They hold the record for the sittings at which five or more divisions occurred over that period. They are nudging the record of sittings at which at least one division occurred as well. Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Just very briefly, the only reason the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has got up today is he is posturing with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the chair. We have half the front-bench missing in action today. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is away. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) is away. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) is buying a new pair of fish-nets. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is away. Who do we have at the table? The person who cannot ever help himself talking about leadership because it is what he aspires to. In the meantime, he wants the Minister for Foreign Affairs's position. He thinks he has solved industrial relations and wants the foreign affairs post. I suggested that to him and he said to me, 'You should be able to get some decent questions up against the foreign minister today,' and I said, 'Why don't you keep him in the House?' Let us have a bit of a discussion about private comment, leader of government business. We are not going to divide on this motion, but let me say this: the fact of the matter is that, for all of the bluster that the leader goes on with about the amount of time in this debate, he refuses to allow the detail to be debated in this House. He gagged through the committee stage when this hill was last in the House and he is now gagging the amendments coming back from the Senate. The reality is the devil is in the detail of this biil and he will avoid at any cost a consideration of the detail. That is why he is moving the gag. That is why he wants to stop members on this side of the House exposing that detail. That is why we believe this is just another example of the way in which this government is trying to hide the detail from the Australian public, to develop the means by which the hattlers of Australia get further repressed under their provisions. It is for that reason that, whilst we will not oppose it. we resist and demonstrate our opposition most strongly to the tactics that they have been implementing in this House. I now want the opportunity for more speakers on our side to get the measly half hour that he has allowed in terms of all of the debate that went on in the Senate-hours and hours of debate. He had 50 hours of negotiation with the picnic hamper and Cheryl Kernot, and he is allowing one half hour in this House. It is a disgrace and we oppose it. Question resolved in the affirmative. Consideration of Senate Message

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I want to'thank the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) for agreeing to the gag. This is absolutely unprecedented and delightful. Well done. Thank you, Simon. This is indeed an historic occasion. It has b.een some 10 years, perhaps 12 altogether, Sll1ce the initial divide in the industrial tions debate in this country. Members will recall that, for decade after decade, largely both sides of politics supported the centralised command driven model of industrial relations. Both sides of politics supported national wage cases. Both sides of politics supported a system where employers and employees were kept apart from each other in negotiations - bout their conditions of employment and mdeed about their wages. . It Was in 1984 that my side of politics fmally started to set a divide in the political debate in Australia. In setting that divide, increasingly, my side of politics has seen a need to move to a more modem and open system, to devolve industrial relations back to the parties where it really matters-that is, the parties at the individual work circumstance that happens to exist. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill we are discussing today goes a long way towards achieving that objective. It is another step in the train of devolution of responsibility from central arbitral bodies back to the central players, the real players-that is, the work force and the management in all the businesses around Australia. One of the things I noticed today as I looked at the Notice Paper is that it is 21 November 1996. I recall that it was on 21 April 1993 that the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, went to an Institute of Company Directors meeting in Melbourne and made two basic propositions. He said, firstly, that the award system was too complex, that it was too full of minutiae and that the awards ought to be simplified. He said that the awards should be brought down to basic core conditions as a safety net for conditions of employment in Australia. He did not say anything about having a single national minimum wage, like the United States. What he said was that awards should be simplified and brought back to core conditions. I have to say that this legislation now accomplishes what the then Prime Minister on 21 April 1993 said should happen. The second major point that Paul Keating relamade in that address to the Institute of Company Directors was that, where workplaces were largely non-unionised-and I have to say that is the bulk of workplaces in our country; certainly 75 per cent, and perhaps more, of the private sector workplaces in Australia are non-unionised-there should be an opportunity for those employees and their employers to negotiate agreements outside the formalised industrial relations system, leaving aside the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and leaving aside the formal arbitral process. But he also said that there should be some minimum standard set of conditions described by the award to underpin that. Literally, this legislation brings to fruition what the then Prime Minister, the then leader of the Labor Party-the party which now sits in opposition-wanted to accomplish. It seems to me an unbelievable dichotomy that the Labor Party sits there and argues hour after hour, point after point, against these basic propositions that its then leader, its Prime Minister, proposed to the nation. I recall that the present member for Kingsford-Smith, Laurie Brereton, wanted to implement what Paul Keating said should happen but Laurie Brereton was prevented by the union leaders from continuing down that path. We have picked up the option based on our policy differential, which we started in 1984 and which has continued since that day, to try to change the system, to make a more cooperati ve workplace culture, to make Australia more productive, to make our industry more efficient and to make more jobs for Australians. (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I want to speak briefly this morning on a matter which I think has received far too little attention from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) and indeed from the Democrats. I was most disappointed to see the Democrats in the Senate agreeing to conditions which will see the position of women in our society deteriorate. I know the minister blusters about this, because it is a point of great sensitivity, but there is now an enormous amount of evidence showing that women under many circumstances, even of enterprise bargaining, are the losers. They lose wages and they lose flexibility and hours. It is a matter that requires very considerable attention from the community because what is proposed in this legislation, and what will now be enacted, is a set of circumstances which makes the difficulties that women already face pale into insignificance. The government is fond of talking about their valuing of families. They have made much of the fact that in their view this legislation assists those people, mainly women, who have dual responsibilities-that is, not only in the workplace but at home. They talk about family friendly arrangements, but the evidence to date suggests that the opposite is occurring in this country and elsewhere. In New Zealand, for example, it is very clear that under these workplace agreements, which resemble what has been agreed with the Democrats here, women are the ones most likely to trade off hours, which makes it more difficult for them to meet family responsibilities. Unlike men in that community, it was found that women do not get any increased wage, so they are actually losing the flexibility and losing the hours. Mr Reith-This is not New Zealand.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Because of concerns about the trends that were evident in New Zealand and concerns amongst women here on our side of politics-including our minister of the day-that there might be some deterioration in women's positions under enterprise bargaining, and certainly under workplace agreements, a flexible working hours and women's project was undertaken under the Sex Discrimination Act. The work that was done there shows very clearly what has been shown elsewhere. In investigating the range of changes made to working time arrangements in enterprise agreements, the effects on women's lives of demands for increasing flexibility and hours were very clear. Women even now have been trading off hours and conditions in a way that is not true of men. That has a lot to do with the way women's work is constructed. They are more likely to be in non-unionised areas of work, they are more likely to work in isolation and they are less likely to have the protection of awards. In other words, they are already subject to the winds that you would now have blow over the entire Australian community. They find it very difficult in many cases to negotiate and to get the sorts of improvements that are supposed to flow from these individual agreements. For example, in Western Australia, where you have had workplace agreements now for some time, there has been some improvement in men's wages: they have traded them off against hours and other flexibility. But, in the case of women, they have traded off the hours, they have reduced flexibility and there is more shift work and weekend workwithout increases in pay. Women's wages in Western Australia are now well below the national average whereas men's wages are above it. In other words, the dispersion and the difference are growing under the sort of system that has now been embraced by the government and, I must say to my great disappointment, by the Democrats. The Democrats would have us believe that they are very sympathetic to women in our community. They make much of the fact that theirs is a largely female party, both in its representation and in its membership. Yet they have, by negotiation with the government, clearly delivered to the women of Australia a significant deterioration in working conditions. It is very clear that not only the work undertaken under the flexible working hours and women's project but also the 1995 report of the Industrial Relations Commission on enterprise bargaining, which was recently released after a long delay, show a large amount of information that confirms what I have been saying. Unfortunately, this report will now come out once every two yearsthat is a compromise, I suppose-instead of the three years that was proposed. What you see in these agreements is that women's hours of work are discussed-some 65 per cent of agreements and 74 per cent of private agreements in particular. And what are they doing? They are trading off flexibility. When you ask women what they want in the workplace they say that they would prefer predictability: they would prefer to work Monday to Friday, nine to five. Yet what is happening here is that they are being forced to work less predictable hours in areas where they are asked to work increasing hours, and they are not getting the wage increases right now. What is happeningMr Reith-You casualised them.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: This is for full-time workers. These are the effects that OCCurring for full-time workers. They have less control over their working lives and not sUrprisingly, resent it. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: O'Connor) (10.55 a.m.)Isn't it amazing to see the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) crying crocodile tears about women's issues. Women to her mean advancement of her political career. She has never had a serious and definite commitment to their welfare. What is more, considering her background, she wouldn't know, she wouldn't understand; she has never been in contact with the genuine working women of Australia. She comes in here and runs this sort of stuff after she has had a talk to a couple of her female mates, possibly in academia somewhere. I stand here as someone who, up until my entry to this parliament and still-through association with my children, who run our family businesses-actually delivers jobs to women, actually gives them the opportunity to bring their kids to work. You can go to one of these places and have a look at that tomorrow. We know what they want. They want the opportunity to get a job where they can set some hours flexibly, which is what this legislation will provide. That is what they want, and that is why they have deserted you. You did not learn the lesson in Lindsay. You went out there and ran your fear campaign-everyone would be working for $3 a day-and the people out there rejected you, because they saw that it was absolutely necessary for their convenience, for their interests and for the future of their children that our labour arrangements in Australia change. You heard President Clinton here yesterday. He came to us with a simple message: Australia is no island, and Australia cannot operate in the international labour markets by giving pay increases just because we want them. Whether we like it or not, that is stealing from our children. You kid yourselves that you can legislate wage increases when in fact the marketplace says, 'We'll pick up our capital goods. We'll go to another country.' You will leave the children of this great nation with nowhere to go. That is are already what you are talking about. You stand up here and talk about wages in they, other countries, and I know that they are extremely low. I also know that those people are extremely unproductive. It would take a lot for those on $3 a day to deliver the same outcome that some Australian worker will deliver on twelve bucks an hour. That is the reality. We can be competitive. But, unless that $12 has a direct relationship to productivity, nobody in Australia will be able to afford to pay it, because nobody will buy their goods at the end cost. We are past that point. If you read the papers today, there is our party trying to be a little more conservative on our international trade dealings in terms of protection, and the academics are out saying, 'Don't. Go for it.' You people did a wonderful thing for the working class. You are the ones-first under Whitlam, then under Keating-who chopped the hell out of protection and then told Australian employers to stick with the regulated labour market. What did they do? They said, 'Thank very much, we're leaving.' Unfortunately, you didn't have the law to nail their feet to the antiquated work practices and workshops-that is what you didn't haveand they left. Pick up your shirt. What has it got written on the back? 'Speedo. Made in China.' A great Australian name. That is what you have done. The purpose of this legislation is to re-establish the rights of Australian working people to be well paid for good work. If we do not do it, the world is going to laugh us out of existence. You can go on living in fairyland but, if you have some commitment to the children, any wage increase that is not tied to productivity is like your $80 billion borrowing: it is stealing from your kids. If workers get wage increases that cannot be justified by productivity, they are just further disadvantaging their own childrenand I think a very large number of the workers now know it. That is why the people in Lindsay told you to go bowl your hoop. If you do not wake up to that and to a few of the other fundamental issues, the present 40 members are going to be 20-we will not mind that. But, to tell you the truth, I would like your numbers to be closer to ours. I do not mind a decent fight. I am getting a bit fed up with beating you blokes by so many votes. Mr Martin-No, you are not.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I waited a long time for it, Stephen. But the reality is that that is the message for you: wake up to yourselves; go out and sell what is common sense and in the interests of their children.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: There is some inconsistency that appears in the government ranks. On the one hand, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) is saying in question time that the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill will be the source of pay rises and higher living standards for Australian workers. On the other hand, the previous speaker, the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), has been stressing the need for suppressing wages. He certainly stressed a very conservative approach to the consideration of wage rises. In any event, the reality is that since the 1980s every pay rise that a worker has obtained has been based on productivity. Indeed, a lot of the blue-collar assault on the Labor Party was their perception that every time they wanted a wage increase they had to sweat blood for it. The $8 pay increase that the government are talking about flowing on to some classes of wage earners would go to areas where the workers have not been able to achieve pay rises, mainly because the recessed state of the industry has not enabled them to bargain in the context of productivity improvements. It is, by and large, in those industries that have been substantially non-unionised where of productivity improvements have not occurred. In all other sectors a pay rise has to be based on specific productivity increases. I have been involved in countless numbers of cases where it has been very difficult to convince the Australian Industrial Relations Commission that the required percentage of productivity improvements have occurred. It is quite wrong to say that wage rates today do not reflect productivity increases. The other area I want to focus on is the misnomer to suggest-as has been suggested in answer to questions-that unemployment will be solved because of stricter and tighter unfair dismissal provisions contained in the legislation. That just will not occur. The reality is that, as the annual report of the Industrial Relations Court indicates, fewer than two per cent of involuntary terminations come before the court as unfair dismissal cases. In terms of the impact that that safety net has-and this is a real safety net because it enables workers who have been unfairly dismissed to preserve not only their own interests but also those of their family-30 per cent of those unfairly dismissed and who have brought cases are over the age of 40. We know how increasingly difficult it is for them to obtain employment. Of the unfair dismissals, 42 per cent come from those whose wages fall between $20,000 and $35,000 a year. This is the classic battler wage group. They are going to be disadvantaged by not having access to the provisions. Also, 56 per cent of those workers are without post-school qualifications. The unfair dismissal provisions have been the actual safety net for the battlers, for those who have been downtrodden. The irony of this bill is that the tighter restrictions will probably mean that the unionised work force will have better unfair dismissal provisions because they will be able to rely on the general industrial dispute provisions, as has been demonstrated in the Vista Paper Products case, the Ranger Uranium case and the Boyne Smelter case. Where workplaces are unionised, they will be able to create industrial disputes-albeit they will have to escalate that to the stage of a 'critical dispute' under these provisions. But, ironically, it is those unionised work forces that will have access to better unfair dismissal provisions. It is the poor old non-unionised battler-to use the now cliched expression of the government-who will really be prejudiced by the removal of the unfair dismissal provisions. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: l am delighted to participate in this very historic debate here today, even though it is only for a short while. However, it goes back to 1986 when the minister at the table, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), the Hon. Neil Brown and I developed the embryo of the current industrial relations policy. I also acknowledge the presence of the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith). He also participated in those early debates to develop a freer and more flexible industrial relations system. It is 10 years almost to the day that those original and very thoughtful ideas were put forward. I also pay tribute to the minister at the table for his contribution during that 10-year period when we argued with the then government. The proof of the success of our particular propositions in opposition is that the Labor government agreed with a more flexible enterprise agreement but, unfortunately, they could not get away from the shackles of the union movement. I also put on the public record the excellent work that the minister at the table did during the election campaign, where the Labor government did everything in their power to misrepresent what the opposition at that time were proposing. The minister got through the campaign, faithfully put our proposition and then has converted that to a legislative program that is here before the House on this very historic occasion. We see the situation where the enterprise agreements are now true enterprise agreements between the employer and the employee under the normal contractual arrangement, not by a third party, the Industrial Relations Commission, interfering with that sensitive and personal relationship between management and the work force. The minister has done an outstanding job in preparing the detailed schedule. I also put on the record the cooperation of the Australian Democrats in allowing the government to get a main plank of their election platform through the Senate. It has now returned to the House on this very historic occasion. We see the situation where the unfair dismissals law has been chucked out. Most members on the other side of the parliament would understand what a good thing that is. They understood it was not working and was causing them considerable difficulty. The Employment Advocate will make sure that those employees who want some assistance can get it. They will be able to use the services of the Employment Advocate to ensure that any agreement they reach with their employer is correct and reflects their aspirations in the workplace, and make sure that any employer does not victimise employees, as has been the allegation of the opposition at this stage. The 45D secondary boycott provision is another aspect that was removed by the Labor government in the hope that the industrial thuggery of the union movement could be used from time to time. Mr Martin-Tum it up. You don't believe that.

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Title: OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: That is true, as the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) would understand, even in his own electorate. I certainly understand it. I had a particular in the electorate of Robertson when the wool scourers were stood over by the union movement because of a demarcation dispute. This was an indictment of the union movement and industrial relations in Australia in the 1990s. That was an example we had in the last six months. It is no good the member for Cunningham suggesting that was not the case. I conclude by saying this is a very historic occasion for this parliament. We had the American President here yesterday and today we have the return of these amendments from the Senate. They will be passed by this House and they were passed by the Senate. This industrial relations legislation will be enshrined as a tribute to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who put a great amount of effort into developing the general philosophy, assisted by the minister at the table and a number of us who supported both the Prime Minister and the minister in developing that framework. We have a very good legislative package which reflects that philosophical position. I am sure all workers in Australia and all managements will be much better off. The prosperity that will emanate from this Over the next 100 years will ensure that this historic piece of legislation forms an important part of the Howard government-(Time expired)
