Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: PAYMENT OF TAX RECEIPTS
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (11.27 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill will give legislative effect to an agreement entered into by the Commonwealth government with the state of Victoria to return windfall tax associated with the announced settlement of a long running dispute between the Victorian gas utilities, Gascor and Genvic and their gas suppliers, Esso and BHP. The dispute concerned the ability of the producers to pass on to the Victorian utilities the impact of the Commonwealth's petroleum resource rent tax, PRRT. The Commonwealth has long supported a negotiated settlement to the dispute as being in the best interest of both parties. The ment reached between the parties involves, among other issues, the Victorian government making a payment to the producers of just over $1 billion to resolve the dispute. A key element underpinning the agreement between the producers and the Victorian government was the understanding that windfall tax arising from the $1 billion would be paid to Victoria through a payment to Gascor. The settlement would not go ahead without this arrangement being put in place. The Australian Taxation Office has determined that the settlement payment made to the producers is subject to both company tax and PRRT. This will involve a payment to the Commonwealth of an amount of tax of around $625 million. The Commonwealth has determined that approximately $555 million of that amount reflects windfall tax. That is, approximately $70 million, representing tax payable on amounts previously unpaid by the gas utilities, but not relating to PRRT, will be tained by the Commonwealth and applied to the budget deficit. The genesis of this dispute dates back to the extension of the petroleum resource rent tax regime to the Bass Strait, through the enactment of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. The act provided that PRRT was to apply on profits recovered from the Bass Strait permit area on or after 1 July 1990, replacing the existing excise and royalty regime. It was expected that the change in taxation arrangements to one based on taxable profits from a petroleum project rather than on production levels would encourage increased activity in the area. This in fact proved to be the case. It was recognised at the time that the transition to a new taxation regime could cause changes to Victorian gas prices, with possible disruptive consequences for industry and domestic consumers. The then government provided the Victorian government with a special grant of $30 million for each of the first two years of application of the PRRT to minimise these transitional pressures. However, what was not known by the Commonwealth at the time was that clauses in long-term gas supply agreements between agreethe Victorian gas utilities and Esso-BHP would give rise to a dispute about the ability of the producers to pass on the impact of the PRRT to the utilities. This dispute has been the subject of arbitration over a number of years. It should be recognised that it has always been the intention that the PRRT should be a tax on above normal profits-that is, profits over and above project expenditure and a threshold rate of return-associated with offshore projects and should not necessarily flow through to gas prices. Given the unintended nature of the pass-on dispute, and in order to facilitate its settlement, the Commonwealth has indicated that it should not seek to benefit financially from this settlement. Hence this bill is intended to provide a mechanism to return the windfall tax flowing from the settlement. This should be seen as a fair and reasonable outcome for all parties. The short time frame for consideration of rethis issue by the parliament is unavoidable, given the sensitive nature of the complex negotiations. The settlement has been structured so that a simultaneous exchange of cheques between Gascor, Esso-BHP and Commonwealth will be made on the payment day. However, if the payment to Victoria is not able to be made on the contracted day, the Commonwealth has agreed to pay to Victoria an additional amount reflecting interest accruing up to the actual payment date. The agreement also puts in place a mechanism ensure that, should future events mean that the assessed tax payable on the settlement amount is changed, this will be reflected in a corresponding flow of funds between the parties. It is designed to ensure the Commonlong-term wealth would be no better or worse off under these circumstances. The resolution of this dispute in a manner acceptable to all parties is to be welcomed. Passage of this special appropriation bill will facilitate the settlement process. It is also expected that the resolution of this dispute regime? will facilitate the opening up of gas markets in Victoria to the benefit of gas consumers. I present the explanatory memorandum which contains an explanation of the provisions of the bill. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAYMENT OF TAX RECEIPTS
text: Is leave granted to continue the debate? Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: PAYMENT OF TAX RECEIPTS
text: The opposition is prepared to cooperate with the government in ensuring the speedy passage of the Payment of Tax Receipts (Victoria) Bill which is, as has been said in the passed government's second reading speech, necesor not. sary to enable formal settlement to take place next week of the long-running dispute over the impact of the petroleum resource rent tax between the Victorian Bass Strait gas producaround ers, Esso-BHP and the Victorian gas utilities. As Minister for Resources and Energy when the old concept of RRT was first mooted, have to confess to a certain nostalgia about the kinds of issues that we are now dealing with today. When PRRT was applied to gas by the final Labor government in 1990, replacing the final existing excise and royalty regime, it was anticipated that a profit rather tion based tax would be a significant encourthe ager of new exploration and production activity, and such has proved to be the case. It was a very sensible policy initiative, manifestly. It was all very much to the advantage of Victorian consumers, both domestic and industrial, in particular the petrochemical industries which are crucial to the states and, to indeed, the national economy. Trouble, nonetheless, was lurking, we discovered rather swiftly, with the introduction of this regime in the form of a dispute over the meaning of certain clauses in the contracts which had existed between the producers and the utilities. The issue, as has been said, was whether producers could pass on to the utilities the impact of the PRRT: who had to bear the cost of the liability for the difference between the old royalty regime and the new resource rent tax It was always intended, as the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) has just said-and I note that it is the parliamentary secretary and not the Treasurer (Mr Costello) here, but I understand he has he would need to have a pretty good excuse for not being here on a piece of legislation as important as this-that the PRRT be imposed in effect on abnormal and not borne by consumers. So the question has been where-not in the consumption end ,of the process-in the production and distribution chain the obligation to pay the tax actually lay, whether it could be on from the producers to the utilities That issue has now been effectively resolved by agreement of the Victorian government to pay on behalf of the utilities a sum of $1 billion to the producers to cover both past and future PRRT liability. While this only amounts to about a third of the I claim that has been made by the producers, which amounts to closer to $3 billion, the settlement clearly reflects the commercial judgment of both sides as to where the risk of outcome actually lay if the issue went to arbitration and litigation. Certainly the opposition does not seek to second-guess that than a producparticular judgment. The effect of BHP-Esso now receiving a $1 billion settlement from Victoria is to expose this amount to tax liability in RRT and company tax so far as the Commonwealth is concerned. An estimated $555 million of this has been agreed, as has been said, to be a windfall gain by the Commonwealth in the sense that this amount would not have been paid by anyone had it not been for this particular settlement. It certainly would not be payable at this time. The former Labor government, when in office, had anticipated in discussions with Victoria that such a windfall gain might accrue. We had agreed, in order specifically to encourage a settlement of this kind being reached, that any such windfall gain be in fact paid back to Victoria, subject, of course, to detailed assessment as to the amount of it, in order to again facilitate, encourage and enable the settlement. That situation that was anticipated when we were in government has now come about and it is manifestly in everyone's interests that this formal settlement now proceed. If settlement of the matter in dispute had not occurred, it is clear that there would be potentially very long further delays as the matter was fought out between the producers and the utilities. I notice that the Victorian Treasurer has said that the dispute may have been protracted for as many as another 10 years. Manifestly, that was in nobody's interest, in particular because a key impact of that, a key result of it, would have been to delay by that duration the very considerably overdue gas reform process-in particular, in the Victorian context, the removal of Gascor's monopoly of distribution rights. That gas reform process was of course very strongly supported by the Labor government. It is a process which we believe can and will result in lower gas prices and certainly will have a very positive impact upon industry as a result. The gas reform process of course involves much more than simply Victorian participation in now more open supply arrangements. What we are talking about is the establishment of a national gas market as part, in fact, of the national competition policy reform process that was initiated by the former Labor government. In 1994, it will be recalled, the Council of Australian Governments, COAG, agreed to the principle of free and fair trade in gas between the states. This will allow greater competition between producers and lower prices, as I have already said, for domestic and business consumers of gas; it will enable third parties to access pipelines and compete for the right to sell gas to consumers; and it will allow greater use of gas in electricity generation, which will produce both economic and environmental benefits. The press release by the Treasurer indicates properly that the market for gas in Victoria will now be substantially liberalised. However, this is a note of caution that I just want to introduce at this point: it is acknowledged in that release that a number of residual anti-competitive elements will remain in the revised arrangements between Gascor and the producers. We are told that these anticompetitive elements will be provided with a so-called section 51 (l) exception by the Victorian government. We are concerned, I have to say, that very little information has been provided, so far anyway, to justify the use of that section 51 (l) provision. The Treasurer's press release states that the ACCC, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, and the National Competition Council were briefed on the residual anti-competitive effects of the revised arrangements. However, we have no information on how the competition bodies view the arrangements and whether they believe that these residual arrangements are in fact justified. They may be justified in all the circumstances, but they may not be. We simply do not have the information available to make a considered judgment on this issue. I hope that some early opportunity will be taken by the government-perhaps in reply if the parliamentary secretary is in a position to do so-to indicate what precisely the state of play is in that respect. The final point I wish to make is this: the second reading speech makes clear that, in addition to the Commonwealth's windfall gain directly related to the RRT issue, the settlement has also resulted in another windfall gain of some $70 million representing tax payable on amounts previously unpaid by the gas utilities, but not in fact relating to PRRT. That $70 million, we are told, the Commonwealth is going to keep and apply to general deficit reduction. The government will not be surprised to know that we in opposition have a great many suggestions as to how that windfall $70 million which the government is going to keep and not give back to Victoria might in fact be very usefully spent. Today in the Senate. we are intending to request a number of amendments to Appropriation Bill (No. I) and (No.2) which spell out, in loving and elaborate detail in fact, many of the areas in which some of that $70 million might be spent very usefully indeed. I conclude by making the suggestion, in all good faith to the government, that it could do no better than to spend at least $55 million of that windfall $70 million on extending, for at least another year, the Commonwealth dental program, which is, I hope the government will finally come to acknowledge, the most indefensible, the most literally shocking, of rather ugly budget decisions to cut expenditure, particularly in welfare delivery areas, that are contained in this year's budget. If you are sitting on another $70 million as a result of this overdue exercise, this very welcome exercise by the Victorian government, the utilities and the producers, I hope that something useful will be done with the additional windfall gain you have thus received. Having said all that, this is a very good thing that this settlement has been finally achieved. The consequences of it go much beyond the mere settlement of this particular outstanding issue that will now open up the scope for the rapid implementation, we all hope, of the national gas market, a new competitive situation applying in Victoria, New South Wales and elsewhere, much to the benefit of consumers and much to the benefit in particular of energy dependent industry. It is something that will be to the great advantage accordingly not only to the Victorian government but to the whole national economy. On that basis, I indicate the opposition's support for this bill.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: PAYMENT OF TAX RECEIPTS
text: In responding to the comments of the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), it is worth noting that he mentioned the Commonwealth dental program. That program was an initiative that was announced by the previous Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in the 1993 election campaign. It was initially planned to reduce the waiting lists that were existing in the state dental schemes. For 93 years Australia had not had a Commonwealth dental scheme. In fact, for 10 years of the previous Labor government there was no Commonwealth involvement in the dental area. The Payment of Tax Receipts (Victoria) Bill is formalising for the Commonwealth what has been a very elegant solution in solving a dispute which has lasted for five years and which relates back to contracts that were determined in the late 1960s. It involves a simultaneous exchange of cheques between three different entities. Gascor, the utility for gas in Victoria, has resolved its long standing dispute with Esso and BHP. As a result of that, it will be making to BHP and Esso a all the lump sum settlement payment of $1.022 billion, which will be assessable for rent tax and company tax. BHP and Esso, which will be assessed for that tax, will pay $625 million in tax to the Commonwealth. Most of that will be windfall tax we were not expecting, but the $70 million which is not part of the windfall will be used to reduce the budget deficit. The Commonwealth will be paying $555 million to Victoria, passing on the windfall tax it has received from Esso and BHP. The contracts, established for production in Bass Strait, were between Esso and BHP and the Victorian state utilities, the then SEC and the Gas and Fuel Corporation but the now Generation Victoria and Gascor respectively. Those contracts said that Esso and BHP were required to sell to only the Victorian state utilities and that no other suppliers could provide gas to Gascor and Generation Victoria. These were just two restrictions that resulted from the contracts established in the late 1960s. That has led to a large surplus of gas in the Bass Strait area. BHP and Esso estimate they could produce something like three times more gas than they currently are, but there has never been any incentive because all they were doing was producing for Victoria. Those contracts had a life of 35 years, and they were established in 1969. At that time, Victoria and the producers, Esso and BHP, decided that indirect taxes levied on supply and production could be passed on to the buyers: the utilities of Victoria. The monopoly that has existed with Gascor, the entity ously known as the Gas and Fuel Corporation, and Esso and BHP has really given them little incentive to develop the gas fields in Bass Strait, because they could supply gas to only Victoria-and Victoria is a mature market. The prices in those contracts were established prior to the two oil shocks of the 1970s. They were established in 1969 and fixed for 35 years. As the member for Holt mentioned, in 1990 the previous Labor government decided to abolish the complex excise and royalty regimes that had existed in the area of gas production and to substitute them with a petrol resource rent tax, which taxed profits on offshore oil and gas production at about 40 per cent. Since 1990, BHP and Esso have been paying that tax, although the contract did mention the contract initially signed so that they could pass it on to the state government utilities. They have been sending the bills to Victoria, and this is what the dispute has been all about. The settlement is, at just over $1 billion, roughly the size of the bills unpaid for reSource rent tax. When we take into account the difference between the lump sum payment and the amount the Commonwealth will appropriate to Victoria through this bill, the settlement will cost Victoria about $425 million. But it removes what the Auditor General of Victoria has estimated as a $3 billion future exposure for the lifetime of contract, based on their requirements under the initial contracts. Alan Stockdale, the Treasurer of Victoria, has said that the settlement of this dispute will not affect current prices because Gascor and Generation Victoria will be increasing their buyings rather than passing the $425 million on to consumers. Net liabilities of those utilities will increase from $600 million to approximately $1 billion. The reason for the great difference between the contract price, which was 27c per gigajoule, and the market price, which was $4.14 per gigajoule, is that the contract price was established in contracts set up prior to the energy crises of the 1970s. The Victorian government has pocketed the difference. The previ- new contracts to be drawn up between BHP and Esso and the state government of Victoria will run from 2001 to 2009. They will be changed a lot more often; there will not be any 35-year contracts in the future. Also, those contracts will be market based. An article in today's Financial Review headed 'What a Gas! Everyone Wins!' describes this as a 'breakthrough' for thousands of Australian businesses being crippled by high energy costs. This solution has removed the last major obstruction to the creation of just one gas market in south-eastern Australia What it will do is decrease the gas prices paid by consumers and by businesses in New South Wales. It will also be able to create new investment. For example, BHP has proposed building a pipeline from Longford to Sydney. Previously, the situation with the intrastate monopolies has meant that was not viable. It will now be viable. Another proposal that has been floated is one linking the Victorian and New South Wales grids with a pipeline between Albury and Wagga Wagga. The solution will allow the Victorian government to move the gas industry to a more competitive structure. For the Commonwealth government, there are benefits as well. The restrictions that this removes will open up the gas fields and will lead to an increase in resource rent tax over the next 10 years. In fact, it has been estimated that this could bring in an additional $300 this million in income per year from the resource rent tax, just due to the expansion that is possible in the Bass Strait oilfields. As I said before, South Australia, New gas South Wales and Victoria have all been regulated, intrastate monopolies. The Santosled group has been supplying Cooper Basin gas to South Australia and New South Wales, and BHP and Esso have been supplying gas to Victoria. The solution will enable Victoria to meet its commitments, agreed to at the COAG meeting, to establish a competitive national gas market. Those commitments have been dependent upon Victoria achieving a resolution to this dispute. The contracts which were established in the late 1960s will now be reformed and will remove the restrictions on Esso-BHP selling gas to end consumers in Victoria. They will also remove the obligation on Gascor to take gas exclusively from Esso-BHP to supply all of Victoria which is connected with the Longford pipeline. They also remove restrictions on Esso-BHP to build pipelines in Victoria and also to market gas in the other states. While initially this will not see a great change-I imagine that Esso-BHP will still largely be supplying gas to Victoria, and the Cooper Basin group will still supply gas to New South Wales and South Australia-in the long term we will see a more competitive situation which will allow an expansion of gas production in Australia and in the long term this solution should lead to lower gas prices for consumers and businesses. I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: PAYMENT OF TAX RECEIPTS
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (11.55 a.m.)-in reply-I would like to thank the opposition for its cooperation in regard to the Payment of Tax Receipts (Victoria) Bill 1996. It is unusual for legislation to be brought in, the second reading to be debated immediately and for it then to be passed through the House. So we appreciate that cooperation. I think everybody recognises that this is in the best interests of Australian business and, of course, intergovernmental relationships. The opposition spokesperson on Treasury matters, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), mentioned section 51C as being anti-competitive. The government is satisfied that it is pro-competitive and, in broader scheme of things concerning 51 C, he was really referring to a legal technicality. The revised arrangements which this will put in place, we believe, are certainly much better than what was in place under the previous circumstances. Without any further comment, I close the debate. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Third Reading Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith. Bill (on motion by Mr Miles) read a third time. NA (F AMIL Y TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996 Consideration of Senate Message Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: On behalf of the Speaker, it is my duty to make a short statement to the House concerning the Senate's proposals with respect to this bill: Senate amendment No. 2 appears to have the effect of making a reduction in the number of taxpayers who will obtain the benefit of the increase in the tax-free threshold which is central to the family tax assistance initiative. If enacted, it would therefore leave the effect of not decreasing in some instances the taxable income of some taxpayers to the extent provided for in the bill as introduced. Senate amendment No. 1 appears to be consequential to amendment No.2. There is significant doubt as to whether the Senate may proceed in such instances by way of amendment. This is because of the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution which provides that the Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. The overriding consideration, in my view, is the matter of principle and respect for and the regard to the terms of the constitution. I acknowledge that in the circumstances it will be difficult for the House to reach a concIusive understanding of this matter. I note, however, that both houses now have the benefit of committee reports concerning the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution. It will also be difficult for any satisfactory dialogue to take place between the houses on the specific matter of the purported amendments to this bill. Nevertheless, I understand that the propodecency sals to which I have referred were originally drafted as requests for amendments. I would ask that ministers in the Senate, when providwhen ed with advice from those who drafted the legislation that the appropriate course follow is by way of request for amendment, satisfy themselves as to the adherence to constitutional principles before deviating this course. I believe that it is my duty to draw these matters to the attention of members before any further consideration is given to the Senate's proposals. Mr Latham- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order in relation to the information you have just provided the House. Is it within our standing orders to now make a request upon a request, which seems to have been the tenet of your remarks?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: It is up to the important House as to how we proceed with this mosignificant tion. (Quorum formed)

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (12.05 p.m.)-I move: That(1) the House endorses the statement of the Deputy Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by message No. 93 transmitted by the Senate in relation to the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996; (2) the House, having regard to the fact that public interest demands the early legislation, refrains from the determination of its constitutional rights in respect of Senate message No. 93; and (3) the amendments be considered forthwith. We support the position which the Speaker has adopted. We do not believe that this is time for a debate about constitutional matters. We want to move on to a debate about the mentary amendments, so the government supports the Speaker's comments.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: I think what the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) wants to do is sweep the constitutional provisions under the carpet without telling the opposition beforehand, without giving the opposition the and the courtesy of notice of this constitutional question. The first I had heard of it, as shadow minister taking the bill, was the Deputy Speaker read out a short statement. Then one of the clerks handed me to the relevant motion that the parliamentary secretary then stood up and moved I do not think it is sufficient for the parliafrom mentary secretary to stand up and say, 'We support the words and judgment of the Speaker in this matter, but we think there is a public interest consideration which is so pressing that the House now needs to deal with the bill as a matter of urgency, forgetting all about the constitutional questions.' If the parliamentary secretary supports the statement of the Speaker, does he support the sentence that was read out: 'There is significant doubt as to whether the Senate may proceed in such instances by way of amendment'? I would have thought it would be very for the parliament to deal with a doubt that has been raised by the Speaker and not just say in part 2 of the motion, now moved by the parliamentary secretary, that there is some public interest demand for the early enactment of the legislation. It is not the view of the opposition that there is a public interest demand for the early enactment of the legislation; the view of the opposition is there should be proper regard for process. The proper regard for process would be to have a parliamentary debate about the the provisions of paragraph 3 of section 53 of the enactment of the constitution. The member for Banks (Mr Melham), who fortunately is at the table, chaired a parliamentary inquiry and delivered an outstanding report on the provisions of paragraph 3 of section 53. Why was he not notified of the the terms of this debate now before the parliament and the motion moved by the parliasecretary? I believe it is the height of indecency and it is the height of parliamentary malpractice to not give the opposition notification of something as important as this. Time after time on these tax matters it is the parliamentary secretary who is wheeled into read out notes provided to him by public servants. We have never once seen the Commonwealth Treasurer (Mr Costello) deal with a taxation bill. We never see Mr Costello in this House on taxation legislation. This is the same government which said they would make the powers of the parliament supreme over the executive. If the parliament is supreme over the executive, why do we not see the executive minister who has responsibility for taxation instead of the parliamentary secretary? He is not the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer; he is the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister. As such, he has no direct responsibility for taxation matters. The opposition wishes to record that objection. It should be the Treasurer handling this matter, not a parliamentary secretary divorced totally from any responsibility on taxation matters. It should also be recorded that the government should have had the decency and the courtesy to notify the opposition of this major issue concerning paragraph 3 of section 53 of the Australian constitution. Government members, most of all a minister, should not scoff at the idea that the constitution is important. This is the side of parliament that is always lecturing Australians about the importance of upholding the constitution-constitutional tradition. The constitutional tradition on paragraph 3 of section 53 is that it is an important part of our legal framework and something that should not be swept under the carpet in the motion that has now been put by the parliamentary secretary. The opposition, as I understand it, is not in a position to divide on a matter like this because we understand the weight of government numbers. We also understand that the government would have far better cooperation on these matters if it displayed base courtesy in letting the opposition know that an opinion had been provided to the Speaker which cast 'significant doubt as to whether the Senate may proceed in such instances by way of amendment'. I am very disappointed that the government is not displaying any courtesy or seeking any cooperation from the opposition on this particular matter. I am also very disappointed that we did not have the Speaker himself in the chamber. Where is the Speaker? He should be in that chair providing his opinion on paragraph 3 of section 53 rather than handing a note to a Deputy Speaker who is on roster and who is obliged to read out the opinion of the Speaker. Mr Bruce Scott-Are you reflecting on the Speaker?

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: I am reflecting on the Speaker and the discharge of his responsibilities. If he has a statement to make to this House, if it is a statement headed on the written document 'Statement by Speaker' and if it is a statement that relates to an unresolved part of the constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia-paragraph 3 of section 53-the Speaker should discharge his responsibilities by coming into this House and giving us the statement that stands in his name. He should also be available for questioning by members about the legal advice that has been made available to him. It is not sufficient for a government which said it would be boosting the powers in respect of this parliament to treat us in such a shabby way. The Speaker should be in that chair, the Treasurer should be in that chair and we should have the right-indeed, we do have the right-to question the Speaker about the legal opinion that has been made available to him, especially when so recently, just last year, the member for Banks chaired an extensive parliamentary inquiry into the terms and conditions of paragraph 3 of section 53 of the constitution. I note again the 'significant doubt as to whether the Senate may proceed in such instances by way of amendment'. It is suggested here the motion be moved by a minister. It has not been moved by a minister; it has been moved by a parliamentary secretary with no responsibility for the matter now before the House. I doubt very much whether there is public interest demand for the early enactment of the legislation. I was going to mention in the substance of the Senate amendments a whole range of concerns the opposition has about the administrative efficiency, or rather inefficiency, of the way in which the government is now handling the so-called family tax initiative. A whole raft of matters need to be sorted out in the administration of that particular bill-the compliance costs to employers, the availability of information for the family tax initiative coming into force on I January, the confusion as to the arrangements of families where the parents have separated but still have dependent children. If the truth be known, on the family tax initiative the government have created for themselves a legislative and administrative nightmare. They have now realised that. They have got some advice from the public servants, who know it is a nightmare, who know that this is the worse possible way to administer a family tax benefit. They have tried to get it up as fast as they could through the Senate, a questionable amendment moved by the Senate, knowing full well that there would be an important constitutional doubt cast over that process when it came back to this House. It is pretty shabby stuff all round, shabby in the type of people who are here in the House to handle the matter: we do not have the Treasurer-we have a parliamentary secretary; we did not have the Speaker reading out his own statement-we had a Deputy Speaker who was obliged to read it out on his behalf. We do not have access to ask questions to the Speaker. We do not have access to the legal advice upon which the Speaker has made this statement. We do not have an explanation from the government as to why, knowing these things, knowing the doubt about paragraph 3 of section 53 of the constitution, they still persisted with moving Senate amendments. Why doesn't the government follow due process and recommit the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill before the House of Representatives so that the amendments can be moved here first and foremost? This is just one symbol and one sign of the way in which the government has created an administrative nightmare for itself in the handling of this family tax initiative. The proper procedure is not, as the Speaker said, to cast 'significant doubt as to whether the Senate may proceed in such instances by way of amendment'. The proper procedure is to recommit the bill to the House of Representatives. If the government did that, there would be no question whatsoever about the terms and conditions of the third paragraph of section 53. This is a serious matter. The House should note with due gravity that we are now considering an amendment by the Senate that we are going to deal with in return by way of a request-when the Speaker himself has cast doubt on whether it is available to the House to do those things. This really is a terrible moment in terms of process and a terrible moment for a government which promised the people of Australia that it would uphold the powers-indeed, boost the powers-of the House of Representatives ahead of an executive government. Executive government has made the mistake, Parliamentary Secretary Miles. You probably do not have an awareness of these things because the Treasurer is not here. Executive government has made the mistake in the drafting of the bill. It has made the mistake in the way in which it is to be administered. It has had to scramble up to the Senate, knowing full well that these provisions really should not have been placed before the Senate but should have been recommitted to the House of Representatives. Now the government is calling on the opposition to just sit here smiling as they bodgie up the process. They are bodgying up the process with a statement read out casting significant doubt on the process. And they expect the opposition to regard their motionwhich said there is some public demand for the early enactment of the legislation-as accurate. There is no public demand for the early enactment of the legislation. There is public demand for due process. There is public demand for treating the House of Representatives with proper respect. And there is public demand for getting the administrative terms of the family tax initiative correct, not having to do it through some bodgied up process knowing full weIl that it would be doubtful as to how the House of Representatives could deal with any Senate amendment. This is a terrible moment for the House. I again record the opposition's concern that it has been asked to deal with these matters without consultation, without prior notice and without the proper tenets of due process.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, I rise to support the statement you made on behalf of the Speaker in relation to the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996. I had the honour and the privilege in the last parliament of chairing a committee of the House of Representatives, the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. That committee considered the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution. I suppose what is disappointing to us on the opposition benches is that in the last parliament that committee produced a unanimous report. On the committee at that time was the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the father of the House, and the current Attorney-General and Minister for Justice (Mr WiIliams). We produced a unanimous report. This is not an issue of government and opposition, as far as the House of Representatives is concerned. It is an issue of the powers of the House and the powers of the Senate.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: And the constitution. We on both sides of the House wish to respect the constitution, so that committee produced a unanimous report. I suppose that is why we in the opposition are a little disappointed. In relation to the Speaker's statement, we endorse it. In relation to the motion moved by the parliamentary secretary, we endorse it. The first paragraph of the parliamentary secretary's motion said: The House endorses the statement of the Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by message No. 93 transmitted by the Senate in relation to the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 ... Let us be under no illusion. There is crossparty support for that aspect of the motion. What the government needs to understand is that they need to observe the protocols. I think that is what our objection is at this stage. We cannot derogate from our powers as a House, especially when we are attempting, as a result of the reports that were tabled in the last parliament, to reach a compact with the Senate. That is why I am rising to speak. I am rising to say, 'Look, we support that aspect. We support the Speaker's statement.' The Speaker's statement said: There is significant doubt as to whether the Senate may proceed in such instances by way of amendment. This is because of the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution which provides that the Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. The overriding consideration in my view is the matter of principle and respect for and regard to the terms of the constitution. That is why we support the Speaker's statement. But it is disappointing when we on this side did not get, as I understand it, notice in relation to this statement. It just allows the Senate to attempt to divide and rule in this instance, because this is something that is about the powers of the House and the Senate. I endorse further down in the statement the comments which said: Nevertheless, I understand that the proposals to which I have referred were originally drafted as requests for amendments. I would ask that ministers in the Senate, when provided with advice from those who drafted the legislation that the appropriate course to follow is by way of request for amendment, satisfy themselves as to the adherence to constitutional principles before deviating from this course. That is why we on this side endorse the Speaker's statement. That is why the government should understand that they need to, and should, give us notice in terms of the protocols. They need to do that so that we as one can assert the powers of the House, and so that those in the other place can be under no illusions that there is no division on either side of the House. We regard this as the people's House. We do have the benefit of a comprehensive report. I think there is a possibility of reaching a compact so that we can have an understanding as to how we should proceed. I implore the government to give us notice in future. I applaud you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the Speaker for bringing this to the attention of the House. It is important. I don't think that what has happened today should derogate from the fact that we are at one with the government in relation to your statement. That is why I have risen to speak on this matter. It was an honour and a privilege to be the Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the last parliament. The secretariat was excellent-and still is. The then opposition members-now in government-signed off on that report. Mr Deputy Speaker, I applaud you for the statement you made on behalf of the Speaker. I say again to the government: there is no need to have proceeded down this path at this stage-that is, in not giving us notice. (Quorum formed)  indebted to the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), and I thank him for his courtesy. Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, it gives me some sense of satisfaction that you should have been involved in such an important message from the Speaker about the powers of the House in respect of money bills but, like the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham)-without wishing to reflect on you-it would have been nice if the Speaker was in the chamber for such an important message. When we are talking about the respective powers of the Senate and the House, I am a little embarrassed that I have perhaps previously considered some of the Senate's powers as too much and, as a government backbench member, very frustrating. In opposition you learn to understand some of the benefits the Senate has in consideration of legislation-its ability to actually extract the detail behind legislation. I would in no way wish to reflect on the powers of the Senate. However, I do believe the message from the Speaker is a very important one. As both shadow ministers on the opposition side have stated, there is no disagreement on either side of the House on the interpretation of the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution. It is pleasing that that should be the case. The Senate doesn't have the power to affect the tax burden on ordinary people, yet your message alerts us to the fact that the schedule of amendments made by the Senate has this very direct consequence. The parliamentary secretary has been very courteous to me-and I am grateful-in allowing me to make a small contribution. Again, I make the point that, if this House is to function and the prerogatives of the House are to be maintained, it is really important that courtesy be extended to the opposition, particularly to the shadow minister, in foreshadowing that this bill would be coming up and the likelihood of the Speaker making such an important statement. It is unfortunate that on these bills we, as a House, do not have a proper opportunity to address the constitutional issue that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have placed before us in the statement you read out on behalf of the Speaker. I sincerely hope-this being a sitting Thursday in the last week of a parliamentary sitting-that at some future date the government may consider that the issue is of sufficient importance and gravity for there to be an appropriate parliamentary debate about section 53 of the constitution. Members on both sides of the House are very concerned at all times to ensure that the constitution is followed. Indeed, the government has a track record of insisting on this, more so than perhaps us. By way of summary, it is a pity that proper courtesies were not extended to the opposition on this matter and that the Speaker himself was not able to be present in the chamber, given the importance of the Speaker's message that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, read out. Last but not least, I hope there will be a future opportunity where the support of all honourable members about the constitution in this instance can be brought to a head and debated and an appropriate message sent to the Senate. I thank the House.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (12.31 p.m.)-in reply-I would just like to sum up this very brief debate which we have had. I understand the comments from one or two people in the opposition on the way in which this matter has been dealt with by the government. First of all, can I make it very clear that we are following exactly the same procedure as the former government followed with us in regard to this matter. So, in getting again. the forewarning, we are dealing with the Speaker's statement in the same way this matter was dealt with previously. I suggest to the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) that, if he wants further information on the legal basis for this, he might refer to the speeches by his current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the then Assistant Treasurer, the former member for Canning, Mr Gear, so that he might be more acquainted with the way in which the previous government dealt with it. I am just saying that this government is following precedent. There is nothing unusual about it. There is quite a bit of fuss being made by the member for Werriwa about this. I just want to put it on the record that we are following the same sort of procedure. The member for Werriwa also made the comment that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) was not in here and was not having carriage of the matter. Neither is the shadow Treasurer in here taking carriage of it. That is okay. All I am saying is that I have responsibility for carriage of this bill through the House. In regard to the public interest, I would think that the Australian people out there who have been told that they are going to get some tax cuts would have a great deal of interest in family taxation cuts of $1 billion. There is certainly public interest amongst families right throughout this country looking for a $1 billion cut, looking for $1 billion back in their pockets on 1 January. They know this is coming. The government is honouring its promise to the Australian people within a year of coming into government. They are getting family cuts. Mr Martin-This is about the sovereignty of the two Houses-the House of Representatives, the sovereign parliament.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: That is okay. The member for Werriwa was saying in regard to the second point of this motion that there was no public demand. Well, there is. I just want to make the point that a lot of Australian families out there are keen to see the tax cuts. Mr Martin-Never mind the substance. This is about the Senate trying to railroad us

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT
text: -All right, let me come to that in a moment. There is no doubt of the interest out there by families right around this country. Turning to some of the other comments made by one or two members of the opposition, yes, we do agree on the way in which we should handle this with respect to the way in which the Senate is dealing with the constitutional question. It has been pointed out that a report, which is a bipartisan report, has been done. It came down late last year and is being reflected on. text: Werriwa) (12.39 p.m.)The opposition understands the situation to be one where the government has maladministered its own legislation and is now seeking the Senate to bail it out by way of amendment, an amendment that many people in this House believe the Senate does not have the right to move, let alone to seek to impose upon the House of Representatives. The proper way of handling this matter would to have been either for the government to recomincome mit the bill to the House of Representatives or for the Senate to make a request and nothing more than a request; not for the Senate to exercise powers that many in the House believe are beyond its jurisdiction and charter, constitutionally and morally. It is very important for the House to recognise those points. The opposition is very concerned that the government is using incorrect practice, using false powers of the Senate, to try to tidy up the administrative nightmare of its own legislation. We all know that this family tax initiative was not framed by reasoned, diligent and rational policy makers; it was framed by a Liberal Party focus group which was told, 'John Howard will give you a big fistful of dollars in this election campaign. How would you like it paid to you?' That focus group said, 'We do not really regard ourselves as welfare recipients, so we do not want it in terms of a Social Security cheque that might arrive every month, like the basic family payment.' They said, 'Why don't you pay it through the tax system?' So the person organising the focus group, with Andrew Robb taking notes on the other side of the one-way glass, said, 'What if we do it through a change to the tax free threshold instead of a rebate which would be the most efficient way to pay the benefit-a rebate at the end of the financial year?' The taxpayers said, 'We like the idea of getting the benefit on an ongoing basis through PAYE deductions rather than an end of year rebate.' So that is how the Liberal Party devised its family tax initiative. It was poll driven; it was focus group driven; it was research driven. But something happened to this policy on the way to the forum. They handed it over to the bureaucrats in the federal Public Service who said that it may well be research driven but it is not administratively sound. Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: AYES
text: I have been speaking to the statement that the Speaker gave the House on Senate amendment No.2, which is now before the House. It appears to have the effect of making a reduction in the number of taxpayers who will obtain the benefit of the increase in the tax free threshold which is central to the family tax assistance initiatives. I was asking the question: why is the government at this late stage taking away its much touted and much vaunted family tax initiative from a body of Australians? The answer as to why the government has had to use the false powers of the Senate to carry an amendment now before the House is that there are a whole range of administrative inefficiencies concerning the family tax initiative of which this amendment is but one. The amendment, for instance, is related to the fact that employers now have to notify the Tax Office of a change in the PA YE deductions for each employee. Therefore, there is a huge increase in compliance costs in Australia. It also raises the question: how will people know? How will people know of their eligibility for the family tax initiative by 1 January if the government is not telling them? Most people expect these things to be paid as a rebate at the end of the financial year. There is a problem in the spread of information. There will be a group of Australians who just will not know of their eligibility on 1 January. There is another problem. What happens if both parents claim simultaneously for the family tax initiative? This is the problem with a tax system based on individuals, yet the benefit is being paid to families. There will have to be a huge data matching exercise within the Tax Office to try to deal with the problem of double dipping. This particular set of amendments illustrates the problem the government has in the prevention of double dipping. There is a further problem. What happens where the benefit is being paid even though the parents are living apart? Apparently, parents will have to keep a logbook. We will have the extraordinary circumstance of parents keeping a logbook on the amount of time that they have care of and are paying for dependants vis-a-vis the amount of time the dependants spend with the former partner. There is a range of inefficiencies that is adding to compliance costs for employers. Those inefficiencies are causing distress in the community. They will lead to the absurd situation of parents having to keep a logbook on the amount of custody that they have for one of their children if the parents are separated. The member for Chifley is referring back to Senate amendment No. 1. We have dealt with Senate amendment No.1. We are now dealing with Senate amendment No.2.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AYES
text: Order! The honourable member is addressing the matter before the chair.  ... taxable income is taken to be the beneficiary'S share of the net income of a trust estate in respect of which the trustee is liable to be assessed or to pay tax under section 98 of the Tax Assessment Act. I think the problem for the honourable member for MCPherson is that amendments 1 and 2 are related. The point I want to make to the honourable member for MCPherson and to the House is that I suspect that in my electorate of Chifley-and I would have thought that no-one would argue that there are many fine battlers living in the electorate of ChifleyMr Martin-And well represented.  ber for Cunningham. He is an astute judge in these matters. I cannot say that I am aware of any of my constituents' spouses being such beneficiaries. I cannot think of one. In case I am making a false statement, I plead with any of my constituents who are listening this afternoon to ring me if they are a spouse who is a beneficiary of a trust or the estate of a trust. I do not want to misrepresent the situation when I say that not one person in my electorate will benefit from these measures. In fact, they are not designed to benefit from these measures. It is not the poor or the middle class who will benefit from these amendments, it is those who are well practised in tax matters in setting up trusts. Trusts are set up with the single purpose of minimising taxable income. I am not in favour of this amendment because it is not going to benefit any of my constituents. They are certainly not in the wealthy brigade who can spend thousands of dollars rearranging their tax affairs to pay a minimal amount of tax. It is a pity that the government did not follow the advice of the shadow minister, who suggested that we could have avoided these constitutional difficulties if the parliamentary secretary had been prepared to reintroduce the bill and then forward it to the Senate. (Time expired) Amendment agreed to.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: AYES
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (1.29 p.m.)-I move: That amendment No.3 be agreed to. This is also a minor technical amendment. It clarifies the operation of proposed subparagraph 20P(3)(b) to make it clear that the subparagraph is intended to apply to couples who separate after the end of the year of income. Without the amendment, the provision is ambiguous. We acknowledge that, and that is why the amendment is being moved.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: AYES
text: The opposition is pleased to support this amendment to the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill. We note that the first two amendments were taking away eligibility for the family tax initiative, trary to government election promises. This is an amendment which, as was outlined by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), seeks to confer eligibility on parents who have separated. In the context of this provision, however, is worth repeating that the opposition does not regard the Senate as having a legitimate authority or power to move an amendment; it should have come to us by way of a request. But now it is here, and now that it has been put by the parliamentary secretary, it is appropriate to raise the whole raft of administrative difficulties that the government has with the family tax initiative. This is a provision that relates to parents when they separate. It is worth noting that the situation where two or more people jointly maintain a dependant and those people do not reside together was to be dealt with in the proposed section 20L of the bill, which provides that the child will only be considered to be a dependant for the days when the taxpayer has care of the child for the night. I would have thought that, for members who are worried about privacy and the basic rights of citizens to privacy, this is a new infringement that the government is imposing upon the citizens of Australia in an attempt to force them to keep a logbook to determine for taxation purposes whethei or not their dependent child stayed for the night. And not only that, the government is further breaching privacy by forcing parents to keep a logbook for the amount of time that they have dependent children within their care. The administrative efficiency of it is a total nightmare; the administrative arrangements are a total nightmare. Let me raise a hypothetical situation to illustrate what will happen. Say one parent starts out the PAYE period with 70 per cent of the care of the dependent child and the other parent, separated, 30 per cent. Because the government is paying this through PAYE deductions rather than through a rebate, if the 70/30 ratio changes at any time, the employer will have to be notified, and will subsequently have to change the PA YE deduction to reflect, say, a change to 50/50. Imagine the con- administrative nightmare and the inconvenience and the breach of privacy for people. First of all, they have to keep a log as to how many nights the dependent child spent with them. These arrangements are always flexible and fluid. If the arrangements change it and go from 70/30 to 50/50 they have to present a log to their employer to say that the child is now half in their care instead of 70 per cent; they have to ask the employer to alter the PAYE deduction for the purpose of the family tax initiative. The government clearly had not thought any of these things through before it brought the family tax initiative legislation into the House. I note the concern that is echoed on the faces of the member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) and the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) now that the penny has dropped. The penny has dropped that their much vaunted family tax initiative is an administrative nightmare. What you are setting up in the name of family values is a tax logbook on separated parents: when they have the care of a dependant in their house for the night-not for the day, necessarily, just for the night-they need to put it on the night log. If those arrangements change from PAYE period to PAYE period, they have to tell their employer of that and he will notify the Taxation Office through a change to the PAYE deduction. That is an extraordinarily draconian provision for a government to impose. It is a nightmare for people in terms of their right to privacy. Why should employers know the arrangements that their employees have with regard to dependent children? Why should they have the right to know how many nights their separated employees have dependent children in their houses? Why do they have that right to know? Why, even, does the Taxation Office have that right to know? The answer is: because the government engaged in the folly of not paying this as a rebate or a cash transfer. They decided to pay it by virtue of their electoral research and by virtue of their focus group findings. They decided to pay it as a PA YE deduction. That has led to a whole series of administrative inefficiencies and privacy concerns that this parliament should note. The member for MCPherson looks as though he is about to jump to his feet. He is one of the executive members of the Lyons Forum. He is one of the creators of this family tax initiative. Let him explain to separated parents in Australia why they need to keep a taxation logbook every night they have a dependent child in their house. Let him explain why employers should have access to that information. Let him explain why the tax office should. This is worse than the Australia Card. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: AYES
text: I might leave it to the parliamentary secretary to answer the question of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) in detail, but I was provoked and I just want to make a couple of brief comments. The family tax initiative is $1 billion for Australian The member for Werriwa once again demonstrates to this House his disingenuousness by 15 minutes ago calling divisions on a principle that there was something wrong with the way these amendments had been introduced. That is when he did not agree with the amendments, because they in fact did what he could hardly argue against, and that is ensure that these benefits were properly targeted. What he is trying to argue now is that somehow targeting is an issue. It has always been an issue for both houses of this parliament that we are concerned about benefits being properly targeted, and yet the argument that he now puts forward in some sense is that it should not be so. So the argument here is about the proper targeting of these benefits and that is whyMr Latham-What about the logbook?

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: AYES
text: What about a logbook? The issue here, of course, is targeting and making sure that those that are entitled to and eligible for the benefits get them and making sure that if they are not entitled to them they do not. There are always going to be difficulties with ensuring that those benefits get through to those that are entitled to them. Let me answer quickly the question about rebates. This is a tax rebate and the member for Werriwa was correct in suggesting it could be delivered at the end of the year, but the obvious point of that is that that would not give the maximum advantage. The point of doing it through the PA YE system is to make sure the families benefited from it immediately, so on the first payday after 1 January all of the families in Australia that are eligible for this $1 billion tax cut will get it in their tax packets. Is the member for Werriwa opposed to those families getting that benefit in their first pay packet after 1 January? Mr Latham-If they apply, they do.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: AYES
text: If they are eligible then they will get it, and it is a matter of semantics arguing about whether they apply or not. The fact is that if they are eligible they will know they are eligible and they will get it. You are being disingenuous in the way that you are treating these amendments and by doing so you are demonstrating, in my view, a lack of families. commitment to Australian families. Amendment agreed to.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: AYES
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) (to the Prime Minister)(1.37 p.m.)-I move: That amendment No.4 be agreed to. This amendment enables but does not compel taxpayers to quote their spouses' tax file numbers in their tax returns. The quotation will be on a voluntary basis but the information gained will be useful to help prevent double dipping. Arrangements will be worked out to ensure that the consent of a spouse is sought before his or her tax file number is quoted. Without the amendment, it would be an offence for a taxpayer to ask his or her spouse for a spouse's tax file number and for the taxpayer to quote the tax file number to the commissioner. I make the comment that, in terms of privacy, there is no privacy being infringed in regard to this; it is voluntary. I would just like to make that point.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: AYES
text: It is interesting to hear that it is voluntary. What do we do about a dispute? What do we do in a situation where both of the separated parents are claiming substantive care of the dependent child? They are both claiming, say, 80 or 90 per cent of the dependent care of the child. How does the tax office deal with that situation if we are not to have some form of record like a logbook? I would have thought what the parliamentary secretary has done to the taxation system is to encourage everyone to claim as much as they feel inclined to claim. If they want to claim 80 and 80, 160, why not? The government will pay 160 per cent benefit. Is that the case? If the government is to police this properly, certainly it needs to have some form of administrative system in place. I would be very surprised indeed if the parliamentary secretary's assurance holds that there will be no breach of privacy as that administrative system is put in place. As he mentioned, this final amendment on the bill deals with the question of double dipping. So the nightmare of the family tax initiative and its administration gets worse. Not only are there the compliance costs for employers of constantly changing their PA YE deductions, not only is there the breach of privacy for separated parents as their employer and the tax office know the arrangements that they have struck in their private life-the nightmare on Lyons Street gets even worse. The nightmare on Lyons Street gets even worse because the Lyons Forum has now run into the problem of how to prevent double dipping. It probably is very difficult in these circumstances to prevent a situation where both parents will claim for the family tax initiative. This is a problem of a taxation system in Australia based on individual income yet the benefit being paid to family units. If both parents claim, what is the government going to do about it? What is the government going to do about double dipping other than this amendment here, the sole purpose of which is to beg people to volunteer the tax file number of their spouse as they lodge their application for the family tax ini tiati ve? The government is begging people to do the right thing but people are not obliged to lodge the tax file number of their spouse as they themselves apply for the family tax initiative. This creates a very interesting situation as to what the Taxation Office will do to try to prevent double dipping. I would have thought it would generate a huge data matching exercise for the Taxation Office. The ATO will now have to match the data from spouse to spouse right across Australia. I know that the Lyons Forum is all about keeping people together in holy wedlock but they are going to be doing it through the tax office by matching people up against each other with their tax file number. Mr Miles-They're splitting them up, are they?

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: AYES
text: No, the Labor Party is not splitting them; we believe in choice. Remember that strange notion, that strange notion of small '1' liberalism upon which your party was founded? We believe in choice and liberty. We do not think people should be forced into living together if they choose other arrangements. They might be single or divorced, they are elements in our society. Choice! We are not social engineers. We are not part of the big 'C' conservative movement for authority in Australia. We are not part of an authoritarian strongarm movement that tells people that because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) grew up in a white picket fence family everyone else should, or because you grew up in a white picket fence family that everyone else should. We believe in choice and freedom in a free and open society. That is the Australian Labor Party's position. What the Lyons Forum has created is social engineering. Members of the forum are trying to tell women that they belong in the home even though many women in Australia so joyfully choose both a career and a familyMrs Gash-That's why we've got so many women in parliament.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: AYES
text: We all know the sort of women the Liberal Party prefers. We are seeing that at the Opera House today. I would not talk too much about the rights of women and feminist issues in Australian politics. The issue on the final amendment is one of double dipping. The government has created a nightmare for the Taxation Office. There are additional compliance costs on employers. So much for the recommendations of your small business report which was going to lower compliance costs on small business. Each small business in Australia will now have to alter PA YE tax deductions on a weekly or monthly basis because there has been a change in the household care of dependent children that then flows on to the family tax initiative. We not only have a breach of privacy, we have the problem of how the Taxation Office stops double dipping. There is no compulsion on people to provide the tax file number of their spouse. That is only voluntary, and if people do not volunteer there will have to be a huge data matching exercise thereby adding to the costs of running Australia's taxation system. The Labor Party would much rather see those expenses devoted to the real task of tax policing in Australia, cracking down on fraud and cracking down on abuse at the big end of town. The Labor Party would much rather see those scarce ATO resources dedicated to catching the tax cheats and the tax frauds. (Extension of time granted). We know why the Liberal Party will not devote the resources where they are needed within the Taxation Office. They are trying to police the situation with their own flawed family tax initiative to stop double dipping when the sensible thing to do would be to ali ocate those resources to the real purpose tax policing in Australia, to catch the big corporate crooks, the tax fraud at the big end of town. Instead, resources will be spent looking through the bedroom windows of Australians through the introduction of this logbook to see what arrangements they are making with their dependent children. The member for Braddon (Mr Miles) earned a reputation in this parliament for wanting the Tasmanian police to look through the bedroom windows of consenting adults on the question of the sex laws and, true to form, he now wants the Taxation Office to be looking through the bedroom windows of Australians to work out whether or not their dependent child is there, whether or not the logbook is correct and whether or not double dipping is taking place. I would suggest that the government really should have accepted the Labor Party's proposal at the beginning of this debate to have a conference between the House and the Senate to look at the gross administrative inefficiencies of the family tax initiative and see how its administration is unravelling day after day after day. Do something positive about lowering compliance costs for small business. Do something positive about protecting the privacy of Australian citizens. Do something positive about an effective means to stop the potential for double dipping on the family tax initiative. The government has rejected those things and it is to its lasting shame that it could not find a better way. It is the old message in public life: good policy stands on its own; good policy leads to sound administration. The government engaged in base electoral research to work out the way in which Australian families would want the family tax initiative paid. As Mr Howard offered his fistful of dollars, the researchers said, 'Pay it through the tax system with PAYE deductions.' In terms of administration, that focus group was wrong, the Lyons Forum was wrong, and the government was wrong. I look forward to reinforcing those points in this House in the lead-up to 1 January and for a long time thereafter. Amendment agreed to. of FAMIL Y (TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996 Consideration of Senate Message Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment. Mrs Gash-Like you used to do?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING
text: There is the question of the after priority that brings this bill to the House. We have to have a backbencher intervene to defend the non-existent, absent front-bench. Half of them will be absent in question time. There will be no Prime Minister, no Deputy Prime Minister, no Minister for Foreign Affairs and no Minister for Primary Industries and Energy at question time today, and yet they say they are more accountable! The priority that brings this bill to the House is disturbing, as is the impact of the measure itself. Let me just go back to the events that occurred on Tuesday night to demonstrate yet again the way in which this government treats the procedures of this House with contempt. We had an agreement on Tuesday night in debating some very important tax measures: one that sees cuts to research and development expenditures in this country which will, in turn, see research and development go overseas; the other which increases taxes on 1996 cooperatives, including a cooperative in the parliamentary secretary's own electorate of Braddon. Yet he sat by and allowed that tax to be implemented. We had an agreement: the opposition said that we would treat the bill as a whole and, therefore, not insist upon going through it clause by clause. We had an agreement that we would be able to move our four amendments, and that agreement was breached. It was breached because the government came into the place with the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) absent--celebrating his passage of resolution through the Senate of the IR bill. He was not even in the House to manage the agreement that he had entered into. The government would not let us move an amendment on cooperatives to support them, and we know that members of the National Party were prepared to cross the floor on it. The government would not allow us to move amendments that retained the 150 per cent tax concession and retained syndication.
