Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, my question is also addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. I ask: is the minister aware of comments that private health insurance premium changes announced by two funds yesterday are 'massive', and that the changes to health fund products are hiding premium increases? How reliable, Minister, are these assertions? Is it not the case that the overwhelming factor in the need for necessary private health insurance premium changes is the lingering effect of 13 years of Labor government administration?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. He obviously has hit the point right on the head because the fact is that what we are experiencing now is the result of what the funds experienced over the 1995-96 financial year. Funds right across Australia had a pretty tough time then, and they are having a tough time now because the make-up of their membership base is changing. People who are over 65 are making up a greater proportion of people who have private health insurance. I say 65 because that is the age at which people generally draw more than a dollar having put a dollar in. This is in fact something that has happened progressively over a number of years. The trouble that the Labor Party has is that they basically do not like private health insurance. This was put very well in August by the former health minister, Graham Richardson, who said this: I steered a package through the cabinet but resigned before I could sell it to the caucus. Practically the whole package died when I left the Labor Party because the Labor Party has always been a bit biased against private health insurance. In fact, you only have to look at their record. We hear the Labor Party bleating about premium increases, but between 1986 and 1988 they went up 40 per cent.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: What did you do about it? Nothing. You sat on your hands and you rubber-stamped every premium increase. And then, between 1991 and 1992, in the financial year, they went up by 17 per cent. So what you did was you hit the old, you hit the frail, you hit the 700,000 people who had incomes under $20,000 a year who still were clinging on to their private health insurance. And you did it because you are a bit biased against private health insurance. It was purely ideologically driven. And how did you do it? You did it very simply. You abolished the federal government's contribution to the reinsurance bill between 1983 and 1989, and you whacked $100 million onto the cost of premiums of private health insurance. You reduced the Commonwealth bed-day subsidy in September 1986 and you whacked another $135 million onto the cost of private health insurance. You then reduced the Medicare rebate for in-hospital services from 85 per cent to 75 per cent and you whacked that onto private health insurance premiums. According to Access Economics, that added, in today's dollars, $846 million onto the cost of private health insurance premiums. That means premiums today are 39 per cent higher than they would have been had you not taken those decisions. Now we see the crocodile tears, we hear the bleating, we hear the gnashing of the teeth, the tearing at the heartstrings, but basically you have always been a bit biased against private health insurance. With respect to these recent increases, yesterday Medibank Private and MBF announced that there would be premium increases. I approved the increase for MBF on Tuesday. I approved the increase for Medibank Private on Wednesday. When I say 'approved', I said that I had no grounds to disallow them. The fact is that, even if you look at those two premium increases, if you average all premiums over recent times, the average increase is a little bit more than six per cent. That is no different from the average increase between March and August. That compares to 12 per cent per year average that you let go through. If you have a look at between 1983 and 1996, you will see that the Labor ministers for health never once intervened. You gave it the tick, you gave it the rubber stamp and you let a 40 per cent increase in two years between 1986 and 1988 go through. I would prefer that there were no increases at all. At least with these two premium increases, I have been able to intervene. I have asked Medibank Private and MBF to go back and re-work their figures. I have asked them to look at their assumptions again, and they did. Not only have the premium increases that have come in been less than what they would have been otherwise-something you never did because you are a bit biased against private health insurance-but also they have been deferred, and that is good news for private health insurance. It is good news for the contributors. At least I am having a go. You never had the guts to. Health Fund Premium Increases

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. Some very interesting remarks from Mr Justice Kirby are reported in the Australian Financial Review. On the basis of that report, I believe he is correct in his observations that under the government's reforms the commission has a crucial role to play in protecting vulnerable workers. Whilst the commission's role will be different, its status and involvement will certainly be integral to the effective functioning of the new system. I am very pleased to be able to join with the Treasurer today as he announces the passage of the legislation which gives people a big tax cut from I January. I am also pleased to say that this morning the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill went through the lower house, completed its passage in the parliament, to give Australia a new industrial relations system from I January. Mr CosteU-h, a great New Year's Day. Mr Reith-It will be a great New Year's Day, as the Treasurer says. It means that we have modernised the role of the commission and in some respects its role will be enhanced. For example, in relation to the unfair dismissal law, applications will go to the commission. Its dispute settlement role will be emphasised. Its role in the maintenance of the award safety 1).et is to be reinforced. It has an important job there. In respect of certified agreements, it will also administer the no disadvantage test. It will assess proposed Australian workplace agreements referred from the Employment Advocate where approval against the no disadvantage test is considered to be doubtful. It will also have a continuing role to make the orders to ensure equal remuneration. It will prepare a report on junior wage rates, which will be very important in the debate about junior wage rates. It will handle revised arrangements for assessing proposals for federal award coverage, the registration of new unions and altered coverage of existing unions. It will also supervise the award simplification process, which is very important. What that really means is that, in a practical legislative sense, our policy now is there for all to see.

You want to tie up business with red tape in a way they have never been tied before and from which we are unshackling them in this legislation. text: I indicate on behalf of the Commonwealth that the settlement of the long running dispute over liability for petroleum resource rent tax on Bass Strait gas production between Victoria, the gas utilities and their suppliers is a great milestone in relation to a long running dispute which has held up much needed reform in the gas industry in Australia. The resolution of the dispute has major economic benefits. The Financial Review today said 'What a gas! Everyone wins!' I indicate that this outcome was negotiated between me and the Victorian Treasurer in relation to the tax aspects over the last two weeks in relation to intensive negotiations. I would like to thank him, as he has thanked me, for the way in which our teams of offithat cials worked together to resolve this dispute under very difficult circumstances. The essence of the dispute was over the imposition of the resource rent tax. The outcome of the dispute is that approximately $1 billion will be paid to the producers, producing about $620 million in windfall tax to the Commonwealth, $550 million of which will be passed back to the state of Victoria. That is not the only part of the settlement. That pass back required an appropriation which the opposition cooperated in passing through the parliament this morning. I thank them for their contribution and I thank them for the cooperation that they showed in relation to that. However, the good thing about this is that it now opens the way for more competition in the gas industry, for new pipelines to be built, for other regulatory barriers to be removed, to join a single market between New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Queensland, and to have the ending of monopoly arrangements where one supplier and one producer had monopoly in a particular area. Hotter competition and more choice will make sure that there are opportunities for consumers, both domestic and industrial, to get cheaper gas. This will help our international competitiveness. This will mean that it will give bendits to Australian business and Australian producers and it will give opportunities to the businesses that rely on gas for their energy supplies to reduce costs. This is a win-win-win situation-win for Victoria, win for Esso-BHP, win for the Commonwealth but, most of all, a win for business and a win for consumers. Health Fund Premium Increases

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Parkes for his question. There have been a number of media reports which have suggested the army will be conducting widespread construction tasks in some remote Aboriginal communities. I just wanted to clear this matter up because these reports are not entirely accurate and require clarification. The ATSIC army community assistance project developed from a meeting between the Prime Minister and the members of the A TSIC council on 23 October this year. It was announced by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on 15 November. This project is designed to enhance ATSIC capabilities to improve water and related health infrastructure, and honourable members opposite should be interested in that. Discussions are under way with ATSIC to identify tasks where the assistance can be utilised. I want to emphasise that it is the army's role to involve itself in design management and participate in projects on the ground in a small number of the most needy communities. In other words, its role is to involve itself in the management design of a pilot project to get the show on the road. So the aim is to establish models for future projects that would involve civilian contractors and local communities down the track. The army will cover its own salary costs and the project costs will be met by ATSIC and by Health. The benefits to army will obviously lie in the training experience that will be gained, and the priority needs to be identified by A TSIC, and the benefits to the community speak for themselves. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Leichhardt for his question. He is a member who has been very concerned about disadvantaged young people in his electorate and has spoken to me on many occasions about them. It is, therefore, entirely understandable that he is interested in the new initiatives of the government to increase opportunities for young people to train for real jobs. Unfortunately, as a result of the training policies that were put in place by the previous government, employers have been faced over the last 13 years with very substantial bureaucratic hurdles when they have wanted to employ an apprentice or a trainee. The fact that their policies have been dictated largely by the ACTU has meant that many small and medium sized businesses have been very hesitant to take on trainees because they do not want to invite a trade union into a previously non-unionised workplace. The government is committed to greatly simplifying the training system and opening opportunities for young people. One of the important initiatives in this regard is going to be the introduction of one-stop apprenticeship shops, which will streamline the process for employers of hiring an apprentice or a trainee and ensure that employers have ready access to our new flexible and simplified national training arrangements. These one-stop apprenticeship shops will have under one roof a number of services currently offered by a range of agencies both Commonwealth and state. They will provide a streamlined service in relation to both state and Commonwealth training regulations. They will also help businesses to process new flexible training arrangements and establish accredited on-the-job training and quality offthe-job training. I have no doubt that one of the reasons why the member for Leichhardt has asked me this question is that Australia's first one-stop apprenticeship shop will be established shortly in his electorate in Cairns. It is an unprecedented agreement between the federal government and the Queensland government to establish three of these one-stop shops over the next few months. The Cairns pilot will be a partnership between the CES and the Queensland department of training. It will be sponsored by the Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry and it will have a board of management comprising industry and government representatives. The federal government is also negotiating with other state and territory governments to establish further one-stop apprenticeship shops throughout Australia. The significance of this is that the government has once again delivered on the promise it made during the election campaign to provide training for young people which leads on to real jobs and to ensure that the training arrangements in this country are not those dictated by the ACTU but are those which meet the needs of business, large and small, for training which leads on to greater productivity, greater profitability and more jobs. Economy

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen today's company profits figures from the ABS which show that, following a very sharp decline in the June quarter, trend profits were down again by 1.3 per cent in September and were down by 2.3 per cent compared with the same time last year? Has the Treasurer also seen the Westpac leading index of economic activity and the coincident index, both of which were released yesterday, both of which are significantly down for September and which together point to a very pessimistic outlook for activity at least until the middle of next year? Given this kind of evidence now emerging day after day after day, will the Treasurer now concede that it is not the opposition talking the economy down but government policy driving it down?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I think the answers to the question are yes, yes, no. But in relation to the speech that was given by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I would like to say a few things. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was obviously floundering and is, obviously, as I have said, not in command of any economic policy on behalf of the opposition. He gets up here and regularly gives us a little economic commentary on figures. Like his economic commentary which said that our policy could never bring down credit card rates, four days before it did. Like his commentary when he came in here saying that the monthly unemployment figures would wipe the smile off the face of the government, when jobs increased by 25,000. Like the statement when he came in here and said that consumer confidence was flat, when it leapt eight points off the back of a half a point cut in official interest rates. Whatever he says is going down is going up. Whatever he says is going up is going down. His head is spinning until he comes to a dead end. In relation to the company profits, the fact is that company profits rose by 0.3 per cent in the September quarter. They rose. It is true that there was a big decline in the June quarter, but that was before any measures on any basis that the government had put in place could have taken any effect. In relation to the measures we have put in place, of course cuts in official interest rates will in next year.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: When would you like the cuts in official interest rates to kick in? Before they were made? Was that your idea? Was it your idea that they should cut in before they were made? If they were made in July and November, they should have cut in by June? The fact is that you cut official interest rates, and they kick in subsequent to the cut. These cuts will kick in in 1997. I think I said in the House the other day that one of the problems in the small business sector has been in relation to the house building industry. The opposition had a supply problem grow over the last couple of years, where supply was outstripping demand by a very large percentage. We expect the supply and demand to be coming back more into equivalence, and we expect a pick up in 1997. We are putting in place changes in relation to interest rates. We have put in place changes in relation to capital gains tax. We are putting in place changes in relation to the provisional tax uplift factor. We are putting in place changes in relation to family tax incentives. All we hear from the opposition, as the Minister for Industrial Relations said, is a position from right back when they were in the unreconstructed days of Brere-onism in relation to industrial relations, from the unreconstructed days of Creanism, and from the doubly unreconstructed days of Fergusonism. That was back in the dinosaur age. When we had our friends in the gallery before, I thought we could have sent the opposition around to talk to them about perestroika. That might have made some difference in relation to your attitude on industrial relations. It is important that we put in place the measures that are going to tum things around. Of course the biggest thing in relation to the budget was to tum around the legacy of deficit and debt. There is only one way to grow this economy on a sustained basis-that is, by addressing the two failures of Labor that gave us speed limits in relation to the kick current account deficit and in relation to inflation. They are the measures that you in opposition are opposing. I do not know whether it has dawned on you yet, but you are opposing the measures that can put the Australian economy onto a path of sustainable growth. You, the Labor Party, are opposing them. The shadow Treasurer said, 'Well, our policy would actually be to balance the budget over three years,' which is what the budget did. And he said it the day after the budget. All I can say in relation to the economic position of the opposition is that, where there is no understanding, there is no conscience. Because opposition members do not understand what their position is, they get up and make these little statements which are taking them nowhere. Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: If one looks at the age structure of the surgical work force, it would appear that things are actually going to get worse before they get better, given that many of the surgeons in rural areas are old and approaching retirement certainly in the next lO years. This is a particular worry because surgeons are just as important in major regional centres as general practitioners are in more remote centres. One of the difficulties has been that surgical training has been largely confined to large city hospitals and there has been no separate rural training program for surgeons. I am very pleased to say that, somewhat due to the work of the member for Murray, I have had a number of meetings now with the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. The college is proposing a new, separate rural training program for surgeons. This is very exciting because it offers the prospect that, for the first time, a young doctor on graduation could go to a country area and do all their training in the country rather than having to go to big city hospitals if they want to specialise. It would mean that, in Victoria, someone could go to Geelong, Shepparton, Moe or Warrnambool, they could sit the first part surgical exam there and then be eligible to be chosen for the surgical training program. The college of surgeons is proposing a new training program that specifically trains people in the needs of rural surgery. Rural surgery is different from city surgery in two respects: one is that rural surgeons need to be trained in obstetrics and the second is that rural surgeons get much more accident and emergency work than a normal general surareas, geon would. The proposal is to increase surgical training from four years to five years and to have two terms rotating through accident and emergency and through obstetrics. This is very exciting. It offers the prospect of surgical training over and above existing numbers. It offers the prospect of a specific rural surgical training scheme with the mentoring, with the resources and with the special skills that rural surgeons can provide. I commend the honourable member for Murray for her work in working this up and for the support she has given. I commend the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. The government is going to do absolutely everything it can to see that this comes to fruition. Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation  addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Is it the case that, as reported in the Australian Financial Review today, Australia's major initiative for APEC-a proposal for free trade in primary energy products by 2000, which was also the centrepiece of the Prime Minister's first major speech on APEC in August-is dead in the water? Given that Australia's other major APEC proposal for a regional business travel card is also reported to be limping, is it not the case that next week's APEC meeting is looming as another major foreign policy embarrassment for the coalition government?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The government places enormous importance on next week's APEC meeting. The Prime Minister will be attending that conference in order to press the momentum for trade liberalisation within APEC and globally-the matter he discussed with President Clinton yesterday. The Prime Minister proposed at a meeting in Sydney on 1 August that APEC examine the idea of free trade in primary energy before APEC's 201 0 and 2020 target dates, and perhaps by the year 2000. This was because the reliable and efficient provision of energy was fundamental to economic growth in the region. It was estimated that removing tariff measures by 2000 in primary energy would increase APEC's real GDP by around $4.5 billion annually. As a major energy exporter, Australia would stand to share in these benefits. The government believes that that proposal will take close consideration, and that consideration may take some time. The Minister for Trade and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy are actively pursuing the proposal. As one might imagine, pursuing the proposal will be a matter of extensive discussions and consultations which will continue leading up to this week's meeting. In relation to the business visa, discussions on that are still continuing through the APEC forum. The government has had some positive responses to this initiative. The government expects to have more in the coming days. Lobbyists Forum Mr HOCKEY-My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Mr Laurie Ferguson-It is better than public meetings, isn't it?

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Yes, it is. Why has the government abolished the register of lobbyists?

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The history of the register of lobbyists goes back quite some time. It was established by the Hawke government following the Combe-Ivanov affair. It applied only to a narrow class of lobbyists defined as 'a person or company who, for financial or other advantage, represented a client in dealings with government ministers or officials', but, frankly, it was a toothless tiger and its provisions were really unenforceable. There is some evidence that the requirements of the scheme were just not being adhered to. In 1993, 1994 and 1995, only eight inquiries were made with the register of lobbyists. There has also been quite a bit of criticism that the register was not available for public scrutiny and that the scheme was an unnecessary hindrance to the business sector. I believe that the need for the register has been overtaken by general changes to the government processes, particularly in light of the active roles taken by the ministers of this government to ensure that their relevant community and business interests are consulted in the decision making process. There will be a revision to the guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. It is to be amended next year. There will be additional guidelines for ministers to observe when dealing with lobbyists. Mr Costello- Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: TIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: On Tuesday, the member for Oxley asked me a question in my role as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security in this House about the provision of special benefits for newly arrived migrants. I am now able to provide some additional information that might help on that subject. Newly arrived migrants who have been in Australia for fewer than 26 weeks and are therefore unable to receive unemployment payments may be eligible for a special benefit if they meet the strict hardship and income tests for that payment. Since 1 April 1996, the hardship test has included the requirement that new migrants must have suffered a significant change in circumstances for reasons beyond their control since arriving in Australia. As at September 1996, 227 migrants were receiving special benefit, because the existing 26-week newly arrived residents waiting period precluded them from job search, newstart, youth training allowances. It is not possible to provide a figure on value of the special benefit paid to new migrants. Special benefit is paid at a discretionary rate which cannot exceed the maximum rate of news tart allowance, which is currently paid at $320.20 per fortnight for a single person over 21 years. Special benefit is reduced by $1 for each dollar of income earned. The rate is also reduced for any in kind support; for example, if the person receives free board and/or lodging. NA NA

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: IRELAND
text: Mr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the House. On Sunday of last week Senator Liam Naughten, the President of the Irish Senate, tragically died in a car accident in Ireland. Senator Naughten was aged 52 and was elected firstly to the House of Representatives in Ireland in 1981. He subsequently lost his seat in the lower house and was re-elected to the Senate where he progressed through to be the equivalent of the President of the Senate a short time later. The cultural and friendship ties which the Australian people have with the Irish community warrant this matter being raised in the House of Representatives today to pay respect in the tragic circumstances of the senator's death, to recognise that at this time his family-his wife and his daughters-are certainly going through that period of grief and, as I have indicated, to recognise very fully the close association there is between this parliament and the Australian people and the Irish Dail and the Irish people. He was known throughout this period in parliament as being a very fair man. He came from the west coast of Ireland. He had a great interest as a farmer in all matters relating to the land. My own family, who still have very small-I assure all honourable members on the other side-holdings on the west coast of Ireland, benefited from the representation that the deceased senator made on behalf of the farmers of Ireland. I raise this matter today in respect for the Irish parliament and the family or sickness of the deceased senator.

Speaker: Mr TED GRACE
Title: IRELAND
text: I the would like to be associated with the remarks of the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) and I echo his words. I first met Senator Naughten on a visit to the old country some years ago. I found him to be a very sensitive man. In spite of the fact that he probably never really made the big time in Irish politics, he nevertheless was a great spokesman for his representatives, the small farming community, and was a spokesman on health matters. He was also prominent when he led a delegation of the Irish parliament to Australia recently. His death, as the minister indicates, was a great sadness to us all. I want to be associated with the words of the Minister for Finance.

I am sure I speak for my colleagues when I echo the sentiments of both gentlemen who have spoken before me.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT
text: I move: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Monday, 2 December 1996, at 12.30 p.m., unless Mr Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting. We previously advised members that we were considering sitting on simply the Wednesday, Thursday and Friday to match the final sittings of the Senate in that week. But on a review of progress on various matters, and given the long list of speakers that the opposition insist on having on the balance of matters, some of which we may have to gag if youMr Crean-You already have.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT
text: If you are not prepared to take a reasonable view as to the listing arrangements, we will need to sit also on the Monday and the Tuesday. It will be governPAPERS ment business on both days, of course, so that we can deal with the issues outstanding. We would hope though in the management of that week, subject to the Senate's handling of legislation to come back to the House, that we might be able to provide some private members business in the latter part of that week. We will, as we have consistently attempted to do, discuss these matters with the opposition for the proper management of the business of the House. I hope that we will get more cooperation than we have had. In respect of the balance of today, our intention is that the House put the adjournment at the normal time at 5.30 followed by the adjournment debate through till 6 o'clock. I appreciate that there has been some concern about whether or not that could in any way be extended, but my understanding is that the opposition parties are not attempting to keep us here this afternoon after 5.30. Obviously it would be advisable for backbenchers on the other side to talk some sense into their colleagues in the Senate.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT
text: As a question to the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), by way of a contribution to the discussion on the motion, is it his intention in excluding all of private members business from Monday and Tuesday to exclude the consideration of grievances?When I was Leader of the House, it was from time to time necessary to remove private members business to consider government matters. But we always left in what has been the time-honoured point in the week when backbench members on both sides of the House represent to the parliament in traditional form the grievances of the people in their electorates. That being the case, I would urge the Leader of the House to take the view that is at least one part of private members business that he wiJI keep sacrosanct and ensure that it appears on Monday as it now normally does.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT
text: in reply-With respect, I do not think it has always been time-honoured but, obviously, the attempt has in the past been to provide that additional time for people. It is important that grievance and private members time be available. Subject to the programming and what is happening in the Senate, our intention is to provide for a grievance debate later in the week as well as some 90-second statements. We might also be able to have an extended adjournment. We would be happy for that to be the case provided that the time is available. Obviously the purpose of the sitting is to get through the government business and to complete it. It is an additional sitting period as a result of the timetabling and developments with the legislation backwards and forwards between the two chambers. But I agree with you that as a matter of general principle we should aim to do that and that is our intention for that week, but it will be in the week. Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: Mr CREAN

text: by leave-I have another point of clarification, and I would like to make some brief comments in relation to this afternoon. There seems to be some confusion over here. Speaker: Mr CREAN

text: In relation to whether we sit late tonight, again I would invite the minister to respond. As I understand it, the opposition is cooperating in trying to get the amendments across here. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The pain inflicted on the health of millions of Australians resulting from private health fund premiums rising by up to 15 per cent, massive cuts to public hospital funding as a result of the Howard government's first budget and further disruptions caused by the government's retrospective actions on Medicare provider numbers. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number o/members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Speaker, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is not in the chamber at the moment. He must be the only person in Australia, certainly the only health ministerMr Crean-He is probably out checking the press releases.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He is probably out checking the press releases, as the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) interjects. He must be the only person in Australia, and certainly the only health minister in Australia, who thinks it is good news when Australia's two largest private health funds increase their premiums by up to 15 per cent. He must be the only one who thinks it is good news-and certainly the only health ministerMs Macklin-Certainly not families.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: And certainly the pensioners and the families that are going to be hit, as the member interjects, are the ones who will be paying the price because of the decision this government has taken. I am not sure whether the minister is coming in for this debate but, if he is squibbing it, it will be the second occasion in a row that the minister has squibbed an MPI. I hope he is coming into the chamber for the debate because we always like to hear his contributions, and we would like him to respond to some of the points that we are going to raise today about the way this government has turned health policy into a complete shambles. We have to remember that this is the minister who claimed that he was absolutely on top of everything, that he was on top of every detail and every scrap of information in his portfolio responsibilities. But this is the minister who said that he was not aware of the MBF press release. In fact, we saw it being handed to him during question time. He claims to be on top of everything but he has to have someone hand him a copy of the MBF press release. Then he cannot even quote from it accurately without misleading the parliament. Then he admits that he has approved increases of up to 15 per cent for this health fund, but he does not know who will be affected. It must be very difficult to be alvmlutely on top of everything, but to not knov' about the press release announcing it, to not . now whether he has misled the parliament or to not know what the arrangements are for that particular health fund, the fact is that health policy under this government and health policy under this minister is a shambles. We have the two largest private health funds increasing their premiums by up to 15 per cent, we have federal funding for public hospitals being cut back yet again, and today is the third national day of action by young doctors who are on strike or who are protesting about this government's unfair and retrospective legislation on Medicare provider numbers. So that is the reason we raise this matter of public importance today. That is the reason we are trying to give the minister a chance to come and defend himself in the chamber. We can only hope that the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) is going to take up the challenge for the honourable member and perhaps speak in defence of his close colleague Dr Wooldridge, the person whom we all know he would like to replace. Let me start with the issue of health insurrebate. ance. For the 13 years when they were in opposition, they always had only two policies for health: the first policy was to abolish Medicare and the second policy was to give rebates for health insurance. They were the only two ideas you had in opposition: abolish Medicare and give tax rebates for private health insurance. After a couple of election losses, they had to ditch the first promise of the claim that they were going to abolish Medicare. In the background of course, as we all know, decision after decision in this budget undermines Medicare. Publicly, they are saying that they have ditched that first philosophy. They have ditched the claim that they are going to abolish Medicare. The second thing, the only thing, they were left with at the 1996 election was this great idea of giving tax breaks for private health insurance. That was going to be the miracle solution to every problem that we have in the health service today. It was going to increase the number of people who would take out private health insurance. It was going to reduce the pressure on our public hospital system. What we find is that, not even six months before the tax rebate starts to get paid, most of that rebate has been swallowed up in higher premiums. They have spent $1.7 ?illion and they have got nothing for it. IS nothing to show for it. There certainly is not an increase in the number of people who have taken out private health insurance and there is no evidence at all that there is any pressure being taken off our public hospitals. The first mistake that this government and this minister made was that, when they decided to provide this tax break of $1.7 billion to the industry, they did not seek any assurances from the private health funds that they would moderate their premium increases. You would have thought that if the government really believed that this tax rebate would solve all the problems in health insurance from I July next year, they would have brought in all the health funds, sat them down at the table and asked them for some form of assurance that they would not be jacking up their premiums to steal back that health What in fact happened? They announced in the budget that they are locked into giving out this $1.7 billion tax break, yet they had no assurances at all from the industry. Imagine if the government believed that it was good for the nation to buy more steel and offered anyone who bought steel a tax rebate. Imagine if they offered us $1.7 billion worth of tax rebates if we bought more steel stakes and more sheet steel. Mr Hollis-I'd support that.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I know that the member representing Illawarra is a strong supporter of such a policy. The point is: before you give BHP and all the people involved in the steel industry a $1.7 billion tax break, wouldn't you pick up the phone and ring BHP and ask John Prescott if he would agree to moderate his prices for steel so that he would not try to snatch back the $1.7 billion? That is what has happened. The government could not be bothered to sit down with the health funds to get some assurances from them about what would happen with increases. What we have seen as a result is that funds are snatching back the benefits that have flowed from this tax rebate. What we find is that every time these increases take place the government goes into There panic mode. Back in August, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who has to be seen to be doing something, decided that in future he would personally consider, vet and ultimately approve every application for increase. Mr Fitzgibbon-He'll fix it up.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I know that the member for Hunter was hopeful that that might make a difference. But what have we seen? Back in August the Prime Minister blamed a junior official in the Department of Health and Family Services for approving six per cent increases. What is happening now? The Prime Minister is approving 12 per cent or 15 per cent increases. So it is okay for the Prime Minister to attack a junior official in the department of health for approving six per cent increases, but when the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the minister for health approve increases of double the there is no blame associated with him. He was forced to do it. But it was okay for the Prime Minister to attack a junior official in the department. Let me remind the House that, back in August when the Prime Minister intervened, he announced an inquiry which is currently being undertaken by the Productivity Commission. It will report in February. The Prime Minister was asked what would happen to further applications that might be lodged by funds before next February. The Prime Minister's response was, 'Well, we'll be disappointed if any funds apply.' He said, The government would look askance at any applications.' So there is the signal. According to the Prime Minister, not only would they be tough on any future application, but they would also discourage anyone from lodging any more applications between now and February. That is what he said in August. What has actually happened? The government's own health fund, Medibank Private, has been approved quite a substantial increase. They say that that is an average of almost 13 per cent, with increases of up to 15 per cent. When the government's own health fund ignores the Prime Minister's plea, that pretty bad. But when the Prime Minister ignores his own plea for restraint then that even worse. When the Prime Minister, John Howard, ignores John Howard's request for moderation on health insurance increases, something is very wrong. The minister for health summed it up accurately a month or so ago when he appeared on Meet the Press. In a moment of honesty, he admitted that this was as much about perceptions as it was about reality. That was the admission that the Prime Minister's intervention back in August was nothing but a publicity stunt. The Prime Minister's intervention in August has actually seen, since he has been personally responsible for health insurance fund increases, a doubling of the size of the applications, a doubling of the size of the increases. It was nothing but an attempt to manipulate perceptions. Question time today was very interesting. We had the minister appear on the AM prosize gram this morning for a few minutes and make three mistakes. He got caught out here today at question time. The first mistake he made was that he claimed that the government had in some way beaten down MBF. What did MBF say in their press release, which was released, by coincidence, yesterday-virtually while the President of the United States was addressing this chamber? The MBF announced: A notification of contribution rate changes as originally submitted by the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia (MBF), which represents the health funding needs of more than 1.3 million Australians, has been approved by the Federal Government. This was as originally submitted by MBF and approved by the government. There is obviously someone not telling the truth here. Is it MBF or is it the Minister for Health and Family Services? We also remind the minister that he said on AM this morning that the average increase for MBF is 6.5 per cent. When we ask him whether he stands by that, whether he is prepared to mislead this House the way he misled the listeners of AM this morning-not deliberately, I am sure-he repeats part of a quote. He quoted quite selectively the rise in is contribution rates of 6.5 per cent across the fund's membership overall, but what he did is not tell honourable members is that the rest of the sentence said that we get that figure of 6.5 per cent by shoving 300,000 contributors into excess policies. It is like saying that, yes, price of a Commodore has gone up 15 per cent but you can get a Barina at a cheaper price. If you take up a product which is of lesser value or with a larger excess, of course you would expect the price to be cheaper. That is the way this minister has misled this House and the listeners of the AM program. Mr Eoin Cameron- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to take a point of order. The honourable member for Dobell would know that, if he wants to accuse a minister of misleading the House, he must do so by substantive motion. Mr Adams-On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have not ruled on this one yet. Mr Adams-On the point of order

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I will hear the member for Lyons. Mr Adams-I think the honourable minister ought to be here. He should be in the House to take objection.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is no point of order. On the point of order of the honourable member for Stirling: I have been listening very carefully to the member for Dobell, and he did go close to the wind on a couple of occasions. He became aware of that, has moderated his language and will continue to do so.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member's point of order raises the question: where is the minister? He has missed an MPI debate for the second occasion in a row. Where is the minister? This is what the chamber is all about. We know the minister had a bad question time. We know he has been caught out misleading the parliament.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He's exercising his right to silence.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: So should the member for Banks.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He might be back in the cone of silence, but the point I want to make is that this $1.7 billion tax break is being swallowed up by increases in premiums that this government is approving. To pay for that $1.7 billthe ion tax break for private health insurance, what has happened? The government have cut federal funding for public hospitals by $800 million, they have abolished the Commonwealth dental health program-that is $400 million worth-and they have increased the cost of essential pharmaceuticals by $500 million. So that is what has paid for this tax break for the industry: less money for public hospitals, less money for essential dental services and an increase in the cost of pharmaceuticals. That is what the government has had to do-not because of some deficit but because it had not funded its election promises. With the government having spent that $1.7 billion for no benefit whatsoever, we now have to ask ourselves: to improve the quality of health care of Australians, wouldn't it have been better to have spent that $1.7 billion in improving public hospitals by giving them extra money? I can assure the House that, whatever decisions this government might wish to take in relation to this area, the minister has been exposed this afternoon for misleading this House. He must be the only person in Australia who thinks it is good news when Australia's two largest health funds increase their rates by up to 15 per cent, he must be the only person in Australia who thinks that in some way we can provide better health care to Australians by cutting federal funding for public hospitals and he must be the only Liberal minister for health who has so quickly managed to have gotten so many doctors and so many organisations offside. So it is no wonder that the minister is not prepared to appear in the House to defend his reputation. We can assure him that the questions will continue and that we will ensure that he continues to be accountable for this shambles of a health policy. (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Boothby) (3.49 p.m.)It has been interesting to listen to the shadow spokesman for health, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). He has been handed what could be considered a dream portfolio in opposition. Health is a dream portfolio. And do honourable members know what? He is going to blow it. He is blowing it because he does not understand it. It is an enormously complex area. The demands in health are great and competitive. It is very interesting that he was there for most of the past 13 years of the failed Keating and Hawke governments. During that period, private health cover membership dropped from 65 per cent to 33.6 per cent of Australians, and it was actually the direct actions of the Hawke and Keating governments which contributed during that period to a 39 per health premiums. The member for Dobell has mentioned three areas in this MPI. He has dealt with private health insurance and has looked at the funding of public hospitals and the restriction of provider numbers -[or medical students and current interns. I will deal with each of those in due course. It is very interesting to see the ALP now coming in here as the defenders of private health insurance. It is very interesting to see the ALP now coming in here concerned about the fact that all these people who hold health insurance will have their incentives supposedly gobbled up by the premium increases. Mr Albanese-What about the battlers?

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: What about the battlers? This is directed at low and middle income earners. It is very important to separate the issue of private health insurance incentives which are being offered to low and middle earners from the issue of insurance premium rises. They are separate issues. As the opposition spokesman for health understands very well, during the Hawke and Keating governments 174 requests for premium increases were made by health funds. How many did they reject? Not one. They did not reject one. The member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) has not stayed to hear my contribution, but her former boss, Brian Howe, when he was health minister during 1991-92-he is a fellow traveller of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese )--oversaw a 17 per cent increase on average in private health funds. That was at about the same time that he managed to walk into a broom closet at the end of a press conference during the dying days of the Hawke government. It has been estimated that a two per cent drop in private health cover costs this nation the equivalent of 325,000 bed days. That is also the equivalent of two teaching hospitals. As I said before, the Hawke and Keating governments oversaw a decline in private health insurance of the order of 30 per cent. That is the equivalent of 30 teaching hospitals cent increase in around Australia. It is interesting that the member for Dobell, the ALP's spokesman on health, has not even bothered to stay and listen to this debate. He is not even concerned about the real issues which face Australians in the health area. We are interested in addressing the issue of cost shifting, which is a rort and which he defends. We are interested in preventive health measures. We are interested in giving people some relief for holding private health cover and trying to increase those rates of private health cover so that there is not such an incredible private demand on the public system. Labor contributed to that decline in private health insurance by such initiatives as changing the Medicare rebate from 85 to 75 per cent. They removed the reinsurance pool and they totally neglected to address the issue of cost shifting. In fact, back in August, the shadow minister did not even understand what cost shifting was. He had no idea that it was so complex. The ALP also removed the Commonwealth bed day subsidy. All of those actions by the previous government contributed to a 39 per cent increase in premiums. About five million Australians will be eligible for private health insurance tax incentives. It is important to emphasise, especially to those 700,000 Australians whose incomes are below $20,000 but who have been holding private insurance, that this incentive will be available as a tax rebate, but it will also be available as an equivalent amount by way of a reduced premium cost for those who do not pay enough tax. So for pensioners and others who are earning less than $20,000 a year and who hold private health insurance, it does not matter if they do not pay tax, they will be eligible; they will just pay a reduced premium. It should be remembered that Labor had a few health ministers during its period in office. Carmen Lawrence's health legislation did nothing to address the haemorrhaging that was going on in private health insurance. Looking at the issue of cost shifting, if the shadow minister is concerned about cost shifting, which we have addressed, he is in a sense defending a rort. There are plenty of visible signs of this rort. In a Melbourne public hospital, there is a bulk-billing Medicare clinic which specialises in things like plaster cast removal. That is a direct shifting of cost from what should be a state responsibility to the Commonwealth government. In another Melbourne hospital, there are 62 privatised outpatient clinics. This is all quite contrary to the Medicare agreement. Health ministers agreed at their June 1995 meeting in Alice Springs to recover annually the growth that was occurring in cost shifting in that period. That is all we have done. The member for Dobell refers to decreases in funding to public hospitals. It relates to addressing this whole issue of cost shifting. I would like to refer to a few quotes. Here is one: ... as the Labor Party had always been a bit biased against private health insurance ... That was said by a former health minister in the Keating government, Graham Richardson. It is interesting to note that Paul Keating, in the 1993 election campaign, said that people did not need private health insurance, that Medicare would be enough. Richardson went on to say: I was never comfortable with the thought of wealthy people elbowing battlers out of queues in public hospitals. That was the situation that occurred under the Labor government. The member for Grayndler talks about battlers. While he was never a fellow traveller of Graham Richardson, Graham Richardson went on to say: Even the thought that the Liberals are prepared make the rich pay more when the Labor Party would not is enough to scare the hell out of me. !f they are so concerned about private health lllsurance and people not being in the system, why is it that they never addressed this issue? Richardson went on to say: . . . there were those in the party who thought any suggestion that public hospitals were not being adequately funded amounted either to cowardice in being unable to face up to funding cutsthat would be members of the Right like the member for Dobellor treason for daring to suggest anything could be wrong with Medicare. That would be members of the Left like the member for Grayndler. Finally, I would like to speak on the issue of the restriction of Medicare provider numbers. There is no doubt this was a tough decision. It was tough on interns and it was tough on current medical students. It was based on the premise that each doctor who goes onto the Medicare benefits schedule adds something like $175,000 to $225,000 through consultations, pharmaceuticals, radiology and pathology services. The OECD has estimated that at least 55 per cent of health care costs are supply driven. This was a difficult decision. We have looked at a number of areas. We are actually addressing the area of reducing medical school intakes. We are making it more difficult for overseas trained doctors to practise in Australia by imposing a lO-year moratorium on those doctors practising. That will apply after I January 1997. In a previous speech on the bill which related to this issue, the ALP spokesman for health said this: The Labor Party certainly understands the importance of seeking to manage the medical work force ... He is so right there, because it is very interesting to look at what has been said on this issue by health ministers in the previous government. First of all, before this proposal had even been floated, this year in Australian Doctor, Brian Howe said: Restricting provider numbers should be considered to limit the general practice workforce. He went on to say: to . . . perhaps provider numbers could control the numbers of GPs. What did the health minister after him, Graham Richardson, say about it? In the Bulletin of October 1996 he said: I hope Michael Wooldridge, the Federal Minister for Health, stands his ground and limits Medicare provider numbers for new medical graduates from November. He went on to say: The AMA was told in 1993 that restrictions on Medicare provider numbers were inevitable. I told the AMA that this would happen, regardless of governed Australia. Last of all, the senior general practice adviser of the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), the last health minister in the Keating government, confirmed that they had sought legal advice which indicated that it was possible to restrict access to provider numbers. It is all very well for the ALP to come in here and say that this is a terrible thing the government is doing. We know it is a tough thing. All members on this side of this House know that it is a tough thing. The problem has been that, in order to keep Medicare going, we had to address some of the uncontrolled increases in cost that have occurred in Medicare. In fact, I believe that most medical graduates will be able to get work after this measure is introduced. There will be 400 places for general practitioners and, as of next year, there will be 760 specialty posts available. The increase in specialty posts has been due to an expansion in positions in ENT, orthopaedics, anaesthetics and urology. There will also be positions for 20 doctors to go into medical administration and 20 doctors to go into medical research. Next year, rather than 400 general practice training positions, it will be 420. This year, overseas trained doctors had 89 places. When you put that altogether, the number of Australian graduates being approximately 1,200 and 89 overseas trained doctors getting places, it means that almost every Australian graduate-and not all of them will want to go on to practise medicine-will be able to get a training position which will allow them to be better trained before they go onto the Medicare scheme.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Grayndler) (4.03 p.m.)I am pleased to support this MPI put forward by the shadow health minister, the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), today. I think it is a pity that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is not in the chamber during this important debate. If I were responsible for his handling of the portfolio, perhaps I would be running and hiding in the cone of silence in my office as well. I intend to begin by addressing the massive cuts to public hospital funding announced this who week, cuts which back up the cuts that were announced in the budget. These cuts are an attack on the Medicare system and public hospitals. They have a bad impact on doctors, nurses and health care workers. But, most importantly, at the end of the day they will have a devastating impact on patients in the public hospital system. There are $75 million worth of cuts-$34 million in New South Wales, $24 million in Victoria, $9 million in Western Australia, $5 million in Queensland and $3 million in Tasmania. This amounts, in conjunction with the budget cuts, to the largest federal cut to public hospitals since the beginning of Medicare. There has been no consultation with governments about this latest round, just letters to the state health departments letting them know that the cuts would start from this week-cuts that will mean, in a state such as New South Wales, something in the order of $700,000 out of the system per week. This is not surprising because this is really consistent with John Howard's views. Of course we saw two John Howards. We saw a John Howard throughout the seventies and eighties as Treasurer and Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Nehl}-He is called the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The Prime Minister. And then we saw another one, the candidate for the prime ministership in the lead-up to 2 March. On the John Laws program just a few years ago, the current Prime Minister said: We'll pull Medicare apart ... Basically we will be saying to people you can make your own health insurance arrangements. He went on to say: The second thing we'll do is get rid of the bulk billing system-it's an absolute rort. Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He changed his mind. He went to the election and he made a series of promises. He said he would keep Medicare, but what we are seeing is Medicare and the public health system being attacked, ripped apart piece by piece. Every week there are new announcements. That is why the Minister for Health and Family Services is not even bothering to be in this House to defend his handling of this portfolio. He is embarrassed by the performance of this government on health. These latest cuts to health are just more in a series that the coalition has introduced since ment. the election, further proof that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Family Services do not consider providing Australians with a decent, fair and accessible health system is important. These are more cutbacks to a system that is already suffering. There are cutbacks in federal funding for public hospitals of $800 million, cutbacks to the dental health program of $400 million and cutbacks to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of $500 million. And what does that add up to? To $1.7 billion, exactly the handout that is being given to the private insurers in their so-called scheme. On top of that, we are also seeing cutbacks to special purpose programs, like specialist health programs for women and men, mental health programscutbacks right across the board. These cuts will have massive impacts on the health care system in this country. To give an indication of that impact, let us take a look at what the latest round of cuts will mean in a state like New South Wales, a state where the Minister for Health, Dr Refshauge, has not rolled over. He has been defending the public health system. Indeed, in the next financial year, funding in the New South Wales system will be increased by $632 million. In spite of the cuts coming from this federal government, there will be a $632 million increase. In real terms, this latest round will mean that over 900 medical and nursing employees will face the loss of their jobs, with another 160 support staff positions to go. Some 400 hospital beds will be closed and an incredible 17,000 fewer patients will be able to be treated in the public hospital system causing severely increased delays for elective surgery and longer delays in emergency departments. The mates of the government over here in the New South Wales parliament are talking about increasing the funding in the health system in New South Wales at the same time as the federal government is making further cuts. It is quite clear that the public health system in this country needs increased funding, not massive reductions. That is why the Carr government in New South Wales has done that, in spite of the role of this governIt is rather ironic that we have a health minister here who is perhaps the only doctor in the country who thinks that it is acceptable for public hospitals to get less funds. It is abundantly clear to anyone who has ever set foot in a public hospital emergency department that the health professionals and support staff are already working incredibly hard, under immense pressure, to provide a quality service to their patients. Members will recall yesterday's comments of the Australian of the Year, Dr John Yu. He said: The public hospitals, hospitals like mine, look after the Australian battler. Remember them-the Australian battlers? He also said: Private hospitals look after people who can look after themselves, but we worry about those who can't. This is the Australian of the Year talking about children and about the latest round of cuts from this uncaring, selfish government. Staff at his hospital, the Sydney Children's Hospital at Westmead, work so hard because they are helping families in need. It is a shame that the coalition is not working as hard as they are on supporting those workers and improving the system they work in. Given a choice of Dr Yu on the one hand and the minister for health on the other, I know whose side I am on. I am on the side of the Australian battlers, just like Dr John Yu. The problem for this government is that they cannot get over their obsessive hatred of the public sector. It does not matter whether it be public housing, the federal Public Service, the ABC or federally funded child care because, if it is public, they will try to mate it. At the same time, the coalition seem to be pretty generous to their mates in the private sector. The shadow minister has pointed that out today with their approval of the 15 per cent rise in fees for MBF and Medibank Private, the government's own fund. These increases will hit the three million contributors in these funds very hard indeed. It makes a mockery of the coalition's election promises on tax rebates for private health insurance when millions of Australians would have lost more than half of that rebate already in premium increases. And that is just since March! They do not get the rebate until July next year, but they have already lost it. The last round of premium increases in August have already been hurting people in my electorate. What does the minister say? He says, 'It's not 15 per cent. They can just downgrade the sort of. insurance they take out.' And he accuses us of being the attackers of private health insurance! He says, 'You can just downgrade. Go for the cheaper model.' What is that if not an attack on those who take out private health insurance? The rather pathetic replacement-the substitute for a minister over there-raised a question of the former minister Graham Richardson and his proposal. He did propose a levy on higher income earners, but he said that you had to put the money back into the public health system. You had to do it-something that you people have not done. Let me conclude with this: I have battlers in my electorate coming to see me. I had a phone call from a constituent called Rita Holden today, a pensioner in Marrickville, talking about the hardships that these increases would bring. They are the sort of people this will impact, not the holders of unit trusts that we see over there. At the same time that these increases were being announced, the President of the United States was addressing this chamber. How ironic, given that Hillary Clinton asked for a briefing on the public health system in Australia-the best in the Western world. How deciembarrassing for this mob over here who are wrecking this system.

Speaker: Mr EOIN CAMERON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Can I say, for a start, how disappointed I am to hear the words of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) because I did, until this day, have a passing respect for the member for Grayndler. He shares a number of things in common with me-that is, he parts his hair on the same side, he is remotely handsome and he has a deep seated repugnance of the New South Wales Right. However, he has spoken today an absolute heap of nonsense. He obviously has not been looking at recent history, especially Australia's history of the last 13 years or so when his side of politics was in power. He is being hypocritical and utterly duplicitous. When did he complain, during the last 13 years, about the 174 times there were rises in private health insurance? When did you grizzle? Tell me about the battlers that you fended away from your door during those 174 occasions-not one. It is equally duplicitous for the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), the joke of a shadow minister for health, to be bleating loud and long now. The only thing that he does with any kind of authority or any kind of authenticity at all is playa Paul Keating clone with some kind of credibility, and I congratulate him on that. This is an act of hypocrisy and an act of duplicity. For Labor to propose an MPI like this is an absolute gall. You had 13 years to do something and you did absolutely diddlysquat. They expect us to clean up their 13 years of mess in just a few months of government. It is something, quite frankly, that you cannot do in that brief period of time. We recognise the mess that Australia has inherited from your lot and we will clean it up. Labor came to power in 1983. At that time, membership in private health insurance in Australia was 63.7 per cent of the population. In Western Australia, membership was 62.2 per cent of the population. In March this when Labor lost and after they had presided over this travesty, membership in Australia was down to 33.9 per cent and, in Western Australia, it was down to 36.8 per cent. There is an election approaching in Western Australia-as opposition members no doubt know and as they no doubt do not want to hear about-but these figures should remind people in Western Australia about how your mob works in government, or how your mob does not work in government. If Geoff Gallop is elected Premier of Western Australia, he will treat the health system with the same neglect that the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) did. I can tell honourable members that it is only in recent times that I have got over shuddering at the title of 'Minister for Health'. It is only since the present Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, has taken over that role that I have had some confidence in a minister for health. When the member for Fremantle was in that position, my flesh would crawl every time you mentioned the title 'Minister for Health'. Here is a woman who was the Premier of Western Australia but who sold the state down the gurgler through the WA Inc. years and who was a disgrace as the minister for health. She was a disgrace to the women of Western Australia. She sold western women short, and I cannot imagine how opposition members can sit there with her still on their front-bench. Most people would be too ashamed and would not have the gall to have her in any position whatsoever. Having spoken privately to Labor members of this parliament, I know that she is a complete embarrassment to you. The sooner she goes the better for Labor, Western Australia and Australia. The Labor government in Western Australia, when Geoff Gallop and Carmen Lawrence were in power, did nothing to encourage the federal Labor government to stop the flow of members out of private health insurance. They did nothing. They assisted in the destruction of our health system and they pretty damn well destroyed it totally. If Geoff Gallop is year, elected the Premier of Western AustraliaGod forbid-Western Australians can expect higher waiting lists as he sits by and watches, just as he sat by and watched what happened when Labor was in government prior to 1993. The fall in membership of private health insurance threatens the stability of the entire health care system. Despite that, Labor sat back and did absolutely nothing about it. They provided no encouragement for people to stay in private health insurance. To have the then Prime Minister of the country bragging about the fact that he was not in private health insurance used to just absolutely amaze me, but of course the man was loaded. With his piggeries and what have you, he could afford to get himself into the luxury hospitals whenever he wanted to. Labor sat back and did nothing through all those years. They came in here bleating about a premium increase when they did n-thing over the 174 premium increases. Mr Albanese interjecting

Speaker: Mr EOIN CAMERON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Grayndler must be so embarrassed. I am surprised you are still in the House. I would have thought you would have been too embarrassed to sit here. I obviously misread the cut of your jib, because I thought you were a man of some standards. Why did the Labor Party do nothing when it was in government for 13 years? Labor members ought to answer that before they come in here seeking the high moral ground after completely stuffing up the health system over that time. Labor was happy with the growing hospital waiting list. I knew all about that because I managed to get here against the tide in 1993. I heard all about those waiting lists, I can tell you.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: You've done a great job ever since.

Speaker: Mr EOIN CAMERON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I thank the member for Fisher very much. Labor let people flow out of the private health insurance system like water going down a drain. They provided no incentive to remain in private health insurance-absolutely none whatsoever. They let the pressure build on the public health system and they caused the waiting list to grow. They did nothing. The coalition has taken the responsibility to redress that, and we will redress it. We did not inherit this $10 billion mess for nothing. We know we have to fix it, and we are taking the responsibility to fix it. Just looking at the member for Dobell's wording in the MPI, he started off by saying: The pain inflicted on the health of millions Australians resulting from private health fund premiums rising by up to 15 per cent. .. What about the pain of the 174 increases inflicted by your mob when you were sending the health system down the gurgler? What a gall. The 174 increases. What did you do about that? What did you do about the decline in the number of members going into private health insurance? You did nothing. Absolutely nothing. It is forever to your shame that you did absolutely nothing. It is time that you opposite understood that the health system that we preside over is not perfect, but we are going to be doing our best to fix up the mess that you left. I think the Australian people told you exactly what they thought of the way you had managed Australia by the way they voted in March. In Lindsay-isn't it glorious to see Jackie Kelly back?-the Australian people underlined what they thought of your management of this country. Australia's public hospital system is in overload. We need to encourage as many people as possible to ensure that they have access to the full range of health care services, both public and private, and we are doing that. We are doing what Labor was too politically bankrupt to do. There are a couple of things I would like to mention. One is the health ministers under Labor. Let us look at them-and what a rogues' gallery, if you don't mind. Neal Blewett: he started Medicare, but made no provisions for a balanced health care system by encouraging people to remain in private health insurance. Brian Howe: he did nothing, but when he retired-it is amazing how you lot get brave when you retire-he said that he should have done something. Graham Richardson: he did nothing but, during the election, he said, 'Something should have been done.' He had plenty of time to do something, but he did nothing. And as for the member for Fremantle, Carmen Lawrence. My God, this embarrassment of Australian politics. One of the reasons why I think politicians have a rotten reputation is the member for Fremantle. She probably forgot what she was the minister for. of She is a disgrace to the Australian parliament. She should never have been a minister. She should never have been the health minister. I will quote from the West Australian on 15 November last year. The headline states 'She lied'. This is the member for Fremantle, who was the health minister at the time.
