Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: HIGH COURT PROCEEDINGS
text: Mackellar-Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel) (4.24 p.m.)-On behalf of the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), I move: That the House grants leave for Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks to produce the following records in evidence in proceedings before the High Court in the cases (a) Laurence Nathan Levy v. The State of Victoria and Others (b) Lange v. Australian Broadcasting Corporation Parliamentary Debates, House of Representatives, 15 November 1994-Speeches of Mr Lavarch-(pp 3336-3342). This motion is intended to grant a request conveyed to the House in the letter tabled by the Speaker on Tuesday. The letter is from Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks, solicitors, and seeks permission of the House to adduce in evidence certain extracts from the Hansard. The request concerns a speech on the Racial Hatred Bill 1994. Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks act for the Herald and Weekly (No. Times Ltd, which is, we gather, seeking leave to intervene in two matters scheduled to be heard before the High Court. These are the SENATE proceedings listed in the notice of motion. The motion itself does not address the substantive issue of privilege itself. That is a matter governed by the law as expounded in section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. The well-known immunity of parliamentary proceedings from being impeached or questioned in court is inherited from article 9 of the Bill of Rights; however, subsection 16(5) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act does Reference in fact state that neither the 1987 act nor the Bill of Rights is taken to prevent the admission of parliamentary records in connection with a matter arising under section 57 of the constitution or the interpretation of an act. While there is some judicial authority for the view that the permission of the House is not required on the procedural question of actual production of the parliamentary records, as distinct from the substantive question of the use to which they can be put, the House has never formally abandoned the position that permission should be soughthence, today's motion. There are a number of precedents for permission being granted. In fact, three instances have arisen in the present sittingsProcessing more recently on 29 October-in relation the same proceedings as referred to in the present request, but of course different tracts from the Hansard. Further background on these matters is contained in House of Representatives Pracred tice at pages 690 to 698. I am confident that, if it grants the request for leave, the House will be acting in full accord with the preceability dents which exist. Question resolved in the affirmative. NA Member for Cowper

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING
text: I had commenced my remarks about the Import Charges Bill 1996 before question to time intervened. I was dealing with the responsibilities of the Minister for Small  for Customs. I was making the observation that, apart from this bill, putting up charges for the use of customs as well as increasing tape for small business was against the background of some very significant cuts to the Customs Service, thereby restricting its to perform its duties. Those cuts total $70 million over the next four years, the loss of 105 jobs in Victoria, 65 in New South Wales, 60 in the ACT, 25 in Queensland and 24 in Western Australia. This is a government that, on the one hand, is saying it will increase employment but, on the other, is taking deliberate steps that indeed cut it back. The government has also introduced a complete ending of all airport shift work. This is a very interesting decision by the Minister for Small Business and Connot sumer Affairs in relation to his own departis ment, because it comes from a minister who, the before he was the minister and when in of the opposition, told his colleagues: Any budgetary cuts to [customs inspection and I clearance procedures] would slow down the clearance of goods, holding up businesses, and result in rea lesser frequency of inspections. cuts would also result in a decline in the number of audits undertaken and hence revenue Any decline in the intelligence activities will impact on Customs' law enforcement activities and, and the in particular, their success. You have not only the impact in terms of businesses wanting to get access to their goods and that being held up but also the minister admitting before he implemented these decisions that they would hamper the ability of the Customs Service to carry out its own activities. The minister has also presided over a $400 million cut to the diesel fuel rebate. Presumably, this cut came about because they claimed there were $400 million of rorters in the scheme. What the government claimed in advance of the diesel fuel rebate decision, in saying that they had kept their election promise, was they would not cut the rebate except in cases of abuse of the system. The minister is really saying to the farmers and the miners of this country, 'We kept the diesel fuel rebate but, really, it is $400 million less. The reason it is $400 million less is that you are rorting the scheme.' This is the stock defence by the government to a lot of the cuts that they have imposed. Rather than enter the dialogue and the debate about these things, they simply assert the fact that there has been a rort. Turning to the minister's responsibility in the small business side of his portfolio, the minister recently released the Charlie Bell review of small business red tape. This was another of the election promises of the government. Interestingly enough, when this report was released, it was not tabled in this parliament. So we have not been able to gain access to copies of this report in the normal way that one would expect. I am told that the honourable member for  ring the minister's office to get a copy of the report. The person ringing on behalf of the member for Shortland was asked which party the member was from. When they said it was for the ALP, they were told, 'You've got to go to the government bookshop.' In other words, what we have here is a government !hat is so into openness, accountability, Improved understanding and improved information that it will only release its report to mates-having accused us of being in the mates' brigade-and, so far as the Labor Party is concerned, we have to pay for the privilege. This is hardly what you would call an evenhanded approach in government, but it is the way in which the minister operates in relation to his portfolio. I think it is in keeping with the way in which he operates his private businesses about which we have already demonstrated there are so many appearances of conflict of interest that they have become legion. Yet his view on all of these things is to deny either responsibility or conflict, or both, and say that so far as he is concerned he will keep it all to himself. The Charlie Bell review was about finding ways of meeting the Prime Minister's commitment to cut small business red tape by 50 per cent over the term of the government, which was a promise reconfirmed by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as recently as last month. The Charlie Bell report has, in effect, set a benchmark for this government. We know the government itself does not like setting benchmarks. It will not set a target for the unemployed, it will not set a target for employment growth, it will not reaffirm targets in important areas of economic activity; but it is prepared, in election promise terms, to set a target of cutting red tape by 50 per cent. Let us understand the importance of that: targets for people do not matter but targets for paper do. When we ask, 'What does the 50 per cent target reduction mean?' they sort of go mute. They say, 'We have got a commitment of 50 per cent over the term of the government.' What is revealing in this report is the ability to measure and benchmark that target. It stated in the report that the average small business spends four hours a week on government red tape-translated, the promise is to cut red tape to two hours. Labor will be keeping a close eye on whether the government does in fact keep to that promise. I see that the minister is not even here in the House. He was not in the House when this debate was on just before question time and he is still not here. No doubt he is lookits ing after the affairs of his private companies. They are more important than the matters before parliament. The minister has made a dreadful start in cutting red tape. As these bills show, one of the minister's first acts is to increase tax. Remember the promises made before the election, 'No increase in taxes under a Liberal government.' Read my lips, honest John: no increase in taxes. This is what this bill does. Don't you think that a charge imposed on businesses that have to use the services to get their goods constitutes a charge or a tax? That is what he has put up. He runs around the country promising to cut red tape and not put taxes up; yet this is a bill that increases taxes as well as increasing the red tape. The package comprises three bills which the Deputy Speaker has indicated we are dealing with cognately. They give legislative authority for the measures announced in the budget to introduce full cost recovery for import related services delivered by the Australian Customs Service. It involves the imposition of 13 fees and charges-in other words, taxes. This is a broken promise-obviously not a core promise-and this is a government committed to helping small business. The new taxes will apply from 1 January 1997. Overall, the bills will not be opposed by Labor because they do expand the user-pays arrangements for Customs begun when we were in office. They apply only to imports and they are levied either on the importer or the shipper. But the opposition does have some major concerns with the impact the bills will have on small businesses and in some regions. We will therefore be moving a series of amendments in the Senate to protect the people whose livelihoods are threatened by aspects of these bills. In essence, Labor is concerned that the bills will lead to extra costs for imports of materials used in manufacturing here in Australia at a time when business incentive measures are being stripped away all through the budget. What the charges will do is also have a greater impact on regional ports where Customs have closed their offices and may impact negatively on regional ports such as Geelong. The measures will also increase small business red tape. The government claims they have consulted widely with industry on the introduction of these charges. This appears mainly to have occurred within the confines of the Customs National Consultative Committee. The intention of Labor is therefore to move amendments as I will outline. The first is a four-year phase-in period for the reduction threshold at which the import entry charge is levied from $1,000 to $250. As it stands now in the proposal, the reduction in the threshold may have a substantial impact on small importers who supply niche markets with specialised product from overseas and to low volume importers, typically small business. The immediate imposition of the lower threshold could drive such firms out of business by imposing the extra $22.80 charge for electronic entries or $44.55 for manual entries. Secondly, we will be moving an amendment for a four-year phase-in period for the new fees. This is particularly important for fees on manual entry which are to be levied at a much higher level than the fees on electronic entry. What this does is threaten disproportionately small businesses which do not have access to the electronic facilities or which lack the expertise to utilise the service. While Customs' advice is that they plan to increase access to electronic entering by installing computers at Customs shop fronts, airports, international mail exchanges and customs houses, where many small commercial importers currently lodge their manual claims, these facilities will not be in place on 1 January when the high fees are proposed to be applicable. It therefore seems reasonable that a phase-in period apply. Thirdly, in respect of the licensing charge for section 17B premises, we will seek to introduce a two-tiered fee based on the turnover of the individual premises. This will help protect premises and jobs based in regional Australia where the turnover may be lower but the service is no less important. So whilst not opposing the overall thrust of this bill we do want to highlight the concerns that we have. The first is with the way the minister has been administering his portfolio-the very fact that he is still not in the chamber is evidence of his neglect and the contempt in which he holds this important piece of work. The second is with the fact that we see inherent in this bill a breach yet again of election commitments on two fronts-first, that it does involve an increase in taxes on small businesses and, second, that it adds to the paperwork that businesses will have to undertake-and the third is in relation to the specific detail of the bill. We think the decision to implement and move completely to full cost recovery on 1 January is not appropriate. For that reason we will be supporting amendments which seek to provide a phase-in for the measures sought.

Speaker: Mr SOMLYAY
Title: CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING
text: The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) for 20 minutes of his half hour spoke about the Minister for Small Business and Consumer  10 minutes to the Customs Amendment Bill (No.2) 1996. In my remarks J will devote my total time to remarks on the bill. This bill is one of the three bills designed to implement cost recovery for import related services delivered by the Australian Customs Service. The three bills in this legislative package provide for the imposition and collection of 13 charges and fees on import related services. The 13 imposts are located in three pieces of legislation, two new charges billsthe Import Processing Charges Bill and the Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bill-as well as the Customs Amendment Bill. These bills will result in full cost recovery for commercial customs activities directly and indirectly required to process imports. This was among the measures announced by the government in the 1996-97 budget. From 1 January 1997 the Australian Customs Service will apply full cost recovery for all commercial customs activities directly and indirectly required to process imports. The services to be covered by the new charges are cargo reporting, both sea and air, import entry processing-sea, air and post-and licensing of approved places for the examination of goods. This measure forecasts a net budget impact of $45.9 million per annum. This represents $66.5 million less the $18.5 million currently collected for the use of IT facilities. To coincide with this measure, Customs has taken the opportunity to streamline refund procedures and associated cost recovery, and adjust current charges for out of hours work or work by customs officers in locations where they do not usually work. Charges have been determined from a detailed activity based costing of customs services. The costing methodology has been reviewed by external auditors. The charges are limited to the calculated costs of delivering the functions and will be reviewed annually to ensure that they reflect only the costing structure. Costs to process import transactions by Customs will be examined annually and any material changes will be reflected in an annual review of the charges. Before outlining the industry impact of these changes, I would like to draw attention to the industry consultation which took place after the budget. After the budget announcement, members of the Customs National Consultative Committee, the CNCC, were briefed at a special meeting about the nature of the proposed charges. This committee comprises representatives from the Australian Air Transport Association, the Australian Chamber of Shipping, the Australian Federation of International Forwarders, the Customs Brokers Council of Australia-CBCA-the International Air Couriers Association, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Law Council of Australia and the Institute of Chartered Accountants. Their feedback resulted in some changes being made to the charges for entry processing and the methods of collection. This committee met again in September where the charges were once more the subject of discussion. Meetings have been held with various sectors of the importing community, such as the air express couriers and the cargo terminal operators, in regard to establishing the most efficient collection methods for the charges. In meeting with a variety of industry sectors, Customs was made aware of some difficulties that the collection of cargo reporting fees and screening fees would impose on cargo terminal operators and shipping companies for manual reporting charges and on air express couriers for screening charges. Special arrangements may be entered into for the collection of the charges, including periodic settlement arrangements to coincide with the operating environment and billing cycles experienced by many of the firms in the importing community. In addition to meetings, Customs has conducted a series of industry briefing sessions in all state and territory capital cities and in several regional centres. These sessions have provided an opportunity for Customs to explain details about the charges and how they will be collected. At the same time, the sessions provided a valuable forum for feedback from all sectors of the importing community, much of which has influenced the implementation decisions. The impact on the industry is as follows: 103,000 importers generated around 2.2 million customs entries in 1995, containing 7.2 million entry lines; based on 1995 data, 95 per cent of importers have entries averaging less than 10 lines per entry; 65 per cent of importers bring in four or fewer entriesaveraging 3.5 lines or less per year-and would incur total costs of approximately $100 per annum; 99 importers generated 1,500 or more entries each, together accounting for around 15 per cent of all entries; four of these importers generated over 10,000 entries, the largest importer bringing in just over 14,000 entries. Customs' annual funding will be reduced by an amount equivalent to that raised through cost recovery. This measure therefore aligns the cost of processing imports with that sector of the community-that is, the importerswhich generates customs work, rather than spreading the costs across all taxpayers. This measure is consistent with the general thrust of government policy, which increasingly sees a closer alignment of costs with sectors of the community that benefit from the provision of public services. The user-pays system is already used in relation to the recovery of the costs of processing passengers at international airports, through the passenger movement charge. Customs currently recovers part of the costs of its electronic systems through charges levied on importers for import entries. This proposal sees an extension of a current cost recovery regime. The extension of the current charging arrangements relates only to commercial import processing. It does not cover activity associated with Customs' community protection function relating to the detection and interception of prohibited imports and drugs. The government recognises Customs' important role in this area and in this budget has provided funds to Customs to significantly increase the use of sophisticated technology to maintain and enhance its community protection capability. Nor will charges apply to the processing of export transactions. The exemption of exports from the new user-pays system is a recognition of the key role export industries will play in improving Australia's trade balance. The Australian Customs Service has played a leading role in the development of electronic systems which have enhanced its capacity to facilitate the efficient movement and quick release of cargo. This ultimately benefits the Australian community. The charging regime established reflects the efficiencies of electronic data reporting and will continue to do so. For example, the cargo management strategy-an exposure draft which was released in August 1996-identifies opportunities for enhanced information mechanisms for information exchange between Customs and industry. Within the five-year reach of that strategy, the key elements are: continued recognition of the importance of existing computer syst-ms; to adopt enabling technology which simulates integration of those systems and allows more flexible reporting of information; to permit rationalisation of information needs and reduce duplication and redundancy; and to adopt new technologies which allow more sophisticated manipulation of information for risk management. The end result will be a seamless and flexible system which will simplify information management for all clients and cater for future requirements. The delivery of these types of efficiencies will have a bearing on the ultimate costs to provide Customs' services to its client base. In the cost recovery implementation, significant inroads have been achieved in creating flexible systems both for liability assessment and payment. This is consistent with the thrust of the cargo management strategy. For example, settlement arrangements for manual reporting charges have been made more flexible. As a result of consultation with the cargo terminal operators, the legislation now allows for the CEO of Customs to agree to terms for settlement-potentially monthlyfor some cargo reporters, rather than payment at the time of reporting. In recognition of need to maximise electronic processing of information and to not disadvantage those operators that lodge electronic reports with Customs, Customs has undertaken IT enhancements that will result in the retention electronic data and minimisation of reporting costs. After an approach by the air express couriers, an arrangement for payment of the screen free charge has been agreed by Customs. This arrangement is represented by the payment of a reporting levy against formal entries lodged by those companies entering into the arrangement. For those companies that do not wish to participate in the alternative settlement scheme, monthly settlement will apply. The cost recovery implementation has enabled Customs to address a series of long standing anomalies in its administration. An example is that for several years the air courier industry has criticised an inequity existing between entry requirements for air cargo imports and importation by post. Specifically, commercial air cargo imports valuing $250 or more have required an entry, whereas requirements for entries in the postal environment are for imports valuing $1,000 or more. The new arrangements see this anomaly disappear with a requirement for the lodgement of an entry for all commercial cargo over $250 in value. In summing up, I would like to refer briefly to the background behind the budget decision to apply cost recovery for commercial customs activities relating to the processing of imports. As we in this House are aware, the government was faced with a huge task to turn around the Australian economy. The decision to introduce cost recovery to the Customs import process is in line with the government's general acceptance of the userpays principle. The new charge will have a beneficial side effect-it will attribute direct costs of the import clearance process to goods imported, thereby removing the burden for funding this process from the community generally. While the cost recovery is to do with commercial activity, it is also true that the import clearance process accomplishes far the more than just collection of statistics and revenue. The entire customs process supplies importers with a mechanism which provides awareness of, and monitors compliance with, Australian safety standards, labelling and of other consumer protection laws. In addition, there is an obvious cost in preventing imported goods being used inadvertently or deliberately as a method of bringing in illicit drugs and other contraband. Goods manufactured in Australia do not present the same risk. Finally, the deliberate exemption of the export process from the user-pays regime, as I mentioned earlier, is also extremely important in the context of Australia's future. It is a recognition of the key role export industries will play in improving Australia's trade balance, creating more jobs and reducing the deficit-a task this government has made its highest priority. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING
text: Here is another ill-thought out bill that has some serious ramifications for small business throughout Australia. It is something that has been thrown together. Based on the last speaker's comments, everything has to be met to meet some deficit reduction while small business suffers. Whether it is R&D research or any sort of level of assistance to business, the government's attitude appears to be that we can go without businesses in Australia as long as we have the deficit right. I wish to address the changes to the charges levied for small business to clear customs. Some changes are to streamline processing by adding an electronic link to allow faster clearances. But new charges are being levied on the processing of the cargo reports, import entry processing and the licensing of the approved place for the examination of goods. Customs are trying to cut the costs of processing to 'ensure that costs recovered do not exceed costs calculated to process import transactions'. They reckon the charges are limited to the calculated costs of delivering functions. I would like either the minister or someone on that side to tell me why a small importer who brings in on each consignment an average of between $300 and $400 worth of goods by post suddenly will be hit with a charge of at least $42.65 customs and sometimes up to $80 just for the privilege of having to take longer to clear his goods because the customs officer has been moved. This particular small business, situated in a country area in northern Tasmania, imports goods from England, Scotland, Ireland and Canada from suppliers who previously could not make their goods available here due to the distance of the markets. Their import orders are not large because of the market size and the variety of interests of their customers. Currently, when goods arrive they undertake an informal customs clearance which takes no more than about five minutes. With this clearance, they inform Customs of the value of the goods, the sales tax and duty payable and the cost in Australian dollars. This is then faxed to Customs in Hobart and the goods are dispatched. All these consignments are worth under $1,000 and are imported by post. The amendments moved by the government have put a stop to informal customs clearances. Their user-pays, cost recovery scheme will now involve a $44.55 charge for manual lodgement. This particular business will have to travel to Launceston to lodge it in person. It is going to cost for the lodgement and it is going to cost the small business money in travel. The alternative offered is that they can use electronic lodgement at a cost of $29.65. However, the advice on this was that they would need a customs agent to process transactions to qualify for this reduced fee. The agent has been charging this business $60 per consignment before they started doing the informal customs clearance themselves. From past experience, they believed that this fee would rise with the more formal clearances and licensing fees. They could be charged a fee of $80 by a customs agent plus the electronic lodgement charge of $29.65. They quite rightly point out that, on a consignment of $300, these charges will make the business unprofitable. Although some charges might be applicable for large consignments, the very nature of this particular business prevents them from placing larger orders. They said that they do not consider that a consignment of 15 books, usually worth $300, warrants a charge of $44.55 to process. This is not the sort of charge they can absorb into the cost price of the article. The cost of customs to this particular small business is 15 per cent of the transaction. There is no way any small business can cope with that sort of cost. The government should have looked at ways of reducing the book work involved before proceeding with this legislation. There has been no attempt to discriminate between $1,000 orders and $300 orders. The scheme in the past worked quickly-the duty was paid where and when it should be. The time taken for the processing by the customs officer was minimal-maybe five minutesand it could be done by fax, which cut down on travelling time. To change this to the cumbersome fee collection regime which is being suggested here without some minimum cut off for the value of the goods coming infor example, $1,OOO-seems to be bureaucracy gone mad. Why change a scheme that works well, collects its money and costs little to implement? Has Mr Hilmer put his nose in here too? Change to so-called 'streamline elements of two existing fees' in this case is change for change sake rather than change to achieve efficiency. The government has obviously decided to cut people out of the Customs Service and is using the user-pays principle to justify the cuts. This bill also seeks to charge depots a licence fee of $5,000. I have sought advice on this from customs agents in Tasmania. Some have said that this will result in organisations being unable to afford to operate. Certainly, the smaller ones would have great difficulty. The customs department has informed me that there are 22 depots in Tasmania and they are currently served by 46 customs agents. The government wants to cut the number of agents, so it makes the depots unprofitable and they will close down. Only the big ones will continue to operate. Small business will be the loser. Small business is hit again. The minister should be sticking up for small business, not imposing more charges on it. He comes in and answers questions in question time by saying that the government is in the process of minimising costs to small business. This bill is going to impose more costs on small business. The department mentioned that a lot of the costs will be eliminated once electronic systems are in place at the main airports and post offices. I suggest we put some of those bureaucrats into the middle of Tasmania, in outback New South Wales or in Far North Queensland for a few months and see how they get on. It takes me a minimum of three days to get a letter from Canberra into my office. Most of these isolated areas barely have telephones or decent television reception, let alone lines to allow such things as electronic data transfer. This means people have to drive to their nearest major airport. For people on the west coast of Tasmania that means travelling for 3Vz hours, and for most of the other people in my electorate of Lyons it means travelling for two hours. The Public Service is supposed to be a public service to help the private sector drive our economy. All this government seems to want to do is put obstacles in its way. The governments's intention to sell Telstra, its inability to get Optus and Telstra together to do the cabling-the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications and the Arts, gave some waffle on how this was somebody else's fault; he did not make any contribution to this debate-mean that the country and regional areas have no hope of being connected to anything, certainly not without paying a considerable amount of money in future. So much for the big argument of helping people in country areas. As I said in the beginning, this bill is badly thought out. It will have all sorts of implications if it is carried in its present form. Some minor but critical amendments should be made to make all the difference to the small business sector. There is a strong argument to leave any major changes to charging on depots until the electronic transfer is available outside the major city areas. This should not take long if the commitment to do it is there. There should still be an ability to clear goods to the value of $1,000 through the informal clearance declaration. I think the government should address these points before the bill goes too much further and before we end up in a disastrous situation for many small operators throughout Australia. There is no doubt that there are some major problems within this bill. They need to be addressed before the bill is passed by the parliament.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING
text: Curtin) (5.08 p.m.)Despite the bluster of the Minister for Small  in his second reading speeches, the Customs Amendment Bill (No.2) and cognate bills are blatant revenue raisers, nothing more and nothing less. The rationale employed by the minister is that they are cost recovery measures. 'Cost recovery' are buzz words. They are buzz words used increasingly by successive governments since the early 1980s to justify new imposts because those governments chose to legislate in certain ways. In other words, the need for so-called cost recovery is created first by government legislation, then or some time later down the track the government decides that its laws have created the need for that very same government to claw back some, all or more of the cost that its own laws were responsible for inflicting. These bills are a classic example. Hitherto, there was no licence fee for customs depot licensing charges. Previously, import processing charges might have been expected to raise $17.6 million in a full year. But with the passage of this legislation the take will increase by just over $44 million or 250 per cent. A more modest-or is it less ambitious-increase is in the cost of section 85: warehouse fees, computer recovery, refund applications and overtime for official services of $372,000. Nearly 11 per cent extra will be raised. The full-year addition to revenue raised under the provision of all three bills being debated cognately will be just under $46 million-an increase of 69 per cent. This is not a bad little earner in times of low inflation. It might be laughable, given in particular the minister's crazy justifications for the imposts-if we could ignore some of the more serious implications. Where will the costs fall, for example? The costs will be borne by small businesses and consumers-a pretty good double for the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. He might very well be better described by the minister versus small business and anti-consumers. It might be fair to ask the minister how he can look either proprietors of affected small businesses or consumers in the eye, but of course he does not. If this is an example of a minister who is for something, in this case small business and presumably consumers, God help us all if he were against them. Most import agents may be held up as classic examples of small business proprietors. Most other importers are small business owners who do not need, so far in our history, the cost of employing import agents. It is unarguable that these new charges will fall disproportionately on small businesses and their clients. But it does not stop there. Many, if not most, of the clients of import agents are in turn small businesses. These are the clients of import agents. It is not clear if the minister to absorb the charges. Surely he is not so silly. He must know that all the additional costs these measures impose will be passed on down the chain, where necessary, through small businesses to the consumers of imported goods. So much for Labor's rorting of the wholesale sales tax system. They must have extracted all the blood that can be got out of that particular stone. The charges raised in these bills are no more and no less than an indirect tax by another name. So the coalition government, with the willing cooperation of the minister, had to scrape the bottom of the barrel and devise new charges, or exorbitantly raise existing ones, all to be embraced under the political speak terminology 'cost recovery'. By way of an aside, if this parliament ever agrees to adopt an across-the-board expenditure tax of one kind or another, it will only be as a substitute for existing indirect taxes including, hopefully, those now before the House. Levied at 15 per cent, one could not expect more because the cupboard is bare. The need for the responsible minister to explain further is not confined to his rhetoric which purports to support either small businesses or consumers. How often have we heard him rabbiting on in this place about the need to cut regulation and red tape, particularly as it affects the small business sector? It was a temptation to say that he may even have waxed eloquent on the subject, except some would not forgive me for such an exaggeration. Here we have another abundance of red tape, which the private business sector in general and small businesses in particular have to unravel at their great cost. Just examine for one minute the charges to be levied for processing imports. For an import entry application lodged electronically, the amount to be paid is $29.65 plus 20c per line after line lO. But, if the application is not lodged electronically, the charge will be $51.40 plus $1 per line after the first line. We do not seem to be told whether the importer has to have IBM compatible equipment to electronically lodge an application for an import entry, but it is probably buried in some obscure regulation either already at large or expects agents to be devised. The next category involving a charge or charges is an application for import entry by air or post lodged electronically, in which case the fee will be $22.80 plus 20c per line after line 10. A similar application not lodged electronically will cost $44.55 plus $1 per line after the first line. For sea cargo, a fee of $2.60 per manifest line will be payable, $3 per house or straight line airway bill, whatever that might mean, and finally a screen fee charge of $2.40 per house or straight line airway bill. The total to be raised by these charges will be $61,675,000 in a full year. However inconsequential the descriptions of the charges may seem, the cost to be added to imports is no mean figure. I have heard about journalists and others being paid by the line or according to the number of words written, but this one takes the cake. Perhaps the best advice we can give to affected importers is that they lodge manual applications, write in very small letters and use abbreviations of the kind used by the real estate industry in advertisements used to flog off houses. But even then, at $1 per line after the first line as well as an upfront charge, almost in both cases about double that of the electronically lodged equivalent, the manual alternative remains less than attractive. The message to hundreds of affected importers is that, if you do not already have a computer compatible with that used by the Customs Service, go out and buy one. But isn't that a cost of compliance? An interesting outcome, if not intent, of the electronic lodging provisions in this legislation is that boutique importers who do not have this capacity may be driven to engage an import agent. Do-it-yourself business people who have hitherto made their own arrangements with a minimum of fuss might be better served to hire an agent rather than pay the premium to be imposed on the cost of manual lodgments. And all for what-to suit the convenience of a government agency, a convenience that the minister has not even attempted to argue in his presentation. Such an outcome will involve a further increase in compliance costs for affected importers not previously needing to hire import agents. Talking about the cost of compliance, I have thumbed through all three explanatory memoranda and I cannot for the life of me find an estimate of the cost of compliance. Surely we have to have superseded copies, because I have heard the minister talk, almost to the point of tedium, about the evils of compliance costs inflicted on small businesses by government legislation and regulation. Perhaps the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who is at the table, could give me the correct memoranda, which would undoubtedly include estimates of the cost of compliance with these bills, given the minister's strident advocacy in opposition to and awareness of burdensome costs of compliance with all types of legislation, let alone that for which he has sole responsibility. It is obvious that such estimates are possible because each memorandum contains estimates of the amounts to be raised in a full year in each of the seven categories to which reference has already been made. For example, category 1, where an application for import entry is lodged electronically-the charge being $29.65 plus 20c a line after line 10-will raise $24,386,000. The manual equivalent, the second category, will raise $585,000 in a full year. Category 3 will raise in a full year $30,314,000, and so it goes on down to category 7. If it is possible to estimate the revenue, it is equally possible to estimate the cost of compliance. But compliance cost estimates are nowhere to be found, and I do not see anyone rushing around the chamber trying to find me more up-to-date memoranda which might include the information. It raises the question: was this proposed legislation referred to the Small Business Deregulation Task Force, which has recently reported to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)? That question gives rise to two further queries. Firstly, if it was, what recommendations does the report contain about the increased and burdensome compliance costs which will ensue under these bills and be incurred by importers and consumers of imported products? The second supplementary question is: if it was not, why not? The sad truth appears to be that the quantum of compliance costs has not even been considered by the minister or, if it has, a deliberate decision has been taken to leave the estimates out of his second reading speech and the accompanying memoranda. In either case, a lack of both honesty and courage is in evidence. The minister also seeks to make a virtue of the exemption of exports under what he quaintly describes as 'the new user-pays system' and goes on to acknowledge the contribution of exporters to improving our trade balance, creating more jobs and reducing the federal deficit. So it is demonstrated that the user-pays principle is not inviolate and, to the extent that it is applied to the Customs Service, will continue to absorb the costs of servicing exports. I am not arguing against that, but the point is made: if it is not a firm principle to recover all the costs incurred by the Customs Service where users can be identified, then it ill behoves the minister and his government to pretend otherwise. In all logic, you could not do so, anyway. We know this government is as much in favour of pulling down non-tariff barriers in its quest for fair trading internationally as it is of seeing tariff barriers removed. If it wants to be able to go to the World Trade Organisation, it wants to go there with clean hands. But wait a minute-what have we got here? New, increased and hefty charges on imports of a non-tariff kind. There must be some mistake, surely. This is not what successive Commonwealth governments have espoused in recent times. What would the Cairns Group say? These are amongst the most cynically explained and stupidly argued pieces of legislation that it has been my misfortune to come across in 18 years in this parliament. If the government is sincere, why can't it simply say that it needed the revenue to go towards the elimination of Labor's legacy of a $10 billion underlying deficit? Admittedly, it would also have needed to confess to ripping $46 million off consumers by way of an indirect tax by another name, and that is contrary to if not its election undertakings then at the very least the spirit of them. As it stands, the minister has resorted to a charade and has brought no credit to him, his government, coalition colleagues or this House.  Small Business and Consumer Affairs) (5.24 p.m.)-in reply-I thank members for their contributions to the debate on this bill. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time.
