Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL
text: At the outset, I foreshadow that the opposition will be moving amendments in the consideration in detail stage to the Bankruptcy Amendment Bi111996. Those amendments are now being circulated. They are as follows: (l) Clause 2, page 1 (line 9) to page 2 (line 12), omit subclause (2), (3) and (4). (2) Schedule 1, page 4 (line 18) to page 5 (line 11), omit item 13. (3) Schedule 1, page 6 (line 6) to page 11 (line 17), omit item 20. (4) Schedule 3-0pposition to oppose. The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 form part of measures designed to increase cost recovery from the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia and from registered trustees in bankruptcy matters. In total, the measures proposed by the government are designed to raise $22.392 million over four years, being $3.648 million in 1996-97 and $6.248 million per year in each of the out years. The two bills seek to do this by, firstly, increasing the initial flag fall fee on estates administered by the Official Trustee; secondly, replacement of existing fees payable in respect of all bankruptcies by a flat levy on all realisations in bankruptcies; and, thirdly, requiring registered trustees to hold trust funds in interest bearing accounts and to pay the interest earned to the consolidated revenue fund, similar to existing arrangements for interest earned on the common investment fund managed by the Official Trustee. The commitment to greater cost recovery in the personal insolvency area was foreshadowed by the government in meeting our commitments. In that document, the coalition committed itself to raising an additional $15 million over three years in the area of personBiLL 1996 al insolvency. The document stated: There is some capacity for increased cost recovery in ITSA. ITSA has total revenue of approximately $27 million, of which $22 million originates from Parliamentary appropriations. Better cost recovery will result in further savings of $15 million over three years. This proposed greater cost recovery is simply bad policy. The persons ultimately likely to bear the costs of these increased fees will not be the people who either through their own financial mismanagement or circumstances beyond their control have gone bankrupt. Rather, it is creditors, the innocent parties in insolvency cases, that will be left to carry the burden of these increased fees. Most of these creditors are the small business owners whom this government constantly claims to protect. These measures will punish those businesses, not because they have done anything wrong themselves but because they had the misfortune to be dealing with a person who ultimately went bankrupt. Why has the government got this measure so wrong? For a start, one need only turn to the sloppy job that was done in putting this commitment together. The estimates of expenditure and revenue raised by ITSA in Meeting our commitments were based on the 1993-94 annual report. You would think that they would at least have got the most up-todate figures before seeking to make a promise of this nature. As a result, the coalition failed to recognise that in 1995-96 a total of $28.715 million was appropriated to ITSA and approximately $7 million was raised by way of revenue. Even in 1994-95, the most up-to-date financial data would have shown the coalition that ITSA received $27.5 million in appropriations and raised $8 million in revenue. Let me now turn to the individual fee increases. First, the flag fall fee on estates administered by ITSA will rise from $2,000 to $4,000. This measure is expected to raise $1.62 million in a full year. In estimates, the Attorney-General's Department admitted that ITSA had estimated that the increase in the flag fall fee alone will reduce the number of estates producing a dividend from 45 per cent to just 30 per cent. Creditors in one out of every six bankruptcies will now not receive a dividend because of this measure alone. Secondly, the increase in revenue from realisation charges will be achieved via an increase in the flat fee payable from three cent to eight per cent. This measure is expectber ed to raise $4.2 million in a full year. In last financial year, the total dividend paid only $12.4 million. Thirdly and finally, the payment of interest earned on realisation by registered trustees consolidated revenue is expected to raise $430,000 in a full year. This interest is currently paid to creditors. The been calculated on an assumed four per cent interest rate on such accounts, although no minimum interest rate is required by the legislation. The result therefore is a senseless slug that will only harm ordinary Australsix-month ians-principally small business owners. However, I am glad to say that the Bankomy ruptcy Amendment Bill 1996 does have some showed. redeeming features. The bill also makes a number of minor amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1996 which Labor does not to oppose. It is on that basis that I will shortly move an amendment to the Bankruptcy ty. Amendment Bill 1996 which will delete those provisions of the bill which seek to facilitate the implementation of the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996. For the reasons set out above, Labor will be opposing the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 in full. I now tum to the Bankruptcy Charges) Bill 1996. Clause 4 of the bill imposes a fee of $1,500 on applications to become a registered trustee. Clause 5 imposes a $1,000 registration fee. As a result, first time applicants to become registered trustees must pay a fee of $2,500. Clause 6 of the bill also imposes a $1,000 fee for extension of registration. Clause 7 imposes a $500 fee for variation of the condition attaching to a person's registration as a trustee. I note that the introduction of fees for registration as a trustee, similar in magnitude to the above, were foreshadowed by the previous Labor government's Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. Accordingly, Labor will support this bill. These bills also provide me with an opportunity to raise a matter of growing concern in the the community and that is the growing number of bankruptcies. If one looks at the rate of per bankruptcies over the period from the Septemquarter of 1992 to the June quarter of the 1995, one notices a very stable number of was bankruptcies in the community with figures coming in consistently averaging 3,600 per quarter. However, over the last year or so, we have seen a disturbing trend. In the September to and December quarters of 1995, the number of bankruptcies rose to approximately 4,000 a quarter. This jumped to approximately 4,400 revenue has in the March 1996 quarter. Before the government jumps up and starts blaming this rise on the previous Labor government, I think we all know that in the lead-up to the last election the economy could be reasonably described as having collectively held its breath. The econflattened somewhat as all the indicators However, with the election of the Howard seek government, we were promised a sudden boom in confidence in the business communiQuite simply, this has failed to materialise. As a result, the number of bankruptcies rose to over 4,800 in the June quarter and to a staggering 5,400 in the September quarter, the highest on record, I believe. Far from getting the post-election bounce that was promised, by pulling half a per cent of GDP out of the economy this government has set Australia on (Registration a dangerous path. As the September quarter figures show, the total number of bankruptcies and part X arrangements, assignments and compositions have risen in Queensland by over 45 per cent on the previous year. In the Northern Territory, Tasmania and Western Australia, the rises are 50 per cent, 54 per cent and 55.5 per cent respectively. In the ACT, the part of Australia most immediately impacted upon by this government's slash and bum approach to economic policy, the rate of bankruptcies has risen by a staggering 63 per cent on the previous year. One of the few states to buck this trend is, not surprisingly, New South Wales, the only Labor state, which had the lowest rate of increase in bankruptcies at only 19.6 per cent. As members would be well aware, bankruptcies are one of the key indicia of the health of an economy. These figures demonstrate that, under this government, the economy, rather than booming along, is sliding into recession. Finally, I wish to tum to the appalling way this government has handled the pursuit of Christopher Skase. We heard last week that the chase for Skase has been resumed, but only after this government and, in particular, this Attorney-General (Mr Williams) let the Australian people down by failing to seize the first available opportunity to continue the pursuit of Mr Skase. On 26 August 1996, Mr Max Donnelly, the trustee of Mr Skase's bankrupt estate, made an application under section 305 of the Bankruptcy Act 1996 for financial assistance to further pursue the assets of Mr Skase. Section 305 of the act vests the power to grant such assistance in the Attorney-General. However, as most of these decisions are primarily bureaucratic in nature, the power has been delegated to the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and the assistant secretary of the secretariat branch of the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia. On 27 September 1996, the assistant secretary, pursuant to delegation, determined that the application should not be granted. Without knowing more about the detail of that application, it would not be appropriate for me to criticise whether that decision fell within the guidelines. However, the decision failed to understand the importance of Mr Skase as a symbol of the excesses of the corporate Australia of the 1980s. It failed to recognise the deep hurt felt by the many ordinary Australians who lost money to this deceptive man. It failed to recognise the importance of taking all reasonable steps to pursue this man to the ends of the earth, to not allow him to forget what he, through his dishonesty and deception, had done to the good reputation of Australian business, to the esteem in which our laws were held and, most importantly, to the livelihoods of many good, honest, hard working Australians. That a bureaucrat, strictly applying a section strictly in accordance with the issued guidelines, should too narrowly construe his duty is perhaps capable of comprehension. But, mindful of the very real anger felt by the Australian public towards Mr Skase, mindful of the damage he has done to our reputation and mindful of the way he continues to snub his nose at Australia and the rule of law from faraway Majorca, for the Attorney-General to initially condone such a decision is simply deplorable. As was revealed in Senate estimates, the Attorney's office was briefed to the effect that the Skase decision was pending and it was likely to be on 24 September 1996, but the Attorney failed to act. His office was formally notified of the decision on 2 October 1996. Again, the Attorney failed to act. Despite having the power to overturn this outrageous decision, the Attorney failed to act prior to the decision becoming public on 9 October 1996. Even then, despite his office being told the afternoon of that day that the story was about to break that evening on A Current Affair, and despite knowing that at any time he could have overturned that decision, the Attorney failed to act. Even when he did act, it took the Attorney six weeks to make a decision he could have that made at any time. The fact that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) then had the audacity to blame the bureaucrats for a decision which they knew the Attorney knew about and which the Attorney's own inaction had condoned is not only one of the most appalling acts of denial this place has seen but also one of the most stupendous failings of ministerial responsibility of recent times. The Attorney owes an apology to hoteliers in Adelaide, florists, airlines, service station owners, limousine companies, computer firms, caterers, accountants, electricians, lawyers, couriers and even a Brisbane pub, who are all owed money by Mr Skase. He should explain just how he got this decision so terribly wrong. Just as importantly, he should apologise to the bureaucrats whom he has left carrying the can as a result of his own deeds. Even today some questions still remain unanswered. The government is refusing to reveal how much money the Attorney has set as the limit for the funding of the continued pursuit of Mr Skase. All the Attorney has said is that the amount is comparatively small when compared with the $800,000 spent to date. I suspect that the reason why the Attorney will not reveal the sum is that it is embarrassingly small. It is so small that he is afraid it will show the government's decision to be nothing more than a cheap political stunt. It is hard to believe that Mr Skase will know what the nature of the action is simply because of the total amount of money to be spent. So what have the Attorney and this government got to hide? There is no reason why the amount approved should not be released. The Attorney should come clean and do it now. This whole affair has been poorly dealt with by this government. Not only has it put at risk the important task of pursuing the assets held by Mr Skase that belonged to his fellow Australians; it also shows that this government does not understand the real pain and hurt caused to ordinary Australians by the profligacy of people such as Mr Skase. I welcome, and so does the opposition, the government's decision to resume the chase for Skase. It is a pity that the Attorney appears not to have given this matter the commitment that it deserves when he initially did what he did. That commitment is important. Nothing less will satisfy the understandable outrage felt by the Australian people at the way this government and this Attorney have handled the issue. Nothing less will help to placate the anger the Australian people feel at the way Mr Skase has shown disrespect for them and for our legal system.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL
text: Fisher) (5.46 p.m.)Listening to the pious words from the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), one could be forgiven for omitting to remember that the Labor Party has been in office for most of the last 14 years. He mentioned small business. He mentioned bankruptcies. He mentioned Christopher Skase. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be well aware that the excesses of the 1980s in corporate Australia occurred under the management of the former government. You would also be aware that the former government attempted--obviously not successfullyto recover assets from Mr Skase. I would like to reject the criticisms made of the Attorney General (Mr Williams) by the honourable member for Banks. As the honourable member for Banks would know, the Attorney General is a very effective minister, a person who approaches his duties with a very great degree of ability and diligence. Dr Kemp-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL
text: The minister at the table agrees. The Attorney-General has done the right thing. The Attorney-General has responded to concerns in the Australian community, and this government will continue to pursue Christopher Skase's assets. I must also reject the comments made by the honourable member for Banks concerning our approach to small business. This is the first government that has come forward with a firm program to recognise the fact that small business is the engine room of the Australian economy. In doing that, you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Minister for Small  has made a large number of announcements concerning the way in which small business will be able to do what it does best-that is, get down to business and create jobs. You would also be aware of the drops in interest rates that will assist small business to grow and invest, and you would be aware of the fact that the parliament has now passed the industrial relations legislation which will do away with Labor's job destroying unfair dismissal laws, enable Australia to get down to work and enable the creation of more jobs. I am pleased to join the debate on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996, the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996. As has been indicated, these bills are being debated in a cognate manner. In accordance with the policy announced in our Meeting our commitments document, the level of cost recovery from bankruptcy activities involving the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia will be increased by an amount estimated at $3.648 million in 199697, rising to $6.248 million per annum in out years. Creditors who benefit from a credible and effective personal insolvency system will thus meet a more appropriate share of the cost of maintaining and administering that system. The increased revenue will come from three measures. First, the initial fee charged by ITSA when administering bankruptcies which have funds in them will be increased from $2,000 to $4,000. This will produce increased cost recovery for the direct use of ITSA services by creditors of an estimated $1.6 miilion net per annum in a full year. Secondly, the current fee charged-three per cent--on all amounts realised and credited to trust accounts of bankruptcies administered by both ITSA and registered trustees will be replaced with a flat realisations charge of eight per cent. This increase will contribute the cost borne by government in providing various ITSA services for the benefit of the full commercial community. This measure is estimated to produce an additional $4.2 million net in a full year. Thirdly, interest earned from trust funds held in bankruptcy and part X administrations which are administered by private registered trustees will be payable to consolidated revenue to further partly offset the cost borne by the taxpayer in maintaining the bankruptcy system. This has been the case in bankruptcies administered by ITSA since 1980, and the measure will thus place all bankruptcies on an equal footing. It is estimated this will produce an additional half a million dollars net in a full year. These arrangements are similar to those which apply in all states where interest on solicitors' trust accounts is used by law societies for public purposes such as the regulation of solicitors and the funding of legal aid. The combined effect of these measures will place all creditors, whether their bankruptcy is administered by ITSA or by registered trustees, on a more equal footing in terms of contributing to the cost of the bankruptcy administration system. The increased charges and fees will only apply in those matters where there are funds. They will not impact on bankrupts. Legislation is necessary to introduce these measures and, in respect of the increase to ITSA fees, will apply to new bankruptcies after the commencement date of the amendments. The legislation will also produce a simpler collection method for fees and charges that are taken. It will streamline administrative practices for both ITSA and registered trustees. For instance, private registered trustees will no longer be required to open a separate bank account for each estate nor issue receipts in respect of each payment into the estate. The government once again is taking the opportunity to reduce the level of paper work required of registered trustees. There has been some criticism of our plans to increase cost recovery of ITSA bankruptcy services. How can we justify this? In accordto ance with the policy announced in Meeting our commitments, increased cost recovery from ITSA will raise an additional estimated $22.3 million over four years. Creditors who benefit from a credible and effective personal insolvency system will now bear a more appropriate share of the cost in administering that system. The proposed fees and charges are not altogether new. They involve an increase in existing fees already collected or, in the case of interest from trust fund moneys in administrations of registered trustees, they apply requirements that have existed in respect of ITSA bankruptcies since 1980-16 years ago. The proposed arrangements for taking interest earned on trust fund monf!Ys administered by registered trustees are similar to the situation affecting ITSA bankruptcies since 1980. They are also similar to arrangements which apply to all states where interest on solicitors' trust accounts is used by law societies for public purposes such as the regulation of solicitors and the funding of legal aid. The combined effect of these measures will place all creditors, whether their bankruptcy is administered by a registered trustee or by ITSA, on a more equal footing in terms of contributing to the cost of maintaining the hankruptcy administration system. The increased costs and charges will apply only in those matters where there are funds and will not impact on bankrupts. The legislation will produce a simpler method for collecting fees and charges. As I have outlined, there are three bills: Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996, the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996. The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill proposes amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 that are consequential on the proposed enactment of the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill-the bills being debated cognately today. At present, fees and charges are imposed by rules made under the act. With the enactment of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, these fees and charges would have been imposed under regulations made for that purpose. Introduction of a new interest charge and changes to the way in w'hich existing fees and charges are calculated in respect of reali sations and registration of trustees are proposed. The introduction of these proposed new arrangements imposing charges will require the enactment of new legislation. Consequential amendment of the act to give effect to these changes is also required and is proposed in this bill. The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill proposes the removal of references to prescribed fees and their replacement with references to the appropriate proposed charges bill-one of the cognate hills. Additional provisions are also proposed to provide for administration of the proposed charges bills, in particular to allow for the orderly collection of charges by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy on behalf of the Commonwealth. Provisions are also proposed to allow for extensions of time in which to pay charges and the remission of penalties and charges in appropriate circumstances. The opportunity has been taken to streamline administration of accounts held by registered trustees by allowing them to consolidate trust account moneys into a single account if they wish to do so and they will be no longer required to issue receipts for moneys paid into accounts in all cases. They will also be no longer required to furnish receipts to the Official Receiver at the conclusion of an administration. The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996 also ensures that the Inspector-General will be the responsible for ensuring the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act 1996, the proposed Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 are complied with, and appropriate powers to allow this to occur are contained in the bill. It is clear that the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 proposes the introduction of charges in respect of the estate administration function carried out by registered trustees and the Official Trustee under the Bankruptcy Act 1966. The realisations charge was previously imposed in the rules made by the Bankruptcy Act 1996. As a result of the enactment of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, rules will no longer be made under that act. Instead, regulations will be made in relation to appropriate matters. The opportunity presented by the changes resulting from the need to revise the rules has been taken to enact separate legislation in respect of charges relating to bankruptcy, rather than imposing them by regulation. The interest charge is a new charge imposed in respect of interest earned on funds held in trust by registered trustees in relation to estates and other matters administered by them. The introduction of the proposed charge will place these estates on the same footing as those administered by the Official Trustee where funds held on behalf of estates and debtors are held in the common investment fund and the interest is paid to consolidated revenue. The third bill is the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996. This bill proposes the imposition of charges in respect of applications for registration of trustees in bankruptcy, registration of trustees, reregistration and applications to vary conditions on registration. These charges were previously imposed in the rules made under the Bankruptcy Act 1966. Enactment of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill would mean that rules will no longer be made under that act. Instead, regulations will be made in relation to appropriate matters. Opportunity has been taken to enact these charges in legislation rather than imposing them by regulation. I believe this is a very positive step because, quite often, there has been the accusation under succeeding governments that by passing so many matters over to the executive the parliament is in effect negating its responsibility to determine what the law ought to be. The fact that we are indeed enacting these changes in legislation rather than by imposing them by regulation is a very important step forward. The issue of bankruptcy in Australia is clearly a very difficult subject. There have been Commonwealth acts relating to bankruptcy for a very long time. As in so many other areas in the law, it is a question of the appropriate balance. In bankruptcy one wants to give the bankrupt person the opportunity to make a fresh start, make a clean breast of things, make a new life and take the opportunity to commence in business again. Having said that, it is important to recognise that a person who has gone bankrupt clearly has committed an act of bankruptcy and usually owes a considerable amount of money. Obviously, the creditors must benefit to the greatest extent possible. I think both sides of politics would not dissent from the principle that the bankrupt ought to be given the chance for a fresh start while ensuring that the creditors are treated in the best possible way. Where both sides of politics differ from side to side is in determintraverse ing the appropriate balance. We believe that the amendments we are debating in the chamber tonight are an appropriate balance. We reject the criticisms made by the honourable member for Banks about this legislation, about the conduct of the Attorney General and about our approach to small business. We are a government which was elected on 2 March to give the people of Australia a fresh start. We achieved almost a record swing at the election. I am disappointed that those opposite simply have not recognised that they did not win the election. They will not accept that we have a mandate for these changes to the law; on that we have a mandate for so many other reforms which will result from our policies. I am very pleased to have risen in the forward chamber tonight to speak to these three cognate bills. I am confident that, whatever amendments the honourable member for Banks might choose to move, the House in passing judgment on those amendments will support the approach taken by the Attorney General. I commend the bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL
text: As the previous speaker, the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), has mentioned, bankruptcy is a very troubled subject. It is rare that any of the people who are associated with a bankruptcy walk away from their experience happy. It is a little bit like family law: there is an absence of goodwill; there is an absence of a desire on the part of many of the parties involved to see the matter to a satisfactory conclusion; and there is a lot of ill feeling about the circumstances that may have led to the bankruptcy. I do not believe the law in this area is adequate, but I am not sure it is possible to devise a system that will adequately resolve all of the impossible problems that seem to arise in the administration of a bankrupt's estate. The amendments we are talking about this evening will make some improvements, but we would be deluding ourselves if we were to believe that this would bring an end to the problems associated with bankruptcy arrangements. The previous speaker has outlined much of the detail of these proposed bills; so I will not that ground again. He has outlined what is aimed to be achieved through this group of bills and pointed out the reasons why the government is taking the action which is put before the parliament this evening. I have some reservations about the legislation. I am not sure that I am convinced by the arguments that the interest earned on estates should go to consolidated revenue. Obviously, the big losers out of any bankruptcy action are the creditors. It is the creditors who will be losing out as a result of the interest money going to consolidated revenue instead of being shared amongst the creditors. I acknowledge that interest does go to consolidated revenue in circumstances where the Official Trustee is managing an estate but, in those cases, the Official Trustee is actively involved in the management of the estate. So it is probably appropriate there should be a greater recovery of the costs of that action from those who will get the benefit from it. The new interest charge imposed in respect of interest earned on funds held in trust by registered trustees in relation to estates and other matters administered by them will result in additional revenue to the Commonwealthrevenue that otherwise would have gone to creditors. There would have been two ways of achieving equity between estates managed by private insolvency practitioners and those managed by the Official Trustee. The second way would have been to return the interest to the creditors in both cases, but that would have had a negative impact on the government's revenue. In these current circumstances where the government is endeavouring to fund a $10.3 budget deficit inherited from the previous government, that option-whilst perhaps philosophically attractive-was financially impractical. So once again the government has to make a compromise between what might well be good policy and what might well be financially necessary. In this particular legislation, by ensuring that these charges come through to consolidated revenue, we are doing a disservice to creditors. We are also acknowledging the very obvious fact that the costs of bankruptcy not only fall on creditors, not only go against the bankrupt's estate, not only go to those who are associated with the process but also go to the government who has some responsibility for administering these matters. It is a pretty unsatisfactory state of affairs. The government has chosen this option, which I will not oppose when it comes to a point of a vote, but I have to say that it leaves me somewhat uneasy. I mentioned in my earlier remarks that the whole issue of bankruptcy means a great deal of pain and hardship for the bankrupt. They lose what assets they have been working to build up. In many cases, it ends a dream. There is a loss of confidence for them in their capacity to manage their own affairs and perhaps to work in business again. Of course, it also affects their family and their friends. It puts a great deal of stress on the family relationship. Many bankruptcies lead to breakdowns in families, as well as the loss of friendships and the circle of acquaintanceships which the person once enjoyed. For creditors there are also great losses. They obviously lose money. Inevitably, they do not get the full return of the money owed to them. They feel cheated. They have acted in good faith with the bankrupts but do not get paid for the services rendered. It can sometimes affect their own viability in business. The fact that their bills are not paid does not mean they do not have to pay their creditors so they can be placed in a most difficult cash flow situation. There is frequently dispute and litigation which again leads to loss of time and effort on unproductive causes. They generally have to wait years for results, and not only is the money when it comes to them often much less than they had a right to expect but they have had to wait years to get what they receive-and now, of course, they will not even earn any interest on the funds that have been accumulated by the receiver manager. They have to return payments in some instances, as well, that have been made before a person became bankrupt. I have recently had drawn to my attention a case in my electorate where a business was owed a substantial amount of money by another business. They went to court and a judgment was awarded in their favour with costs. They finally received the payment from their creditor only to find, about three months later, that the business became bankrupt and they had to return not only the amount of their debt but also the court costs which had been awarded in their favour when the judgment was made. These people feel justly aggrieved. The court had found in their favour and their bill was finally paid after years of waiting. They had costs awarded in their favour but when their creditor finally went bankrupt they had to return all the money plus the court costs, then wait for their share of the distribution the bankrupt estate. So there are many unhappy examples of the effect of one business on another when bankruptcy proceedings occur. One of the obvious public examples of concerns in this regard have been the effects on subcontractors when a principal contractor goes bankrupt. Quite often this involves governments as well. There is a natural tendency, particularly from governments but also from people in private industry, to accept the lowest tenderer for a contract. Sometimes they are the lowest tenderer for a reason: they do not really have the capacity to deliver on the contract. So when the principal contractor goes into bankruptcy the subcontractors are left without being paid. I know many submissions have been made; indeed, a private member's bill was introduced into this parliament by the former member for Dawson to seek to protect contractors in these sorts of circumstances. It is a very difficult area. The former Labor Deputy Premier in Queensland also propose similar legislation. But when it comes to bringing it into existence, it is not as easy it might seem. There is no doubt that many people who start off in business by acting as subcontractors for principals in large contracts find that all their efforts are wasted when, through no fault of their own, their principal contractor goes into bankruptcy; they are not able to be paid for the work they have done and so their own business fails. Sadly, there are also some people who abuse the bankruptcy laws. There are people who avoid their financial responsibilities by irresponsibly running up debts which they have no intention of ever paying. Some people have no sense of shame about bankruptcy. It is just regarded as a part of business. They will walk away from their responsibilities and, as soon as possible, start up a new business and perhaps go through it all again. This also sometimes happens to people with very small means, even people who are just working in a trade, PAYE taxpayers and others. It is a matter of regret that some people buy electrical appliances, motor vehiof cles and all sorts of things that they cannot afford, with no real intention of paying them off. They willingly go into bankruptcy and leave businesses around town having to pick up the bits and pieces. Those sorts of things are really unacceptable. It is immoral behaviour but it is happening more and more. I do not know how you pass laws for morality. In reality, whenever we introduce laws into this parliament there are some people who are too clever and who find their way around them. The laws which I referred to previously, which affected one of my constituents who had to pay back money to a business after it had gone bankrupt, were introduced to try to catch the Skases and Bonds of this world who deliberately siphon their funds away into safe areas before they go bankrupt so they are able to live a lavish lifestyle, even though their creditors go unrewarded. In many of these cases, people-particularly the small people-have no assets and so go unpursued. It is completely pointless for a business to go to court, even to get them declared bankrupt, because the costs of all as that action are more than they are likely to recover. Again, my attention has been drawn by a constituent to a problem within my own electorate of a man who has gone bankrupt owing about $100,000. He is still driving around in his wife's car and living in the house that was transferred to his wife several years ago. He has substantial superannuation and life policies which are exempt from realisation for the benefit of his creditors. My constituent asked me, I think quite justifiably: why can people put large amounts into superannuation and that money be safe from creditors? It seems in this instance there is substantial evidence to suggest that the person was aware of the fact that he had debts beyond his ability to pay and manipulated his affairs so he could continue his lifestyle and leave his creditors receiving nothing. In this case, the creditors pursued him: they spent $16,000 in legal expenses to be told that they could expect to recover absolutely nothing. So the creditors' savings have been lost in a fruitless pursuit of somebody who, it seems, knowingly defrauded them of the funds that were rightfully theirs. Yet nobody is going to prosecute in this case, nobody is going to take this person through the courts, because it will be seen to he a useless exercise. I think there is a need to have some kind of effort made by law enforcement authorities to endeavour to follow through some of these cases where there may not be a lot of money involved but where there has clearly been a wilful attempt to defraud the rights of the creditors. I know that over recent times it has been increasingly difficult in business. The number of hankruptcies has increased substantially over recent years. Labor's economic policythe 24 per cent interest rates, their punitive taxation measures, the crushing business paperwork-has really made it very difficult for many people to succeed in business. When the Labor government came to office, there were about 5,000 bankruptcies a year between 1982 and 1985. By 1991-92, the numher of bankruptcies had risen to 16,000. Since that time, in each financial year, there have been around 14,000 bankruptcies in a year. Many businesses are finding it increasingly difficult to survive under the threat of government regulation, the difficulties of competing with the multinational corporations, the huge shopping centres, the Coles Myers and so forth of this world. They have also found it difficult to make payments such as fringe benefits tax, superannuation payments, the increasing workers compensation fees and the like. All these have really challenged business people to succeed. There has heen increasing business regulation, and all of this has made it very difficult. But another problem has developed as a by-product of the large numher of redundancies that have bcen offered in the Public Service and in puhlic instrumentalities over recent times. MallY of the people who are receiving suhstantial redundancy payments-even volunteering to receive those payments-do so hecause they would like to have a go in small business. They leave their former, sheltered position in the Public Service to try to find a job running their own business. Business looks very easy from the outside, so they often go to the sunbelt areas of Australia where there are strong levels of growth. Many of them come to my own electorate and buy a small business, with little knowledge about how to operate that business, how you need to develop a cash flow, a business plan, how you need to work through the various issues that are associated with running your business. Many of them have absolutely no management skills. They do not know how to assess the financial records that have been put in front of them before they purchase the business. They often pay far too much for what the business is actually capable of returning. In fact, in electorates such as my own there is a developing trade in small businesses. People establish a business, develop attractive premises and then wait for somebody to move up from the south or come from a redundant Public Service position with a substantial amount of cash to invest in the business. Sadly, most of those businesses fail because of a lack of business expertise and a lack of capital, and a lot of people are hurt. The redundancy payment is gone, which leaves the individual disillusioned with business, with the community and with his own capacity to work in private industry. Of course, they also leave creditors around the town dissatisfied and upset that their accounts have not been paid. Many of these circumstances lead sadly to bankruptcy. Some of these people get advice early enough to be able to get out of their business or to get some management expertise to help them through. I caution all of those people who find themselves with a windfall amount of money from a redundancy payment or from superannuation to look closely at the business that they are choosing to enter before they make that financial commitment. They should make sure that they have got a business plan, get some expert financial advice, talk to people in the community about the record of the business that they are proposing to buy-does it really have a capacity to give them the lifestyle, cash flow and income that they had been used to? Sadly, so many of these cases lead to bankruptcy, a loss of whatever assets the people have ever had and certainly the loss of their own confidence in their capacity to be successful in private industry. We have these many unhappy circumstances associated with bankruptcy: the unhappy experiences of losing life savings, losing friends and contacts, the discord that is always associated and the angry words. Insolvency practitioners have a very unpleasant task, Sure, their income is preserved-they are the only ones that get out of a bankruptcy with their income in place-but they have to accept a great deal of abuse and anger at creditors meetings. And then when the news finally comes through that the payment will be only a few cents in the dollar, everybody is critical. There are some insolvency practitioners as well who leave a lot to be desired. I am aware of one case where there had been gross mismanagement of an estate. Fortunately there was another lawyer who was prepared to pursue the case as a white knight. The incompetence of this practitioner was well established but his only penalty was the voluntary surrendering of his licence. The creditors had to walk away, getting only a fraction of what they should have received. I call on the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) to use the additional funds that are going to be coming his way as a result of the interest funds that are going to be transferred to make insolvency practice work better, to make sure that estates Slipper, P. N. are managed efficiently and well and to ensure that creditors get the maximum value for the dollar spent. Debate (on motion by Mr Marek) adjourned. text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (i) Neither the Speaker of the House of Representatives nor the President of the Senate represented the parliamentary departments in ERC budget funding discussions. The measures that have directly impacted on Members are: a reduction in expenditure on security services, which may cause inconvenience to building occupants arising from the more restrictive opening hours of access doors and the closure of some interchange points during non sitting periods (this measure was implemented jointly with the Department of the Senate); a reduction in Members' personalised stationery entitlement, a reduction in the number of daily newspapers supplied during sitting weeks to Members (from three to one), and reduced staffing for Members' keyboard support pools; and some reduction in planned funding for the replacement of Members' computing and office equipment. In terms of broader support services to Members, for example, secretariat services to committees, the Department of the House of Representatives was unsuccessful in obtaining additional funding for new parliamentary committees established for the 38th Parliament. Up to now, the principle has always been that the Department has received additional funding for the net increase in Committee activity. This principle is considered fair and reasonable given that the establishment of the committees is a decision of the government and the Parliament and not the Department of the House of Representatives. To absorb the cost of the net increase in committee activity and to contribute to the funding reductions imposed on the Department, staff resources available to individual committees have been reduced. The savings were achieved through the introduction of linked secretariats to support pairs of committees. If the House agreed to the establishment of additional committees in the next 12 months or required an existing committee to undertake additional functions, additional funding would be essential. If additional funds were not provided this would have an impact on resources presently allocated to all existing committees. Mr Miles to present a Bill for an Act to amend certain legislation administered by the Treasurer, and for related purposes. Mr Latham to move That this House: (1) notes with concern the contents of the Treasurer's answer to question No. 593 (Hansard, 18 November 1996, page 6997); (2) condemns the Treasurer's decision to amalgamate the Industry Commission, Economic Planning Advisory Commission and Bureau of Industry Economics into a new Productivity Commission prior to the introduction or passage of enabling legislation in the Parliament; (3) condemns this abuse of the executive arm of government as a complete breach of the Prime Minister's election promise to make the role of Parliament supreme over the powers of the executive; and (4) notes the need for alternative economic advice and debate outside the orthodox stream, especially with regard to labour market theory, wages policy, exogenous growth theories, national savings strategies and the cultural and spatial features of economic activity. The following notice was given: Mr Latham to move That this House: the (I) notes the Treasurer's answer to question No. 578 (Hansard, 18 November 1996, page 6997); (2) expresses its concern at the failure of the Government's national savings strategy to take account of the substitution effect between private savings and public savings; (3) notes the Government's adoption of the flawed NOTICES twin deficits theory as the basis of its fiscal strategy; (4) expresses its concern at savings measures which will have the counter-productive impact of: (a) cutting jobs in the non-traded sector; and (b) reducing Australia's traded competitiveness; and (5) expresses its concern at the contradictory nature of the Government's national savings strategy and its intent on monetary and private investment policies. Main Committee adjourned at 12.54 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: International Agreements Implemented by Federal Legislation (Question No. 764) Mr Hollis asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 18 September 1996: Which international (a) conventions, (b) treaties and (c) agreements have been implemented by federal legislation since the answer to question No 2351 (Hansard, 23 August 1995, page 380). Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: I note that the honourable member has asked for this information in a series of questions going back some years. Clearly, there is a need for this information to be made publicly available. In the Government's response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee report Trick or Treaty? Commonwealth Power to Make and Implement Treaties, a commitment was made to provide an annual list to the Parliament of Commonwealth legislation specifically implementing treaties. The complete 1995 list has been compiled and is set out below. The 1996 list is under preparation and will be tabled as soon as possible in 1997. I am informed that the following Acts passed by the Federal Parliament during 1995 expressly implemented international conventions, treaties or agreements. Included under the name of each Act is a brief explanation prepared by my Department which sets out the relevant international convention, treaty or agreement or other matter of international law. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Financial Support Fund) Repeal Act 1995 (No. 13 of 1995) This Act repealed the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Financial Support Fund) Act 1976 which authorised the ratification by Australia of the agreement to establish a financial support fund among OECD members. The fund was designed to assist OECD members facing serious external account difficulties following the oil crisis of 1973-74 and was intended to supplement, on a last resource basis, other sources of credit to which members encountering serious difficulties had recourse. The Act was never proclaimed, NA however, because the fund was never brought into effect due to the failure of some other OECD countries to ratify the agreement. International War Crimes Tribunals Act 1995 (No. 18 of 1995) and Intemational War Crimes Tribunals (Consequential Amendments) Act 1995 (No. 19 of 1995) These Acts provided legislative authority for Commonwealth co-operation with the Former Yugoslavia Tribunal and the Rwanda Tribunal in the investigation and prosecution of war crimes and provided for the Tribunals to sit in Australia if required. Income Tax (lntemational Agreements) Amendment Act 1995 (No. 22 of 1995) This Act gave legislative force to the provisions of the renegotiated comprehensive double taxation agreement between Australia and New Zealand signed on 27 January 1995. The Act inserted the text of the Agreement into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 and made consequential amendments to that Act and to a number of other Acts. Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Act 1995 (No. 38 of 1995) The object of this Act was to ensure, as far as possible, that goods and services were not supplied or exported from Australia or by Australian citizens, residents or companies in circumstances where they would or might be used in the development, production, acquisition or stockpiling of weapons that are capable of causing mass destruction or of missiles that are capable of delivering such weapons. The Act implemented in part Australia's obligations under the Biological Weapons Convention, the Non-Proliferation Treaty and the Chemical Weapons Convention. Overseas Missions (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1995 (No 57 of 1995) and Overseas Missions (Privileges and Immunities)(Consequential Amendments) Act 1995 (No. 58 of 1995) These Acts provided that privileges and immunities could be conferred upon the premises of, and persons associated with, certain overseas missions price in Australia which represent self governing or autonomous foreign territories that are not states and are not recognised by Australia as states such as Hong Kong, New Caledonia and the Cook Islands. Transport Legislation Amendment Act (No.2) 1995 (No 89 of 1995) On 1 November 1994, Australia entered into a treaty with the United States and Canada which requires each country to ban smoking on all passenger flights operated by its airlines between points in the territory of one party to the treaty and points in the territory of another party. Amendments to the Air Navigation Act 1920 under this Act extended the application of regulations banning smoking to foreign registered aircraft operated by Australian carriers overseas. Further amendments were made to the Air Navigation Act relating to aviation security including hijacking and terrorism. Transport Legislation Amendment Act 1995 (No. 95 of 1995) Among a range of other amendments, this Act amended Part IV of the Navigation Act 1912 to enable Australia to adopt a resolution of the International Maritime Organisation that will permit the early implementation of a system of ship survey and certification that is harmonised between the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea 1974 , the International Convention on Load Lines 1966 and the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973. The Navigation Act was also amended to incorporate the terms and principles adopted by the International Maritime Organisation in its International Convention on Salvage 1989. The convention provides greater incentives for effective and timely salvage operations and to assist with the protection of the environment. The Act also made certain amendments to the Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to enable Australia to accede to the 1992 Protocol amending the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1969. Racial Hatred Act 1995 (No. 101 of 1995) This Act, which inserted a new Part IIA into the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, created a civil prohibition of offensive behaviour based on racial hatred and made such behaviour a ground for making a complaint to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Act gave effect to certain obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Trade Marks Act 1995 (No. 119 of 1995) The Trade Marks Act 1995 was the result of an extensive review of Australia's trade marks legislation which was redrafted to meet Australia's obligations relating to trade marks under the Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization. Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendments Act 1995 (No. 121 of 1995) This Act enhanced the extent to which Australia discharges its obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) and the Convention on Biological Diversity. The Act provided an improved administrative framework, strengthened measures against illegal wildlife trafficking and included measures in support of the conservation of Australia's biodiversity. The changes largely arose from recommendations of the Ley Report which reviewed the Act having particular regard to Australia's obligations under CITES. Ozone Protection Amendment Act 1995 (No. 124 of 1995), Ozone Protection (Licence FeesManufacture) Act 1995 (No. 125 of 1995) and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Act 1995 (No. 126 of 1995) These three Acts amended the existing legislative scheme dealing with ozone protection to reflect Australia's evolving obligations under the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. The Ozone Protection Amendment Act amended the Ozone Protection Act 1989. Among other things, the Amendment Act repealed the existing licence and quota system to stop the further import or manufacture of chlorofluorocarbons, halon, methyl chloroform or carbon tetrachloride consistent with Australia's obligations under the Montreal Protocol. International Tax Agreements Amendment Act 1995 (No. 127 of 1995) This Act provided legislative authority for the entry into force of the comprehensive double taxation agreement between Australia and the Czech Republic. The Act inserted the text of the agreement into the International Tax Agreements Act 1953 as a schedule to that Act. Customs Tariff Act 1995 (No. 147 of 1995) This Act replaced the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The new Act incorporated some 350 changes to the International Convention on the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System agreed to by the World Customs Organisation in 1993. Australia became a party to the Convention in 1987. The Act gave effect to Australia's obligations to align its tariff structure with the international standard. National Food Authority Amendment Act 1995 (No. 152 of 1995) This Act established a joint food standards system in Australian and New Zealand including the establishment of a joint standards agency, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Authority. The Act implemented the terms of a bilateral Agreement with New Zealand Establishing a System for the Development of Joint Food Standards. Sex Discrimination Amendment Act 1995 (No. 165 of 1995) This Act amended the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in line with Australia's obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women and other international instruments. The Act introduced a general prohibition on discrimination and an equality before the law provision into the new preamble of the Sex Discrimination Act, made it clear that it was unlawful to discriminate on the ground of potential pregnancy and removed the reasonableness test for direct discrimination on the ground of pregnancy. The Act also amended the special measures provision to reflect the positive role of special measures in the achievement of equality. Family Law Reform Act 1995 (No. 167 of 1995) This Act substantially amended the Family Law Act 1975. Included in the Act was an amendment to insert a new section to allow regulations to be made which will implement the Convention on Protection of Children and Cooperation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption. The section will come into operation when the Convention enters into force for Australia. In addition, the objects section of Part vn of the Reform Act dealing with children recognised a number of rights consistently with the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Family Court of Australia: Appropriations (Question No. 765)  notice, on 18 September 1996: (1) Does the Parliament appropriate money for the running of the Family Court of Australia; if so, what sums are appropriated for specific purposes of the Court. (2) Are there legislative requirements for money to be spent on specific purposes; if so, what are they; if not, why not. (3) Are there differences between the responsibility and accountability of executive Departments for their expenditure and the Family Court for its expenditure, in particular its administrative expendiglobal ture. (4) Is he or his department developing procedures to ensure that moneys appropriated to the Court for specific programs are spent on those programs; if so, will the procedures be legally binding. (5) Were the moneys appropriated for the expanded mediation and counselling services in 1995-96 underspent by 82 per cent and 59 per cent, respectively; if so, on how many occasions has similar underexpenditure occurred within federal courts. Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. The Portfolio Budget Statements 199697 for the Attomey-General's Portfolio-Budget Related Paper No.l.1-lists the following budget estimates for program and running costs for Subprogram 4.2, the Family Court of Australia, for the current financial year: Running Costs-$I04,962,000 Other Program Costs-$735,000 Total Appropriations-$105, 697,000 Less Adjustments (for revenue)-$709,000 Total Outlays-$I04,988,000 (2) Yes. Chapter IV of the Constitution and Part V of the Audit Act 1901 require that funds be spent for the purposes for which the funds are appropriated. The funds appropriated for Sub-program 4.2 are for all aspects of the administration of justice and the provision of services by the Family Court of Australia. (3) Yes. While section 38A of the Family Law Act 1975 vests management responsibility for the administrative affairs of the Court in the Chief Justice, subsection 38A(4) of the Act prohibits the Chief Justice from entering into a contract for a sum exceeding $250,000 without the approval of the Attorney-General or acquiring an interest or right in land that would constitute an interest or right in land for the purposes of the Land Acquisitions Act 1989. (4) No. Direct responsibility for the management of the Family Court, including management of its financial affairs, is vested, under section 38A of the Family Law Act 1975, in the Chief Justice of the Family Court. (5) Yes. The figures of 82 per cent and 59 per cent are cited in Australian National Audit Office Report No.4 1996-97, Use of Justice Statement Funds and Financial Position, Family Court of Australia The Report also states that ' ... the Court had the legal discretion to allocate these funds for the purposes the Court saw fit. .. '. The federal courts and tribunals each receive a budget allocation, and have done since they became self-administering. The federal courts and tribunals manage their priorities within their overall funding levels, both within a financial year and across financial years. Union Industrial Action (Question No. 797) Mr Filing asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 8 October 1996: (I) Is it a fact that workplace issues and political motivations of unionists taking strike action in essential services are often not fully reported to the community. (2) Do the actions of unionists engaging in industrial action often affect a wide cross section of the general community. (3) Will he require unions to publish full particulars of strike action in the mass media prior to or during industrial actions so that the community is aware of the reasons for any disruption to essential services. Mr Reith-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) collects data on industrial disputation in Australia, consistent with international conventions. The data are published on a monthly basis and are regularly reported in the press. In line with these conventions, the ABS measures time lost due to industrial disputation in those disputes in which ten or more working days are lost. The data are provided on an industry basis and record information about the causes of disputes, including whether the dispute is over wages, conditions of employment, trade unionism, managerial policy or other issues. The statistics of industrial disputes are compiled mainly from data obtained from employers (both private and public sector), from trade unions and from reports of government authorities. Particulars of some stoppages, for example State or Australia wide general strikes, may have been estimated and the statistics therefore should be regarded as giving only a broad measure of the extent of industrial disputes. (2) It is undoubtedly the case that some industrial disputes can adversely affect a wide cross section of the community. (3) The Government does not intend to require unions to publish particulars of strike action in the mass media. However, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 contains provisions relating to the notification of 'protected' industrial action, and provisions to minimise the disruptive effects of industrial action on essential services. The Bill provides for a limited right to engage in industrial action or to lock out employees in the negotiation of single-business certified agreements. For industrial action or a lockout to be regarded as protected action (that is, free from certain civil liability) it must take place during a bargaining period, which is initiated by a party given written notice to each other party and to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) about their intention to reach an agreement. Industrial action or a lock out must also meet other conditions to be protected, including that it has been preceded by a genuine attempt to reach agreement, and notice must be given to the relevant party about the proposed industrial action. Where such industrial action is threatening to endanger the life, personal safety or health, or welfare of the population or a part of it, or to cause significant damage to the Australian economy or an important part of it, the AIRC can terminate the bargaining period. The AIRC is then required to conciliate and, if conciliation is unsuccessful and the AIRC considers it appropriate, to arbitrate. Any industrial action or lockout that persists following the termination of a bargaining period is not protected action, and would be liable to the range of remedies and sanctions available for illegitimate industrial action. There is also a limited right to engage in industrial action or to lock out employees in the negotiation of Australian workplace agreements. Immunity from civil liability in respect of such industrial action or lockouts is conditional upon giving notice to the other party of the intention to take the action. Noise Reduction Project (Question No. 865) Mr Zammit asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 October 1996: (1) Has the aircraft noise reduction project involving the insulation of homes in Sydney achieved its objective, particularly in the inner-west area. (2) Has the project fallen short of its target. (3) What progress has been made to acquire residences in the most noise affected areas. (4) What progress has been made to insulate schools and public buildings from noise effects. Mr Jull-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. 85% of those who responded to a recent homeowners survey offered positive comments and felt that the attenuation of their home had been successful. Early results indicate that the Project is achieving the expected reductions in noise level consistent with the type of building construction and the treatment applied. Homeowners are being approached in batches. To date over 1506 homeowners have been directly invited to participate. 1153 homeowners have indicated an interest in participating in the scheme; 449 residences have been insulated and a further 522 have commenced the process. (2) No. To date progress has been consistent with milestones agreed with the Department of Transport and Regional Development. The announced program to the north of the airport is for 4400 houses and an initial group of 350 houses is being insulated to the west of the airport pending the announcement of the new airport operating conditions. Response rate and timing of the work is largely determined by the individual homeowner and the response rate has been increasing as people are becoming more confident in the effectiveness of the insulation. (3) Considerable progress has been made towards acquiring the 150 eligible residences: 123 houses have already been acquired; a further 8 owners have agreed on the terms of sale; the owners of another 13 houses have expressed interest in participating and have sought valuation advice; 6 owners have not responded to communications from the Commonwealth. Acquired houses are being demolished. 75 houses and one block of 12 flats have already been demolished and the sites grassed. A further 13 houses are under demolition and the remainder are in preparation for demolition. The acquisition program is voluntary. The offer, which is open to the end of 1996, allows owners to relocate at their convenience. Valuations are based on fair market value as if the house was not in an area seriously affected by aircraft noise and residents are entitled to seek an independent valuation at Commonwealth expense. If an agreement on the price cannot be reached the matter can be referred to the Australian Institute Valuers and Land Economists for an independent valuation review. The average settlement price of the houses is $215,305. (4) The program to insulate schools, childcare centres, healthcare centres and churches is well advanced. Sixteen schools, two T AFE colleges and 20 pre schools have been noise attenuated. Overall, exceptionally good results have been achieved. Insulation of Newington College is to be completed by February 1998. Work has commenced on the first two buildings. Concept designs and technical briefs are complete for all eight nursing homes/aged care facilities. Redundancy Payments (Question No. 883) Mr Allan Morris asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 30 October 1996: What was the total cost of redundancy payments made to former staff of the Newcastle office of his Department following its closure. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The total cost of redundancy payments to former staff of the Newcastle office was $111,753. Telephone Interpreter Service (Question No. 897) Mr Filing asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 31 October 1996: Will the Telephone Interpreter Service be reduced as a result of fmancial measures announced in the Budget; if so, in which area. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: No financial measures were announced in the Budget which affected the Translating and Interpreting Service (TIS) directly. However, TIS forms part of the Immigration and Multicultural Affairs portfolio, and derives its of funding from within the Department's Running Costs appropriation, supplemented by revenue received from TIS's fee-paying clients. In 1996-97, funding for Commonwealth departments and agencies has been reduced due to both the on-going application of the 'efficiency dividend' (-1 %), plus an across-the-board cut in Running Costs (-2%). Reductions such as these, impact on the TIS funding base. TIS's three functions-translation, on-site interpreting, and telephone interpreting servicescontinue to be provided as they were pre-Budget.
